Hi, it's been a while. Grayewick the Fusionist here, I took a bit of a break from Master Duel and dueling in general, to an extent, just to get myself cleaned off of the tilt and salt that's been building up within me due to the terrible format that is the OCG but hey, I'm back with a deck that I've been using in the Xyz Festival right now, pure Mekk-Knights. As per usual, the cards in the side would be the "nice to haves" or the tech choices I personally would use. "Why play this over Scars turbo?" Well first of all, Girsu, the Orcust Mekk-Knight is at 1 (for some reason), so it's not gonna be as consistent, and second is I do not have the other cards to make it work and I can't fill any good fillers for the strategy because a lot has to go right to pull it off. The Strategy: So, as per usual, the strategy is simple. You build a standard Mekk-Knight list, you stun them with World Legacy's Secrets, World Legacy Whispers, and World Legacy Key, and you beat them down with your Mekk-Knights since they're all just bigger Cyber Dragons. A lot of decks in the event right now are anti-meta Barrier Statue stun or Phantasm Spirals, and this is where this deck shines. ALSO, thank God and everything in creation that Eldlich the Golden Lord is banned, I am so sick and tired of seeing that monki flip deck (even though to a small extent I am partially responsible for it because I've shared some of my list about it but I digress), it's just a deck that could be argued as "maybe fun" to use, but definitely not fun to play against. Discussing the list changes: The only difference between this deck and the usual Mekk-Knight build is that we don't have access to Mekk-Knight of the Morning Star, Lib the World Key Blademaster, or Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax, which makes the zone management a bit more challenging. But the good thing is, since it's an Xyz centered event, a lot of decks are playing the nasty floodgates such as Imperial Order or Skill Drain, both of which we can comfortably play around and through since we play a lot of high-impact going second cards. • x3 Mekk-Knight Avram - Since we also do not have access to the Invoked package, our dedicated Normal Summon will be filled by him. He's a 2000 ATK Normal Monster, which means he can get over the Barrier Statues or Banisher of the Radiance/Banisher of the Light. If you wanna go really budget, that's also fantastic since you can turbo him out of the deck with the freely obtainable Unexpected Dais, but the most important thing is he's a Mekk-Knight, which means your Continuous Spells/Traps work with him. • x1 Mekk-Knight Orange Sunset - This card is usually not being played in most, if not all, Mekk-Knight lists, but since we have space, we could play it just for the name, and it's a 3000 DEF wall. It's effect to Special Summon from the hand doesn't always come up, but it's always nice to have than nothing (I think). • x3 Lightning Storm, Evenly Matched, Forbidden Droplet, Ice Dragon's Prison - The remaining 9 slots of your deck could be any combination of these four cards. I only chose Lightning Storm, Evenly Matched, and Ice Dragon's Prison because it deals better with the anti-meta stuff than Forbidden Droplet, even though clearing our opponent's board seems counter intuitive. • x3 World Legacy's Memory - In pure Mekk-Knight variants, this deck is usually just played as either a 1 or 2 of since it's searchable, but since we do not have access to Lib the World Key Blademaster, it's safe to play it to 3, plus, it's an archetypal Emergency Teleport. • Extra Deck - These are just filler cards. If you have Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy, or both Number 97: Draglubion and Number 100: Numeron Dragon, or any generic Rank 8 monsters that are generally good, play them. So yeah, that's pretty much it. There's really nothing much else to discuss about this deck but have fun, I guess. Until next time.

deck_excerpt: P.U.N.K. synchro deck with the Adventurer engine and Halqifibrax lines.
deck_description: This deck is a little messy, so any comments or assistance would be appreciated. This deck seeks to set up a board of negates with Borreload Savage Dragon, Joruri-P.U.N.K. Nashiwari Surprise/Joruri-P.U.N.K. Dangerous Gabu, and a synchro summon on the opponent's turn into Ukiyoe P.U.N.K. Amazing Dragon.     How does this deck work? Well, the Adventurer Engine and Halqifibrax lines are both self explanatory, but there are some interactions that I want to point out. When using Rite of Aramesir, it locks you out of activating the abilities of normal summoned monsters for the rest of the turn. Most P.U.N.K.s have an ability you will most definitely want to use on their summon, so consider special summoning the ones you want to activate. A few ways to do this:  -Emergency Teleport, search and summon a P.U.N.K. (Ze Amin if you need monsters, Sharakusai if you have the other P.U.N.K. in hand to fusion summon with, or Wagon/Madame Spider depending if you need Spells or Traps)  -Noh-P.U.N.K. Foxy Tune can discard themselves and one card from hand to special a P.U.N.K. from deck  -Noh-P.U.N.K. Dia Note can send themselves from hand to grave to special a P.U.N.K. from hand  -When Noh-P.U.N.K. Dia Note is sent to the grave, you can special a P.U.N.K. from grave  -Lastly,  you can tribute the P.U.N.K. fusion monster (Carp Rising) to special two P.U.N.K.s from deck     Keep these in mind, because we almost always want to activate Rite of Aramesir and set up the Wandering Gryphon Rider as a negate. On most of our starting turns, whether we go first or second, we want to move through the Halq line to get to Borreload Savage Dragon. That isn't hard for this deck; the tricky part is figuring out what we make alongside it.     For now, I'm uploading a list in progress. I'm going to update this description and decklist over time, and any suggestions or comments you have I'm happy to incorporate. Thanks for taking the time to read this!

deck_excerpt: "Eldlich is the best back row stun deck in the current meta" LMAO
deck_description: Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with an actual Fusion strategy again in a long time this time, one that is not necessarily not a top tier deck itself but can definitely kill most top tier decks, especially Eldlich and Drytron, Gravekeeper's Dogmatika. As per usual, cards on the main will be my personal choices based on what cards I currently have, and the cards on the side will be the tech options for you to consider. A few questions: • "Why Dogmatika? That seems counter intuitive since they're all about the GY set up?" - This deck doesn't really care about how fast it wants to win. All it needs is to control the tempo of the game within its reach and be comfortable with that pace. If you can manage to keep that, everything else will follow. But I do admit that often times I find myself lacking necessary pressure, and the Dogmatika cards are just generally great as a supplementary engine for anything that needs that but isn't really concerned about sacrificing their Special Summons from the Extra Deck. I also did some tests with the Shaddoll Schism, and it could be fine, I guess? But for you to be able to access that, you'd need to turn your Necrovalley off first, which isn't good so I've cut it. But what I did consider is putting x3 El Shaddoll Apkallones in the Extra Deck as Dogmatika Punishment targets and including one copy of each Naelshaddoll Ariel, Shaddoll Dragon, and Shaddoll Beast for added utility. The game plan, and the list: It's pretty simple. • x3 Necrovalley - Your boss card, not even a monster, which deals with the GY. If this card properly resolves, you pretty much win the game against most decks. I do not recall any top tier deck that doesn't make great use of the graveyard as of now, but I am damn sure they all do. • x3 Royal Tribute - This card is what truly seals the deal, since it deals with the hand. There's a reason why Confiscation, Delinquent Duo, and The Forceful Sentry are all banned. If I could make a room for Monarchs, I'd even put Thestalos the Mega Monarch in here, but maybe that's a list for another day to test. Phantom Knights need to banish themselves to gain effects from the GY. Drytrons activate from the GY, but tributes for cost and cannot be Normal Summoned/Set. Eldlich also activates from the GY and also sends for cost. It doesn't matter. • x1 Dogmatika Maximus - The one card dedicated to deal with the Extra Deck. This is probably the only list of Dogmatika that I'll use Maximus with, at least as of now, because this list isn't really concerned too much with being able to summon Extra Deck monsters. • x3 Skill Drain, Royal Decree, Jinzo - Any of these three will do, but personally I would choose Skill Drain to deal with on field monster effects. I just want that extra consistency that Pot of Prosperity provides. The latter two for trap heavy floodgates even though we do not really care about that, except probably for There Can Be Only One., also it turns off our Dogmatika Punishments and Solemn Judgments, which is bad because we need protection for Lightning Storm. • x2 Gravekeeper's Supernaturalist - This card is more of a win more card, which also provides itself and your Necrovalley some neat destruction protection. He's a decent beat stick, and he also searches your Hidden Temples of the Necrovalley, which also is in here to deal with Special Summons in general. • x3 Imperial Tombs of Necrovalley - It's an archetypal Infernity Barrier, despite it being a hard once per turn, it's still good to have as an added protection to be considered, although it's an SR so if you're on a budget, I don't really recommend it. Despite winning most of the time without actually needing to Fusion Summon, this still technically is a Fusion strategy so I figured I might want to share it because I love Fusion strategies in general (with a select few exceptions). So yeah, enjoy ruining Eldlich and Drytron players' lists.

deck_excerpt: Yes Libromancer can apparently do more than just Tzolkin Control
deck_description: Just wanna let you know that I and many others want an anthology series of Libromancer support that is playable enough for us to at least let us get as creative and zany as we can be. So in spite of all the constant barrage of ideas of decks for this archetypes, Phantom Knights can indeed run this engine. While not the best in the world, it doesn't take much for it to get what it needs done for the sake of self doubt. In short, just play Phantom Knights how it should be played However the only problem I haven't added for the sake of this being a demonstration deck is the addition of Crossout Designator targets. Other than than, the notion of adding the Libromancer engine is to extend the link plays (if taking the Agent/Doombroker route) or going the XYZ route excluding Raider's Knight (if taking the Geek-Boy/ Firestarter Route). Destroy Phoenix Enforcer also helps in a time of need for he does things (especially Celestial for Draw 2 and Dasher for Special Summoning if you draw into a monster during the draw phase, while in the GY). As for Raider's Knight, he is there for Arc Rebellion XYZ Dragon (indestructible beefcake that could DRNM all monsters on the field the turn it used it's XYZ effect).

Then it branches:  (1) Sack a bunch of monsters to beef up the Shadow Ghoul (Unhappy Maiden. etc.), which pairs well with the Castle of Dark Illusions/Pumpking combo (the zombie deck that could've been :< ).  (2) Get the Battleguard squad growing (using Sangan and Black Forest Witch to get them to your hand if needed). If you can get the Sogen field out there, all the better. deck_excerpt: A Chaos MAX Dragon Focused deck that utilizes Impcantation cards to consistently get OTKS or just overpower opponents.
deck_description: Honestly the extra deck is unfinished, but you won't get too many opportunities to access them anyway because Impcantation locks you out of it. there are plenty of ways to clear your own Impcantation cards like having a bewd in hand and tributing but the goal is chaos dragons regardless. Crealtar also helps with giving your impcantation cards some damage if you didn't summon them in defense AND unlocks your extra deck by negating the impcantation cards but not the ritual ones.  I would say the 5 most replaceable cards in this deck would probably have to be Raigeki, Harpie's, Solemn, Skill drain, and Return of the Dragon lords. They're really only there because of my experience with specific players, I encourage you to swap these out with stuff that suits your playstyle and or builds upon the chaos archetype.  Biggest weakness would definitely have to be the inability to clear the board or negate stuff in general, I used to have ash blossom but I think I can get away with skill drain more with more effect. I found that with most problematic cards, regular chaos dragon would just flip it and the problem was solved.  I see too many chaos max dragon profiles exclude Blue-Eyes Chaos Dragon (the 3000 one) and I don't get why, its so easy to summon both and guarantee you OTK on 2nd turn if the opponent can't negate you and they have at minimum 2 monsters on the field.

deck_excerpt: ABC mixed with Clear New World in order to bring out synchros.
deck_description: This is all based around a brand new card available at common, Clear New World.  Clear New World is situated perfectly for ABC due to the fact destroying your own A,B, or C just plusses you, and with tuner access now allows you to make Baronne along with your normal end board.  The idea is to use the Clear New World with 2 or more ABC monsters on field to grab an Ash Blossom, make Burei to grab Ninishi, then make Baronne.  The side board shows some of my side board and other ideas, like just making Dawn Dragster, or for a budget option using Burei to grab Gama to make Crystal Wing.  I think the general idea of Clear New World is one that needs to be explored more and has a ton of potential.

deck_name: Golden Lord Of The Skull Servants ;)
deck_excerpt: A combination of King of the Skull Servants and Endlich to create a graveyard heavy zombie deck!
deck_description: just put the entire fucking deck into the graveyard then gg.  But seriously this works better than it should. I know I could have cheesed with a LOT more annoying trap cards, but I've been using this in Mater duel against some friends and it's the perfect balance between shitass annoying and creative.  Anyway, quick strategy description; You want wightprince in the graveyard by any means. The most basic way of doing this is playing wightprincess and using her effect. Uni zombie also helps by discarding Wightbaking, which allows you to add wightprince and then discard him. Uni zombie ties both archetypes extremely well tbh since he can send Eldlich and any skull servant/ wight card to the graveyard pretty easily.  Anyway, you eventually use wightprince in the GY to special summon King of the skull servants and just deal a fuckton of damage.  THERE ARE REALLY EASY WAYS TO BACKFIRE. Wightprincess's 2nd effect should generally be used BEFORE you summon Eldlich otherwise you drown your attack points for no benefit.  Also, skill drain does kill King of the Skull Servants' effect so really only use it to stall while you have a Eldlich in your GY so you can get rid of skill drain manually.  Burial from a different dimension is the only thing saving yourself from getting locked when your opponent banishes your monsters, you can play around with the ratios but keeping it at 2 is safe enough for me.  The things this deck can do is insanely fun. There's a lot of cheese you can do to save yourself in the extra deck, especially if you a super unlucky hand of 3 regular skull servants and two wight princes, you can link summon and send them to the graveyard and unbrick yourself. Knightmare works really well for this.  This deck just has so many basic things going for it that's easy to understand and hard to mess up WHILE still having the adjustability of any viable deck.  You have a deck that's really hard to brick yourself, A ton of sustain through your trap cards, ways to thin out your deck to your benefit, and cards with really high attack potential (king of the skull servant).

To be viable en masse, the Ogdoadics need to resolve one glaring issue: Alleirt's recursion of non-HOPT handtraps to the opponent's hand (think veiler). Therefore, another method of preventing the banishment of Nunu and Nauya is required. Using them as XYZ material bypasses that restriction. In comes the time thieves to fill out the remainder of this strategy. Incidental synergy with extenders such as stardust trail, protection via gamma for both your big starters (snake rain and regulator), and follow-up with a searched water lily leading to a Ogdoabyss creates a casual rank-4 strategy.

Your combos can easily access Time Thief Redoer and Retrograde to enable searches of Gamma off of a Lambda. Spicier plays setup a Crossrose Dragon and a Rikka Queen Strenna. The Crossrose can tribute the Strenna, netting a bounce or field wipe and a Hyperyton monster negate.
Dark magician

Upon losing Block Dragon, Adamancipator fell off the map. Other combo decks could do what it did, but better: Infernoble, Drytron, Dragonlink, Virtual World. They were more consistent, not requiring the bricky rocks that built the bulk of your deck should you want to build large combo boards.  However, Adamancipator has an unexplored, and exceptionally powerful synchro: Adamancipator Risen - Leonite. This monster allows you to excavate 5 and add any Adamancipator card (monster, spell, or trap) to your hand, and, if you can get a fire into the GY, can revive a monster on your opponent's turn. Koa'ki Meiru Guardian is the obvious choice, but less obvious option is Adamancipator Crystal - Dragite, who will trigger and let you draw a card.  Add in that their field spell, Adamancipator Laputite, can stack your deck once per turn, and you can fate-seal yourself into two starters and a guaranteed excavation on your following turn, making this strategy incredibly sticky.  This deck is streamlined to do one thing: make Halq and a live Leonite, and start plusing. Handtraps form the backbone of your interactions, and we play a whopping 11 of them. Including the three Forbidden Droplets, and you have a robust package to give you a chance when going second.  If you're tired of being blown out by Dark Ruler no More, and still want to play rocks, this may be right up your alley.

deck_description: If you want to spam, you have come to the right place.  Karakuri recieved some new support some time ago, and I wanted to play it. But it bricked; it bricked hard. Its lines were short, except that occasional golden opportunity that would dump your entire extra deck onto the field, half your deck into your GY, and the other half into your hand. deck_description: You always want to get your fusion monster out turn 1, then use its effects to establish a board.  If you open with the Fusion spell, use it. If you dont, normall summon Genni or Schmietta > use its effect to get the other one> get Potterie. Activate in Schmietta graveyard, sending the fusion spell, then Genni to copy it and fusion summon. Worst case if you have none, you will have to normal summon Potterie or use Creation.  try for lethal when you feel it is safe. Collaboration give double attack to the witches and you have option to link climb into Code talker.  Card choices: -standard Witchcrafters.  -third Genne as how impotant she is to fusion summon  -3 Fusion spells, getting it in open hand is so rewarding it is worth even if you never use 3.  -1 Edel good target for Vicemaster special summon, you never want to draw her. replaceable  -1 Magicians soul, 1 masterpiece  to link climb into charmer -> selene> codeTalker.  -2nd Bystreet, 2nd draping,  : as the deck gets more combo oriented, protection and trap removal get more valuable.  -veiler: hand trap that is spellcaster.  - patronus: testing, may replace it.  -other hand traps: preferences

I like playing Paleofrogs. It's a trap-based strategy that functionally turns into a combo-deck by the end of turn 4. But time has not been kind to the archetype. Control decks like Eldlich and Dogmatika simply outpace it in a few key areas. Recoverability, pressure, compactness, there are a lot of reasons the deck can't stand up to its modern counterparts.  However, for a brief stint, I found the deck rather playable. The frog engine pairs very well with the Numeron engine. Numeron gives frogs a first turn Apollousa or Avramax to pair with your traps. It can also provide an OTK to unsuspecting opponents. Swap Frog's bounce for cost effect lets you clear the field of your normal summon, meaning you can dump a Ronintoadin and resolve a Numeron Network on the same turn. Pair that with arguably the best boss monster in Yu-Gi-Oh, the aptly named Toadally Awesome, and you have a pretty solid deck.  With ZEXAL's ban, I have had to make a few updates, but I am overall still pleased with the deck.
Casual Magnet Warriors, budget

The deck aims to end on Adventurer Token, Wandering Gryphon Rider, Dawn Dragster, Apollousa and Phoenix Enforcer with set Fogblade. Alternatively, you could make Abyss Dweller or Masq in place of Verte into DPE at end. Full board needs Rite of Aramesir and two warriors for Isolde.

deck_excerpt: A Phantasm Spiral Deck focused on control and defending your field.
deck_description:
*This deck is heavily inspired by Yuri who won locals 1st place using a deck like this.* The Phantasm Spiral archetype is underrated. Although non-meta, this deck has a lot of power. It's focused on control and resummoning your boss monster  - the "Phantasm Spiral Dragon". The strategy goes like this:
  • searching out and/or playing your field spell - "Pacifis, the Phantasm City";
  • searching out and/or playing "Megalosmasher X" with "Unexpected Dai" and/or using a token from "Pacifis, the Phantasm City";
  • searching out your Phantasm Spiral spells and/or traps with "Pacifis, the Phantasm City" (when you normal summon), based on the appropriate situation: - traps and "Phantasm Spiral Wave", when you're cornered; - spells (excluding "Phantasm Spiral Wave") to destroy monsters and/or do damage and to summon "Phantasm Spiral Dragon";
  • negating effects (including negating effects that negate and/or destroy your spells and/or traps) using: - "Soul Drain"; - "Phantasm Spiral Power"; - "Fists of the Unrivaled Tenyi"; - "Sea Stealth Attack" (1st effect); - "Called by the Grave";
  • negating attacks and destroying/returning to the hand monsters using: - "Phantasm Spiral Battle"; - "Raigeki"; - "Storming Mirror Force"; - "Sea Stealth Attack" (2nd effect);
  •  and getting the needed cards with "Pot of Duality".
If your opponent tries to destroy your "Fists of the Unrivaled Tenyi" do NOT stop him because if the aforementioned card is destroyed WHILE set, you can special summon from your Extra Deck "Blue-Eyes Ultimate Dragon" which is the strongest monster (in terms of ATK and DEF) in the deck. Also, you should rarely use the Extra Deck except if there's a problematic spell and/or trap card/s on your opponent's field and you don't think that you aren't going to draw cards to negate these effects, THEN you should summon "Knightmare Phoenix" (if you don't have the needed amount of monsters with different names on your field use "Link Spider") and if you've run out of those - "Decode Talker" (if you don't have the needed amount of monsters on your field use "Link Spider"). And if it's your turn, your opponent has a problematic monster, you have 3 monsters on your field (you can also use the effect of Link Spider if you don't have a total of 3 monsters on your field in which case you'll need AT LEAST 1 on your field), turn 2 of them into "Link Spiders", then play "Geonator Transverser" so that it points to one of your monsters which you don't care about AND the problematic monster your opponent has. Use the effect of "Geonator Transverser" AND destroy the monster you gave to your opponent. If you think that "Geonator Transverser" won't point to one of your monsters that you don't care about AND the problematic monster your opponent has, THEN DO NOT summon it. *This deck is heavily inspired by Yuri who won locals 1st place using a deck like this.* An upgraded (more competitive) version of the deck is coming soon. ;)
Heeeeloooo! Welcome to the brand new meta deck with a price of... JUST $200 (~€170) ?! Wow, this is a pretty cheap deck, having in mind how good it is!

deck_name: MASTER DUEL - Resonator Inca/ Red Dragon Archfiend
deck_excerpt: Resonator, Red, Inca, Red Dragon Archfiend, Chaos Ruler
deck_description: Hi :) i'm here with another version of my favorite deck since 2010 NOW for Master duel. This singular version is optimized to play against Maxx C and Ash Blossom. (2 Gamma's. 2 Called and 3 Ash) and maintaining the light attribute spots for Chaos Ruler. Gamma works well even playing 1st due to Crimson Resonator and Inca package (Dawnwalker and Duskwalker) being a hand trigger effect. If your opp triggers maxx c to crimson resonator and you gamma it you will gain a free chaos ruler + light monsters on grave as extenders.   A particular add on this deck was Red familiar. I used to play Witch of black forest, she's good, but only works on field. Red familiar can work as a discard, you can tribute it from field sometimes to get a synchro used from grave and the main reason: from grave you can banish it and module your synchro levels to start your plays from bottom again. One of this deck issues was the fact that it will have follow up from grave, but if you don't draw a non-tuner top deck you can't use de rest of your lvl 6's from extra deck properly.   that's it. hope you guys enjoy :)   https://youtu.be/gfIjF7pwFvc

deck_excerpt: My favourite nun? I think I'd have to go with Sister Mary Phoenix Enforcer
deck_description:
Missionary Brief This is a fun, mid-range, rogue deck that pivots between the Exosister Xyz monsters to build advantage and search on your turn and create adaptable and powerful disruption on your opponent's. The DPE package is used to wear down opponents' resources and provide added disruption. Standard turn 1 involves going into one or two Xyz to search for Exosister spell and traps, protected by Lord of the Heavenly Sky Prison.  The Sisters  The Exosister main deck monsters are devoted to a life of chastity and modesty by which I mean they don't do very much. Bar their quick-Xyz effects they each have either mild swarming abilities or even milder card advantage effects. Elis is by far the most versatile, Sophia is the best to have on board for the free draw and Stella is useful enough, essential three ofs, if just for the names. I'm sure Irene's a lovely gal but her cycle effect is by far the least useful since usually you want to be seeing the Exosister cards in hand, still an important one of for Vadis and Pax. The Exosister extra deck monsters are really where the deck gets to shine providing a wide range of highly useful and relevant effects to stop each of your opponents plays. When Exosister Magnifica arrives with Dimension Force it will be a welcome addition for its high impact and OTK enabling ability. Arment, Pax and Vadis are all fantastic suporting cards to help you build resources on your turn and enable Xyz plays. Carpedivem is a really interesting and versatile support spell that can be used to play around cards like Ash and Nibiru but also turn off floodgates like Skill Drain and Mystic Mine. Rank 4 Extenders I've come to learn that rank 4 extenders in Yugioh are pretty much a game of pick your poison. Dynatherium is close enough the only completely "free" extender for the deck providing at worst a free body and at best providing some quick xyz upgrades for your nuns to punish any opponents on the side of the player base that don't value reading. The deck is built with as few bricks as possible to try and offset the fact the deck struggles to built up card advantage on turn one. The risk of opening double Parallel eXceed however is easily offset by the amount of advantage it can get you (extending from the deck is really good, who knew?!) All your sisters are potencial Almiraj material to get into eXceed plays and even if it gets ashed, you're left with all you need to Anaconda into DPE on exactly your 5th summon. Shade Brigandine is always live turn one and that's when you'll need it most. Even if you have to set it, it at least often has LOTHP protection.  Friends of the Convent Lord Of The Heavenly Prison really is an MVP of the deck. He lets you set multiple backrow turn 1 without worrying about falling foul of a feather duster and allows you to search powerful follow traps for your next, often Vadis or Judgment. He's easily searchable by Gallant Granite who can then be used to make Utopic Draco Future with one of your Sisters or linked off for Anaconda. Called by the Grave and Triple Tac help you play through hand traps and Xyz Reborn gives some recovery otherwise lacking from the deck. Triple Imperm because it's great going first or second and IMO the best hand trap in the game at the moment. F0 and Zeus because they're F0 and Zeus and Gagaga Magician to help facilitate some F0 plays. STRENGTHS
  • It's fun, unique and like any decent rogue option puts an opponent who doesn't know how it plays on the back foot.
  • In the right hands it is incredibly versatile and able to adjust and target disruption on the fly.
  • Good, new support on its way.
  • While it doesn't synergise enough to warrant playing, its generally quite comfortable playing through banish cards like Macro Cosmos
WEAKNESSES + PROBLEM CARDS
  • It's a difficult deck to play. While the cards for the most part function pretty simply there's very few easy wins with this one, one wrong move can lose you a game. Knowing how your opponent's deck and cards work is vitally important in order to target your disruption.
  • The recovery for the deck is really low. If you burn through all your main or extra deck Exosisters you'll be lying high and dry.
  • Going second
  • It's expensive. These days you can build some pretty meta-competant decks on a budget, this is neither.
  • Ash Blossom, Nibiru, There Can Be Only One and Cosmic Cyclone all have the potencial to throw your game plan off big time. Unless you side in Ice Dragon's Prison, it really struggles to get over Dragoon too.
  Constructive feedback and good side deck options always appreciated!
Basic Superheavy deack without Ash Blossom and Joyous Spring

deck_excerpt: Fairly cheap XYZ deck using dolls and Princess Cologne.  Not optimized yet.
deck_description: This deck is based around using Princess Cologne combined with either Grandpa Demetto or Doll House to get XYZ monsters out.  Soul Tiger and Phantom Gryphon could be swapped for other Normal monsters, but you should use level 4 Normal monsters with either 0 Atk or 0 Def.  The 6 Doll Monster cards are required for Doll Happiness to work.  Box of Friends is basically required before you can Princess Cologne on the field in an effective way.  This is easiest with Doll Happiness, but setting Box and letting it be destroyed works otherwise.  Grandpa Demetto, if you already have one Normal monster in the GY and Princess Cologne has at least one material, allows you to SS any rank 8 XYZ from the Extra deck, depending on what you need at the time.  Fortune Fairy Hikari is an additional way to get Demetto out.  There may be a better replacement that doesn't clog your hand if drawn as a starting card.  Doll House allows you to get out rank 6 XYZs, but with the requirement of having 2 Normal monsters in the GY that also have a copy still in the deck.  Use Pot/Jar of Avarice if there are too many in the GY and none in the deck to make this happen.  Nefarious Archfiend Eater of Nefariousness can be special summoned when Grandpa Demetto is on the field, and once it goes to the GY can destroy your other monsters to come back from the GY, proccing Supply Squad, proccing Box of Friends, or just getting rid of a monster you don't need anymore, such as certain XYZ monsters that are out of materials.  Supply Squad and Piercing the Darkness provide additional card draws, and Piercing the Darkness additionally buffs any XYZ monster that used Normal monsters as materials for summoning.  Pairs very nicely with Kachi Kochi Dragon.  Solemn and Ash Blossom probably shouldn't need explained.  Number 97: Draglubion could be easily swapped for a different XYZ but I highly recommend the others, especially Hieratic Sun Dragon Overlord of Heliopolis, which combos with Grandpa Demetto (who will usually be on the field if Hieratic is out, since you need Demetto to create the level 8 materials).

deck_excerpt: Ultimate goal is spyral sleeper, tri-gate, apollousa as your points of interaction. You lose to dark ruler, and forbidden droplet but deck is fun, I l
deck_description: Spyrals have been my favorite deck for as long as its been around. I have tried to keep it viable and this is my 2022 list.  Few glaring issues....     46 card deck and 2 absolute dead cards, 5 undesirable starting cards:  Spyral sleeper, Last Resort, Scrap Golem, Crystron Rosenix, and Codebreaker.     First off the deck is categorized according to Patrick Hoban's Road of the King card categories. So we start with the....Starters. Spyrals lose to handtraps, hard so scrap package is the best way to either bait out hand traps or establish apollousa before double helix hits the field. This also helps get around nibiru. 6 copies split among fossil dig, raptor and scrap recycler. I prefer to dig so having fossil dig helps bait ash, raptor baits imperm and effect veiler and then recycler starts the combo. Raptor also getting its effects negated keeps it on the field to help establish naturia beast with quik fix. Drones is other starter in the deck, its the other normal summon and gets you information.  Extenders are the spyral agent as recycler gets you apollousa and a spyral on field so spyral agent gets you to double helix, but rescue or assault as the spell/trap to pop off scrap package is probably the best start.  Worst part of this deck is the bricking. its a going first so for defense I want to run dragged down to the grave to rip hand traps but also draw cards off it (crossout or called by doesnt get you there). Instant fusion gives you a monster negate and a level one for where arf thou, and called by is called by. Triple tactics can be draw off sylvan xyz later in combo and if you baited out a hand trap its a free draw two or steal a body to combo with.     Ultimate goal is spyral sleeper, tri-gate, apollousa as your points of interaction. You lose to dark ruler, and forbidden droplet but deck is fun, I love the archetype and probably wont ever stop playing going first spyrals.     Try it out!

deck_excerpt: This is what Ultimate Defense in Yu-Gi-Oh looks like
deck_description:
The Deck I grinded to Platinum 1 in master duel with. This is a going first deck Key Card Rulings/ Tips: Megalosmasher X
  • Normal summoning can Proc Pacifis
  • cannot benefit from Sea Stealth's 2nd effect to destroy monsters
  • can be searched with fossil dig
Phantasm Spiral Dragon
  • Garnet "Boss" monster
Card of Demise:
  • Can be activated in main Phase 2 after dealing damage to your opponent
  • Can be used to send Pacifis to the grave as a backup for set sea stealth
  • Activation conflicts with pot of extravagance and prosperity but not duality or Pacifis
  • Be careful not to clog up backrow for more draws
Starlight Road:
  • Used to protect backrow from cards like lightning storm or feather duster
  • Be careful summoning Stardust Dragon after negating because it can disrupt phantasm spiral cards which require all monsters to be vanilla
  • cannot stop Evenly matched
Macro Cosmos:
  • Can be used to bait an ash blossom but utterly useless against us
  • be careful with activating cards like phantasm spiral battle or Power after Macro Cosmos because they have a graveyard effect
Pot of Prosperity
  • Can be activated anytime during the main phase unlike pot of Extravagance
  • Use this card to search key cards in deck based on matchup and/or board presence
Vanity's emptiness
  • Cannot be protected from self-destruction using sea stealth attack's 1st effect
Phantasm Spiral Grip
  • Use this card instead of spiral wave to get more damage or summon a Phantasm Spiral Dragon during the Battle Phase to beat over high attack monsters
  • Can bring out Phantasm Spiral Dragon with 3400 attack from hand, deck or graveyard
  • Conflicts with pot of duality and card of demise
Phantasm Spiral Wave
  • Control card which should be used to make your opponent discard a card of their choice
  • Works well with Macro Cosmos
  • Can be used to bring out Phantasm Spiral Dragon from hand, deck or graveyard
  • Conflicts with pot of duality and card of demise
Phantasm Spiral Battle
  • can be searched by Pacifis
  • can be activated during either's players turn from the hand if Pacifis is out
  • used to disrupt opponent's key plays
  • can be used defensively or offensively to equip all equip cards on the field to 1 monster (most opponents don't read this effect)
Phantasm Spiral Power
  • can be searched by Pacifis
  • can be activated during either's players turn from the hand if Pacifis is out
  • used to disrupt opponent's key plays
  • can be used defensively or offensively to equip 1 equip card from hand or graveyard to 1 monster (most opponents don't read this effect)
Metaverse
  • use this to activate Pacifis from Deck or add to hand (to thin out deck)
Fists of the unrivaled Tenyi
  • Omni-negate for problem cards like evenly-matched or field clears
  • can be used to summon Blue-Eyes Ultimate Dragon which is a normal monster
Sea Stealth Attack
  • Takes a bit of time to setup as it has to be chained in Master Duel because of the way priority works
  • inactive (useless) without Pacifis
  • can be used to activate Pacifis from Grave or Hand when activated
    • the activated Pacifis will be on a separate chain if chaining Sea Stealth and won't trigger Pacifis
  • can be used to protect all face up spells and traps if banishing a water monster
  • Spiral tokens generated with Pacifis will be able to destroy all other monsters even before battling if sea stealth is "active"
    • attacking with a token with an "active" sea stealth will be considered destroyed by a trap effect
    • if the opponent's monster can't be destroyed by spell or trap effects, the monsters will battle normally and tokens will be susceptible to destruction by battle
    • can be used to banish Megalosmasher X to protect it for a turn especially if spiral token is out as opponent's monsters usually can't kill them by battle
    • Megalosmasher doesn't get the destroy effect of Sea Stealth
  • spiral tokens can used as tribute for 1st effect to protect cards but won't return during end phase as token's cannot be banished
    • if opponent activates a card to destroy face up spells or traps, chain 1st effect to banish a spiral token which will replace itself due to Pacifis
  • Banish monsters or tokens equipped with spell cards to clear up space for backrow
    • equip spells can be re-equipped with phantasm spiral power from graveyard
  • wait for opponent to destroy Pacifis before activating in order to be able to re-activate from the graveyard
Pacifis the Phantasm City
  • "Boss" Field Spell
  • Generates Phantasm Spiral Tokens on opponent's effect activation (2k att, 2k Def, Level 8 Water Wyrm)
    • generates tokens whenever you don't have one (even if you tribute it for another effect or it gets destroyed)
  • Searches Phantasm Spiral cards Once Per Turn on normal monster normal or special summon
  • Protect at all Costs
Best Combos:
  • Pacifis + Sea Stealth: once per turn free protect all face up flood gates while having recurring monsters which can destroy any monster which doesn't have spell/ trap protection
  • Emptiness + Macro Cosmos: no special summons and cards on your field are banished so emptiness doesn't destroy itself.
Extra deck isn't very important. Just fodder for Extravagence. Only cards that matter are Blue eyes Ultimate Dragon For fists of the unrivaled Tenyi, Stardust Dragon for Starlight Road and LANphorhynchus if you need to get rid of a kaiju for a vanilla monster. *Missing extra Deck card is Evolzar Dolkka

deck_excerpt: Melffy with a bit of synchro spice!
deck_description: I wanted to build Melffys, and I took a list from an amazing youtuber by the name of Thrifty Duelist. His deck was insanely cheap, and I was happy to see a list to use that is extremely easy to build in cardboard, but I did imagine the $12 price tag was really strong, but the deck could be stronger. So using a comment under the video, I implemented Naturia Beast, Fabled Unicore, Rescue Cat, and a Hop Ear Squadron Engine. With that, I thought that with how many tuners and synchro monsters that were already in the deck, I decided that leaning more into it with being able to Synchro on your opponent's turn and disrupt their turn using Crystron Quandax, Desert Locusts, and a choice between Psy-Framelord Omega or Draco Berserker of the Tenyi. With this, you still get all the interruption of the Melffys, with the pops from Kalantosa, and potentially some bounces and negates using Melffy Time and Melffy of the Forests. Not only that, when your board can get clogged with spare monsters, you can pull out the Plasma and lock down your opponent, and send them packing.     Even with all this, the deck increased in price so much compared to the starting canvas i was provided, but I believe it's still entirely budget, gives people a fun deck, and stays cute, making it a great entry into Yu-Gi-Oh! for many.

I made this deck for the Xyz Event after I built a pretty cool Utopia deck and was promptly shown the way.  The deck is based off of the Exodia deck that Dzeef has on his channel and an old reversal quiz ftk that I can't find anymore. The goal is to get down to 2000 or 1000 lp through chicken game, map, and popperup, then reversal quiz with set shurikens.  I've tested a few builds and this seems to be the most consistent but you still brick occasionally.  You lose to an ash vs a bad hand, veiler, imperm, and going second vs most decks. You deserve this. Thankfully these aren't really problems in the Xyz Event since everyone is playing self-ftk and numeron otk.  Please don't take this to ranked, just play the Exodia version.

deck_excerpt: Colors of Chaos: 50-card deck features powerful and versatile Fusion Monsters, focusing on accumulating monsters of different attributes while cutting
deck_description:
The Colors of Chaos is a 50-card deck that’s full of monsters featuring different effects and attributes, all looking to take opponents down in creative ways. The Extra Deck is comprised mostly of fusion monsters, taking advantage of all different ways to fuse these monsters of Chaos.

The boss-monster, Guardian Chimera, can be fused with three monsters that have different attributes so it becomes very versatile for any problem you may face. When summoned with a Spell or effect, Chimera has a special ability that lets you destroy your opponents’ cards while simultaneously allowing you to draw a card(s). Be careful, however, because Necro Fusion cannot be used to Fusion Summon this great beast; the only valid way is for monsters to be released from the hand or the field. Plus, while Polymerization is in the GY, Chimera cannot be targeted with card effects by your opponent.

The other fusions also feature easy ways to be summoned with the Small Engines available in this deck. Blue-Eyes Tyrant Dragon can be summoned by either fusing BEWD with another dragon, or can be Special Summoned by tributing a BEWD equipped with a Fusion monster. While it is more difficult to fusion summon, its special ability makes it unaffected by Trap Cards or effects and once it battles, during the end of the Damage Step, the player can target 1 Trap in their graveyard and Set it to the field.

Centaur Mina (1 LIGHT Warrior + 1 Beast) can quickly negate an opponent’s Trap Card during the player’s turn and Set it right back down. Mina can be really easily fusion summoned, especially using her Noble Knight’s effects, and can also Special Summon Level 2 or lower monsters during the Main Phase allowing for Synchro Summoning and more.

Dinomorphia Stealthbergia (which requires 2 different Dinomorphia monsters) utilities the Dinomorphia LP effects to the player’s advantage, allowing for the player to activate Trap Cards or Dinomorphia effects without paying LP. As long as your LP is 2000 or less, you are free to activate all the Trap Cards that halve LP. Plus, if your opponent activates a monster effect, Stealthbergia can inflict damage equal to that monster’s Original Attack. When this fusion dino-machine is destroyed, it brings back one of your Dinomorphia monsters from the GY. This deck provides many ways to Fusion Summon but lacks the endurance for longer encounters so players must be wise about using Dinomorphia cards and effects because of the LP-draining constraints.
FUSION AND WIN!!!!

deck_excerpt: Absolutely destroy your opponent using tokens.
deck_description: The goal is to get Black Garden, Field Barrier, and 3 Token Stampedes on the field. It's a really basic strategy. deck_excerpt: Synchro, Ghostrick, Brave, Rose Dragons (Oh My!)
deck_description:
This list is heavily inspired by the logic used for the Ghostrick Deck used in MBT's TMT, with the idea that the Ghostricks have like 3 really good cards that can be splashed into a suite of level 3 spam monsters. Conveniently, the Rose Dragons are ALSO level 3. So, this deck does most of what Kitchen Synch ( or Rose Brave Tenyi Swordsoul) does, but can also make use of Utopic Draco Future.   I will briefly explain some of the combo lines that are possible:
  1. 2 level 3 extenders: very simple but also quite low ceiling, get the 2 level 3 bodies on field, make Ghostrick Alucard, overlay again for Angel of mischief, detach Alucard to search for shot, use shot to revive Alucard, rank up the Alucard into another mischief, make Draco Future.
  2. Brave Engine plus Red Rose Dragon: Full combo, do brave stuff to get gryphon and the token online, summon either the Rose dragon, make Baronne with Red Rose and Gryphon, use Red Rose to summon Roxrose, search for Basal Rose Shoot, make Halq with rox and the brave token, special Deskbot 001, make Auroradon with Halq and 001, get tokens and 001 back, make Cupid Pitch with token and 001, increase Pitch level, make Borreload with cupid and token. Now you have a choice with what to search off Cupid Pitch, either search Psychic Tracker and use that plus the basal rose shoot to go through combo line 1, or search hop eared squadron so you can make satellite warrior on your opponent's turn.
  3. Interrrupted line/ brick: pray they dont have nib, and try to make halq at all costs, then continue like in line 2
This list is still very work in progress, i am currently considering Ghostrick Shot at 1, but it's a hard garnet, and obviously the handtrap lineup can change to suit your preferences. I hope you give this deck a spin, and let me know if you have any questions :D

deck_excerpt: Dinos doing Dino things even without Links or Synchroes
deck_description: Dinosaurs are well-known for breaking open boards, and in the rather fun (for good and bad reasons) xyz festival event, they definitely still excel even if they have some trouble with utilizing Double Evolution Pill properly sometimes.  Due to the change in the format and lacking enough URs, I had to go with what worked, but given Dinos often use the main deck instead, they can still do their thing, but they need to have a bigger emphasis on going 2nd as a result, thus requiring the use of more board breaker cards.  The deck definitely thrives in a format where negation isn't as rampant, but still watch out for Ash Blossom and Artifact Lancea (if it somehow crops up) since those on the Misc in the GY can shut this deck down hard.

deck_excerpt: Not your turn, not your beatstick!
deck_description:
Steps to use this deck:
  1. Go first and play a bunch of monsters to Xyz Summon Primathmech Alembertian with 4 materials.
  2. Activate its effect to add Trap Trick to your hand, then Set Trap Trick.
  3. Link Summon Link Disciple, then use it along with Primathmech Alembertian (this is VERY IMPORTANT) to link into I:P Masquerena and pass.
  4. Activate Trap Trick to search for Limit Code and activate it.
  5. Special Summon a powerful Code Talker monster from your Extra Deck and activate I:P Masquerena's effect to immediately link it away into a powerful beatstick, perhaps Accesscode Talker, Firewall Dragon Darkfluid, or others.
  6. Kill.

deck_excerpt: A cute OTK deck that loves to clear boards and negates stuff hehe
deck_description: This is a fun deck to play, it has many outs to a lot of decks that are played in master duel.  The main play is usually 2nd turn otk.  A lot of plays are just about drawing cards and summoning Rainbow Neos to clear the board and Vortex and Naturia Beast to negate. Thats about it, everything else is just so you can run over any card. You can also go into Apollousa to negate monster effects since this deck is not running the staple hand traps. Utopia, Accesscode Talker,.. Feral Imps is there to extend the play either for drawing or Pendulum summon, you can put Jigabyte instead of Nefarious it can expand your board a little for that otk. Raigeki is there for I don't know what u can put what ever you want keep in mind that Rainbow Neos is the last monster to enter the field since you cannot summon after using Neos Fusion. If u feel like pendulum Rising is bad bcs there are not enough targets in the deck just put another duelist alliance. Thats all. This is my first deck list that I ever made myself and I got to plat with it in Master Duel in a week. Maybe that's not good enough but i returned to this game now after 6 years so i had a lot of catching up to do! Have fun!

deck_excerpt: Konami just put Nadir Servant to 2 or and Super Poly to 3 in MD already, they literally have no reason to stay at 1 and 2 respectively.
deck_description: Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with a Ritual deck this time, but isn't the cringe ass Drytrons and can actually be a fun one to pilot, Nekroz Dogmatika. As per usual, cards on the side will be those that are nice to have but are not necessarily mandatory, if you have them. Before anything else, I wanna preface this first with a bit of story and a disclaimer that this isn't exactly a budget list due to for some strange reason, all Duelist Alliance archetypes are expensive as shit to build in MD, especially Shaddolls. I actually once loved Rituals, I like building Ritual good stuff decks like Impcantation Relinquished or Impcantation Nekroz, even though most of them looks incredibly similar to each other... until the day Drytrons came. At that time, I was already focused on building more Fusion strategies but it pissed me off how they abused the hell out of both Herald of Ultimateness and Herald of Perfection, and it's just as bad as the days of the formats where those two are being turbo'd or arguably even worse. But that scar eventually got slowly remedied by Konami's decision on suddenly making Dogmatika a Ritual focused archetype (which to an extent makes sense considering all the Extra Deck hate), and I've received an epiphany. Impcantation Dogmatika. (Here's the list for those that are interested, although it's a bit outdated: https://ygoprodeck.com/impcantation-dogmatika/) The list: • x3 Zaborg the Mega Monarch - Upon successfully Tribute summoning with a Dogmatika monster, destroy itself (or another Level 8 or higher LIGHT monster on the field that can be destroyed) to send 8+ cards from your opponent's Extra Deck and all three copies of your Herald of the Arc Light, up to two copies of your Elder Entity N'tss, El Shaddoll Apkallone, Toadally Awesome, Titaniklad the Ash Dragon, and Psy-Framelord Omega to the GY for a triple Ritual monster/spell search, a pop or two with N'tss, a Shaddoll Schism and Dogmatika monster search or Special Summon during the End Phase. • Nekroz Kaleidoscope, Nekroz Mirror, and Nekroz Cycle - Some people only really play 2 Kaleidoscope and 1 of each Mirror and Cycle since they're searchable and they also play Pot of Prosperity, but I'd much rather open with those cards than searching for them, plus more copies means more grind. • x1 Nekroz of Areadbhair - For some reason, he's legal in MD. You're almost never gonna be using his discard effect. He's here because he's a monster negate that banishes, and Tributes for cost, which could lead to some neat interactions with Cyber Angels and Hieratics (the latter which I may or may not test any time soon, probably). • x1 El Shaddoll Anoyatyllis - A funny card against Drytron match ups alongside El Shaddoll Winda. • x3 Soul Exchange - Stormforth for Ritual decks, though it sucks that it targets. Anything else in the Extra Deck are just either Kaleidoscope or Dogmatika Punishment fodders. If you're worried about running out of resources, that's why both Toadally Awesome and Psy-Framelord Omega is mandatory. As soon as we get access to the newer Dogmatika support, White Relic of Dogmatika and Dogmatikamacabre in particular, this deck and Impcantation decks in general will get even stronger. So yeah, that's pretty much it for the list.

deck_excerpt: Pure Adamancipators, thank goodness for 3 Block
deck_description: Your best board would be to end in as many negates/counters you have as possible. Stuff like Apollousa is normal, but Desert Locusts is there since I used it as a flex slot really (Had a funny duel where I dumped a Crystal Wing on the poor guy, but not necessary) . Absolutely needs Gallant Granite, Halqifibrax, and Block Dragon for the best boards, although I have seen people use Prankkids to great effect, even if I don't know how they function in this deck.  Another choice is Fossils for a more aggressive build, like Skull King for monster snatching and Skullgios to end matches. In the end, Adamancipators are pretty flexible, so ratios for different cards could/will change depending on the meta and decks.  Other choices:  Koa'Ki Meiru Supplier to add Guardian to your hand, and Guardian to negate hand traps and stuff Doki Doki to let you special monsters from deck I:P to go into Unicorn/Agramax/Underworld Goddess on your opponent's turn, if they have a boss monster immune to destruction or immune to effects respectively Hand traps (Maxx C, Called by the Grave, Imperm) are interchangeable, but I've found Effect Veiler mostly redundant in this deck, since you have a ton of monster negates as it were.  Would recommend Ash Blossom/Dark Ruler/Forbidden Droplet if you want to swap them out.  Note: Crystal Clear Wing isn't out in MD yet, but it's definitely something I'd splash into the deck regardless, since it's easy to make with your level 6 synchros + level 4 tuner or Desert Locusts + a level 4 like Supplier.

deck_excerpt: use the law of the normal to clear your opponent's board before going into some crazy link plays.
deck_description: use the law of the normal to clear your opponent's board before going into some crazy link plays.

Any 1 of Magileine/Petingcessoeur/Anjelly in the opening hand are enough to begin the combo. Deck aims to OTK turn 2 or 4 at worst, aim to go second always because you need the extra card and can't afford to give your opponent the chance to break your board. Should be good enough to reach plat V assuming you don't get too unlucky with matchups breaking your win streak. Dies a gruesome death against Heralds and Utopias, most other things can give you a rough game if you don't get a good opening hand with handtraps or misplay them. Not the perfect Madolche deck by any means and quite expensive as far as Master Duel decks go.  Combo is usually:  Magileine normal -> search for Petingcess -> Special Petingcess -> Special Anjelly -> Tribute Anjelly to special Hootcake -> Special Messengelato -> add Chateau/Salon or Ticket depending to game state. -> XYZ summon Tiaramisu and Link summon Fresh Sistart -> Use Tiaramisu's effect to send back the cards used to link summon Fresh Sistart to shuffle back to the deck the opponent's most dangerous cards. Once you get the three spells up on the field you can recycle and search a lot and the deck snowballs from there. Sometimes you don't even need to link summon Fresh Sistart as you might get enough Madolches on the field to OTK.

deck_excerpt: the best utopia deck, deal wit it  Heres some duels: https://youtu.be/CZQhHkeL7ok
Time to summon a ton of convenient Level 9 monsters for a snake or a weird dragon that won't let your opponent play.
deck_description: Ah, Generaiders, probably the 2nd best deck to be able to spew True King of All Calamities out on field as soon as possible. Generaiders are a suite of boss battle-themed monsters that have quick effects that tribute other Generaider cards to activate them, apart from Mardel. These monsters (except for Loptr) are all Level 9 and can be summoned onto the field with ease with the most important card in the deck, Generaider Boss Stage.  We'll go over Generaider Boss Stage as its own card first. This card allows you to special summon any Generaider from your deck if your opponent draws a card, even in their draw phase, which means its Ash Blossom this effect or suffer. And when a Generaider is special summoned on our opponent's turn, Boss Stage fills our board up with Generaider Tokens, which are basically fodder for your powerful Generaider effects.  Now we'll go over the Generaiders, the monsters of the hour. We are running most of them, because Frodi and Dovelgus are about as good as a dumpster fire. We're running 3 Loptr, 3 Mardel, 1 Naglfar, 1 Nidhogg, 1 Hela, 1 Utgarda, and 2 Harr. Loptr is the only Level 4 Generaider, so he's one of the most important cards to get our metaphorical train rolling. He can tribute a Generaider (including himself) to special summon a Level 9 Generaider from our deck, which is most usually going to be Mardel. Mardel is the first of our Generaiders, and the only one that has an effect when its summoned instead of a quick effect. Mardel allows you to add a Generaider card (not just monster) from your deck to your hand, so this is a consistent way to get our Boss Stage out on field by our opponent's turn. The next is Naglfar, which prevents the destruction of a card(s) by tributing a Generaider monster to be able to keep the card(s) alive. A funny thing can happen with this is if the Generaider Tokens live until the end phase, you can tribute Naglfar to keep the tokens on your board until your next turn, which can come up like once every 50 games. Next is Nidhogg, who tributes a Generaider to negate the special summon of a monster and destroy it, which is by far extremely useful compared to Naglfar. Its a piece of negation without too steep of a cost. Hela can tribute a Generaider to special summon a unique Generaider from your GY, so we can use her to gain access to a Generaider we need in the GY. Utgarda can tribute 2 Generaiders to banish any card on the field. While it is a steeper cost, its non-destruction banish can prove useful against many other decks. And we have Harr, which by far is the most useful main deck Generaider, tributes 2 Generaiders to negate the activation of a card and destroy it. Omni negates are fun :) Harr also has another effect where if your opponent adds a card from their deck to their hand when its not draw phase, you can force your opponent to send a monster from their hand or field to the GY. He can get really oppressive with our funny pet snake when we explain the Extra Deck.  Next our Generaider Spell/Traps. While there's not too many, they are powerful enough to unbrick a hand, bait an Ash Blossom, or straight up gain advantage. 3 Boss Quest, 1 Boss Fight, and 1 Boss Room. Boss Quest reveals a Generaider monster to be able to add 2 Generaider Spell/Traps from your deck to your hand, and you put the Generaider you revealed on the bottom of the deck. You usually don't want to draw or open Generaiders except for Loptr, so you can put the monster back in your deck to special summon it on your opponent's turn. Boss Fight is literally Metaverse for the archetype and your opponent draws a card after, so you can use Harr's effect, Droll and Lock Bird your opponent, etc. Boss Room allows you to discard a card when your opponent responds to a Generaider's active effect to literally change the effect of that card to "both players draw one card" which is nuts. You get to draw a card, Harr can do Harr things, Droll and Lock bird can screw up everything. Good shit.  Now onto our generic cards. The good 'ol staples. We got 1 Droll and Lock Bird, 3 Maxx "C", 1 Ash Blossom, 3 Lonefire Blossom, Raigeki, Harpie's Feather Duster, 1 Lightning Storm, Terraforming, Called by the Grave, 3 World Legacy Monstrosity, 1 Solemn Judgement, and 2 Fists of the Unrivaled Tenyi. Yeah yeah, I know Lonefire Blossom, Monstrosity, and Fists aren't generic, but they're REALLY good in this deck. Lonefire Blossom can tribute itself to summon a Plant monster from your deck... Mardel is a Plant monster. Its basically Loptr, but for exclusively Mardel. World Legacy Monstrosity can special summon a Level 9 monster from your hand, or you can select a Level 9 monster you control to special summon 2 more from your deck with different attributes and types. Hmm... its almost like most of the Generaiders are Level 9. That's handy! Fists of the Unrivaled Tenyi is a Counter Trap that's active only while you control a non-effect monster. The Generaider Tokens are non-effect monsters. Its basically Harr but without the tribute, spell speed 4, and not once per turn. I shouldn't have to explain what the rest of the cards do...  Now the Extra Deck! These cards are a rather good reason to play this deck. We got the 'ol reliable duo of Utopic Future and Utopic Draco Future, True King of All Calamities, 2 Number 92's, Infinitrack Earth Slicer, Jormungandr, Generaider Boss of Eternity, 3 Nine-Lives Cat, Sacred Tree Beast, The Spider Duo of Pain Gainer and Seven Sins, and Zeus. UF and UDF takes 2 level 9 Xyz monsters that don't have "Number" in their name and makes a big 'ol boy that'll negate monster effects and permanently take control of them. Cool! I shouldn't have to explain Calamities. Best Rank 9 Xyz in the game that'll make anyone on the opposite side of the board from him sad. Number 92: Heart-Earth dragon wipes your opponent's board of whatever monsters they summoned during the End Phase. Its amazing in the situations it can come up in, nearly unmatched in what it can do. Earth Slicer takes opponent's monsters destroyed by battle with it and can use them as material for its effect, which is to pop cards on the field equal to the materials used. Its other effect doesn't matter in this deck. Jormungandr is the pet snake I mentioned earlier. It can use 1 material for both players to draw cards, then both players must give one card in their possession from their field or hand to Jormungandr as material. This combined with Harr is nuts. You basically get to rip 2 cards from your opponent for free basically. Very cool! It can get oppressive if your opponent has exhausted all their resources and has almost nothing to work with. Nine-Lives Cat can reborn a Level 9 monster from any GY and it gives it protection. Its very handy, just like Number 92! Sacred Tree Beast is a weird version of Invoked Mechaba. You activate a card or effect during your turn and it can attach a card of the same type to it as material. And when your opponent activates a card, you give up a material of the same card type to negate it. Unfortunately, both of these effects are once per turn and can only be used on their respective turns. The Spiders; Number 84 and Number 77 are not that useful, but more useful than most. Number 84 gain DEF equal to the amount of Xyz ranks on your field x200, and can detach a material to destroy all opponent's monsters with DEF less than its own. Oh, and I guess it deals 600 damage for each Spell/Trap card they activate. Number 77 can detach 2 material to banish all special summoned monsters your opponent controls and you get to take one of those monsters as material for Number 77. It can also detach a material to prevent its destruction. Honestly, if I had 2 more Jorms, I'd use them over these spiders. This answers the age-old debate that nobody asked: "Which is cooler? Snakes or spiders?" And finally, Zeus. I shouldn't have to explain it, but I will: attack with an Xyz monster, get a non-destruction board wipe with a 3000 ATK/DEF body.  And that's it for Generaiders! It may be behind VW when it comes to making Calamities, but its such a cool archetype with a unique style of play and it'll be Number 1 in my heart. Its got a ton of plays and starters, but when it bricks... yeesh... Its pretty nuts in the Xyz Festival Event, and can take over the game over a decent bit of the decks, like Numeron who wants to go 2nd and Timelords who do the same, except worse and without an OTK. Also I'd probably run 3 Droll and Lock Bird for Drytrons. Hope y'all learned something about how to play Funny Level 9 Monster Deck :)

You can use Astral Kuriboh to give your XYZ Number monster protection from destruction. With Astral Kuriboh and Galaxy Queen's Light you can even summon Number 92, so you could Special Summon it from GY if it gets destroyed (negated on the field and then destroyed)  Just summon Number 97 and use it to summon 92 or 38. deck_excerpt: S-Force partnered with some Chaos bosses and your friendly neighbourhood DPE.
deck_description: Not the most competitive version of the deck around. However when it gets going, it can be a real force.  The main idea of the deck is to generally just use the S-Force to build up a level of control and then use the engines available to round out the game.  If you start with Rappa, it's best to just do the usual Gravitino, Platina board with chase set and hopefully and imperm or an ash in hand. Usually, this is enough to disrupt your opponent turn 1.  If you end up with two s force on board with no chase set, you're best off linking into Verte. You then have the option of going into a chaos monster (Daedalus with a field spell up is ideal as it gives you a level of protection) and then making DPE.  Small World is brilliant in this deck too, as it's extremely easy to get whatever S-Force monster you need, due to the LIGHT/DARK attributes and the variety of types.  As for the Chaos monsters themselves, it would probably be more ideal to use the Dragon chaos monsters. I only run BLS and CED because I have them in CR lmao.  I don't run TCBOO as Rappa and DPE clash far too much for my liking. With all the backrow hate in the format, it tends to get wiped pretty quickly too. However, it is an option should you think it is needed.  Let me know what you think of my absolutely jank profile lol

deck_excerpt: Melodious Artifact Stun deck, focused on beatdown after locking your opponent
deck_description:
This deck focuses on creating a strong field with the Aria + Elegy combo and preventing the opponent's game with Scyther and Aurora Paragon. We need to access Scyther and Aurora as soon as possible with condmened witch and Artifact sanctum. For Aurora Paragon we still have Dimension Guardian that will make it perennial on the field, and can be used to make Scyther or any other melodious indestructible. The steps to prioritize are:
  1.  Link Summon Composer
  2.  Create the lock Aria + elegy or Aria + some more necessary melodious
  3.  Normal Sumom Aurora Paragon or Condemend witch
  4.  Put some comeback (back to ther front) or dimension guardian to protect Aurora paragon, chaos has been normal summom
  5.  If you used witch, only use its effect after the opponent's first normal sumom.
43 cards is a bit inconsistent, but ~25% of that are cards that bring in others from within the deck, counterbalanced by the amount.

deck_excerpt: Deck strategy focused on:  Field control Invocation lock Monster destruction Monster banish
deck_description:
Deck strategy focused on:
  • Field control
  • Invocation lock
  • Monster effects negated
  • Monster banish
  COMBOS Invocation lock Cards you need : Zombie world + Rivalry Of Warlords The purpose of this combo is control the enemy invocations, for example:
  • You have Zombie World activated
  • Opponent summon Aleister the Invoker (Spellcaster) but its changed as zombie monster by the Zombie World effect
  • Opponent use Invocation to fusion summon Invoked Mechaba
  • You chain Rivalry of Warlords, then he cant summon the fusion because just zombies can be summoned, the lock Its complete !
  1. Use Zombie World at your first card, if you dont have any Zombie World in hand search it with Necroworld Banshee, Terraforming or Metaverse (This last 2 cards are not included on my recipe)
  2. Set Rivalry Of Warlords  and use it on the opponent turn whe he summon any monster
    Limit invocation lock Cards you need : Summon limit This combo its very simple, in your turn try to summon a lot of monsters if you can summon the boss monsters of the deck should be better for example:
  • Doomking balerdroch, Eldlich The Golden Lord and Vampire Sucker was summoned
  • At your Main Phase 2 set Summon Limit
  • Activate Summon Limit, now your opponent just have 2 invocations
If you use Summon Limit to control the opponent invocations but you cant summon one or more monsters you can send to graveyard Summon Limit with Eldlich the Golden Lord effect, if eldlich isnt in graveyard be patient     Banish opponent monsters + The attack of one  opponent monster become zero Cards you need : Doomking Balerdroch + Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi Every time a zombie monster uses an effect doomking can negate that effect or banish a monster in field or graveyard You can use the Doomking banish effect with any zombie monster effect activated, including the zombie monsters of the opponent
  1. Summon Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi (You can link summon using 3 monsters but one of those must be a link 2 like Vampire sucker or Avendread Savior)
  2. If Doomking Balerdroch is in graveyard, summon him with mezuki (In your turn) or wait to the opponent Standby Phase to summon him by his own effect
  3. When Doomking is summoned chain Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi effect to change the attack of the opponent monster to 0 and then chain the Doomking effect to banish one monster in field/graveyard of your opponent
    Monster effects negated Cards you need : Skill Drain + Eldlich the Golden Lord Other simple combo, just set Skill Drain and use it on the opponent turn if you can play without your own effects its ok but if you need monster  effects use the Eldlich the Golden Lord effect to send Skill Drain to graveyard     COMBOS Bloqueo de invocaciones Cartas necesarias : Zombie world + Rivalry Of Warlords El propósito de este combo es controlar las invocaciones enemigas, por ejemplo:
  • Tienes Zombie World activado
  • El oponente invoca Aleister the Invoker (Spellcaster) pero es cambiado a zombie por el efecto de Zombie World
  • El oponente usa Invocation para invocar por fusión a Invoked Mechaba(Spellcaster)
  • Encadenas Rivalry of Warlords, entonces el oponente no puede invocar a Invoked Mechaba porque ahora sólo puede invocar monstruos zombies, el bloqueo está completo!
  1. Usa Zombie world en tu turno, si no tienes una en mano búscala con Necroworld Banshee, Terraforming or Metaverse (Estás últimas 2 cartas no están en la lista pero puedes incluirlas)
  2. Coloca Rivalry Of Warlords  y usala en el turno del oponente cuando invoque cualquier monsttruo
    Limitar la cantidad de invocaciones Cartas necesarias : Summon limit Este es el combo más sencillo, en tu turno invoca la mayor cantidad de monstruos posibles y si puedes dejar a los boss monsters es mejor, por ejemplo:
  • Doomking balerdroch, Eldlich The Golden Lord y Vampire Sucker fueron invocados
  • En tu Main Phase 2 coloca Summon Limit
  • Activa Summon Limit, ahora tu oponente sólo podrá invocar dos monstruos en su turno
Si usaste Summon Limit para controlar las invocaciones del oponente pero nopudiste invocar uno o más monstruos puedes enviar al cementerio Summon Limit con el efecto de  Eldlich the Golden Lord así no te afectará a ti el límite de invocaciones, si no tienes a eldlich en cementerio se paciente     Remueve monstruos oponentes + Convierte en cero el ataque de un monstruo oponente Cartas necesarias : Doomking Balerdroch + Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi Cada vez que un monstruo zombie active un efecto puedes encadenar el efecto de Doomking para negar ese efecto o para remover un monstruo del campo o cementerio El efecto de Doomking puede ser activado incluso si el monstruo activado es un zombie del oponente
  1. Invoca a Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi (Puedes hacer link summon usando 3 monstruos pero uno de ellos forzosamente debe ser un link 2 por ejemplo Vampire sucker o Avendread Savior)
  2. Si Doomking Balerdroch está en cementerio: invocalo usando el efecto de mezuki (En tu turno) o espera la Standby Phase para invocarlo por su propio efecto
  3. Cuando Doomking es invocado encadena el efecto de  Yuki-Onna, the Absolute Zero Mayakashi para cambiar el ataque de un monstruo oponente a 0 y enseguida encadena el efecto de  Doomking para remover una carta del campo o cementerio oponente
    Efectos de mosntruo negados Cartas necesarias : Skill Drain + Eldlich the Golden Lord Otro combo simple, sólo necesitas colocar Skill Drain y usarla en turno oponente si puedes jugar sin tus efectos de monstruos consérvala en campo pero si no usa el efecto de  Eldlich the Golden Lord para mandar Skill Drain al cementerio ahora podrás usar tus monstruos

deck_excerpt: An initial build of my Invoked Dogmatika Shaddoll Icejades, which is still technically a work in progress.
deck_description: Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with a deck that isn't really new, to be honest. I just figured that I might want to test it out since I just discovered that Icejades aren't really bad so without further intros I present to you, Invoked Dogmatika Shaddoll Icejades. That's a mouthful, but I wanna preface this first with the thoughts that #1. This will not be my final iteration of the deck, I most definitely will be testing more of this in the future since I can see a lot of potential from it but I cannot promise that this will be a top tier deck or at least not immediately, #2. This does run 5-6 Field Spells on it, but they are not necessarily bricks, and #3. My side deck was initially designed with Crossout Designator in mind, until I remembered that Bridge of Salvation was a card (or at least going to be a card, which I will discuss in a bit) and this is a deck that plays two different Field Spells that can both be starters. Addressing the weirdos in the deck list first: • x1 Icejade Kosmochlor - This card is the reason why I decided to play Icejades. She's a 3000 DEF body on board that's a delayed Skill Drain, and we all know what that card does, provided that their archetypal Field Spell Icejade Cenote Enion Cradle is on the field. • x1 Icejade Creation Kingfisher - I really wanna play more of this card because it's so good with Kosmochlor, but Foolish Burial Goods and Bridge of Salvation is just too good for the consistency of this deck. I might cut Icejade Tinola for an extra copy for insurance but sacrificing utility. • x1 Bridge of Salvation and x1 Rainbow Dragon, the Zenith Crystal Beast - This is where the funny comes, with Bridge of Salvation in particular, because it searches Magical Meltdown, which I am actually considering on cutting down to only 2 copies because of it, and Rainbow Dragon, the Zenith Crystal Beast acting as a bridge and a LIGHT target or discard fodder for Invoked Mechaba. • x1 Icejade Erosion - This card is one of your interruptions on the Icejade portion of the deck. Sure, it does target, but it's still a negate for a face-up CARD, not just monsters or spell/trap, and it's searchable. Some initial testing thoughts: 1. Predaplant Verte Anaconda and the Dogmatika package conflicts against each other, unsurprisingly, but it does leave you vulnerable to being hand trapped, that's why I decided to cut the Predaplant Verte Anaconda, Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, and its main deck package for either more defensive cards like Infinite Impermanence or some ratio of hand traps and Crossout Designator or more Icejade cards for utility. I'm still on the fence with playing Nadir Servant and Titaniklad the Ash Dragon, but it's always an option but then again, this is still a pretty early phase for me testing this deck. 2. I'm surprised that Icejade Cradle is not a once per turn, which actually makes the deck pretty fast at digging through the deck for combo pieces, alongside Foolish Burial Goods. I definitely am not playing less than three of both cards and Metalfoes Fusion since it's not really a hard brick because it can be used as a discard fodder for Invoked Mechaba against spells. 3. It technically is a smokescreen strategy, because you can go through your initial Icejade stuff without worrying about getting xeno locked in any way, shape, or form and without spending your Normal Summon. 4. The deck can easily swarm, but the extra deck is exceptionally tight. The only reason I play Invoked Cocytus over an extra copy of Invoked Mechaba is that it actually can be a combo piece to maximize the use of your Icejade Cenote Enion Cradle, and is also a 2900 DEF wall that can't be targeted or destroyed by your opponent's card effects which can be further boosted by Aleister the Invoker. 5. As per usual for an Invoked variant, this deck can play extremely well under There Can Be Only One, which is always a bonus. Closing thoughts: I am still undecided on whether to make a new list for the succeeding updates or just straight up do the updates on this list and make the changes here directly, we'll see, but I'll definitely be testing more of this deck since I just love Fusion summoning in general. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.
Brave Virtual World competitive deck
