deck_excerpt: Presentation of my Marincess deck in Master Duel.
deck_description: Marincess is an Anime Cyberse archetype of Water attribute monsters. It follows the same characteristics of other anime Cyberse decks like Code Talker, Salamangreat and @Ignister of being able to make a decent game volume to establish an end board and have very satisfactory recursion in the grind game. Like Salamangreat, deck interactions are based on activating Traps, but so far Archetype has no way to add them to the hand on turn 1 (there is an OCG support that solves this problem but it will take a long time to get to the TCG and a lot even longer to get to the Master Duel). One thing I want to say about the Archetype card design is that in Anime the same character that played as Marincess was the one who played as Trickstar so several of the Archetype cards have burn effects, especially Traps have this feature that 90% of Traps are unusable in the deck because they are not actually interaction. The deck's gameplay is based just like @Ignister on making Towers unaffected by card effects. For this you need to have the Battle Ocean field activated and have made your Archetype LINK-3 or LINK-4 in the Extra Monster Zone using Crystal Heart as material. What is most impressive about archetype is the card economy while setting up your field, for example if you made 1 combo card among your 11 ways to achieve this you will in the end have your Boss Monster with high ATK thanks to the FIeld Spell plus a Follow Up in hand guaranteed. That said below I will show you all the possible combos to do with the deck and discuss archetype cards and generic Cyberse support and Water generic support possible to use in the deck. ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 1: Sea Horse/Cynet Mining (1 Card Combo) NS Sea Horse and LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff Add Sea Horse to Hand (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell LINK-2 Splash Mage and eff Reborn Sea Horse (You want to have Splash Mage in the GY for your following turn) ***LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 to Coral Anemone Coral Anemone eff Reborn Splash Mage (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) LINK-4 Bubble Reef (summon in Right Extra Monster Zone) Coral Anemone cl1 Field Spell cl2 Equip 1 LINK-1 from GY and Add Sea Horse to Hand Gamestate: Bubble Reef + Field + (Equip LINK-1) /in Hand: Sea Horse Opponent's StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish Other LINK-1 in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Your Next Turn: StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish LINK-2 Coral Anemone in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Bubble Reef eff discard Sea Horse SS Coral Anemone ***LINK-3 Transcode Talker Coral Anemone eff add Sea Horse to Hand Transcode Talker eff Reborn Anemone Sea Horse eff SS from Hand ***LINK-4 Accesscode Talker and Anemone eff Reborn Splash Mage Splash Mage eff Reborn Sea Horse LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff Add Sea Horse (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) NS Sea Horse and LINK-3 Marbled Rock (Co-Linked with Blue Slug and Anemone) Marbled Rock eff Return Bubble Reef to Extra Deck LINK-4 Bubble Reef using Blue Slug and Marbled Rock Gamestate: Accesscode + Bubble Reef + Anemone + Field /in Hand: 2 DRAWS /in GY: Sea Horse ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 2: Sea Horse/Cynet Mining (Blind Second Version) NS Sea Horse and LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff Add Sea Horse to Hand (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell LINK-2 Splash Mage and eff Reborn Sea Horse ***LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 to Coral Anemone Coral Anemone eff Reborn Splash Mage (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) ***LINK-4 Wonder Heart Coral Anemone cl1 Field Spell cl2 Equip 3 LINK Monsters in GY and Add Sea Horse to Hand Previously Gamestate: Wonder Heart + Field + (Equip 3 Link Monsters) /in Hand: Sea Horse After the first attack you Special Coral Anemone from s/t zone and attack another opponent's Monster LINK-4 Bubble Reef (summon in Right Extra Monster Zone) Field eff Equip 1 LINK-1 from GY Gamestate: Bubble Reef + Field + (Equip LINK-1) /in Hand: Sea Horse Opponent's StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish Other LINK-1 in GY = DRAW 1 CARD ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 3: Blue Tang 1 Card Combo NS Blue Tang and eff Send Sea Horse to GY LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff cl1 target Sea Horse Blue Tang cl2 Excavate top 3 cards (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) add 1 MARINCESS CARD (need lucky) and Add Sea Horse to Hand Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell ***LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 Coral Anemone eff Reborn Sea Horse (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) LINK-3 Marbled Rock and Coral Anemone cl1 and Field cl2 eff Equip 3 Link Monsters (You save your resources to OTK next turn when opting for Marbled Rock) Add Blue Tang to Hand and Marbled Rock eff Add Sea Horse to Hand Gamestate: Marbled Rock + Field + (Equip 3 Link Monsters) /in Hand: Blue Tang + Sea Horse + (possible 1 Marincess Card) ///////////////Combo 3. 1: If Opponent's Destroys Marbled Rock: Coral Anemone eff Return Sea Angel to Extra Deck (Help with plays involving Marincess Mandarin) Next Turn: OTK Version ***NS Blue Tang and eff Send Marincess Mandarin LINK-1 Blue Slug (NOT use the effect because you don't need to be lock in Water) ***cl1 Blue Tang Excavate top 3 cards cl2 Field Spell Equip LINK-1 and Anemone Sea Horse SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell(if you use 2 Field) Mandarin eff SS from GY(banish it when leaves the field) Splash Mage = Transcode Talker = Reborn Marbled Rock Marbled Rock eff Add Blue Tang to Hand (Follow Up) ***LINK-4 Bubble Reef(summon in Right Extra Monster Zone) Anemone eff cl1 Add Sea Horse to Hand Field cl2 (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) Bubble Reef eff discard Sea Horse SS Mandarin to Field ***LINK-4 Accesscode(have 2 pops) and for each pop Bubble Reef eff activates to GAIN600ATK until END TURN - MANDATORY EFFECT. Gamestate: Bubble Reef(58k atk) + Accesscode(53k atk) + Field + (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) /in Hand: Blue Tang /in GY: Sea Horse + Mandarin ///////////////Combo 3. 2: If Marbled Rock Survives: Next Turn: OTK Version Sea Horse eff SS from Hand LINK-4 Bubble Reef(summon in Right Extra Monster Zone) Coral Anemone eff cl1 target Sea Horse and Field eff cl2 (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) NS Blue Tang and eff Send Marincess Mandarin Mandarin eff SS from GY(banish it when leaves the field) LINK-2 Splash Mage and Bubble Reef (MANDATORY EFFECT cl1 GAIN600ATK) and Blue Tang eff cl2 Excavate top 3 cards Bubble Reef eff discard Sea Horse SS Mandarin Previously Gamestate: Bubble Reef(52k atk) + Splash Mage + Mandarin + Field + (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) /in GY: Blue Tang + Sea Horse LINK-3 Transcode Talker = Reborn Marbled Rock Marbled Rock eff Add Blue Tang to Hand (Follow Up) LINK-4 Accesscode Talker(have 2 pops and Bubble Reef synergy - MANDATORY EFFECT) Gamestate: Bubble Reef(64k atk) + Marbled Rock + Accesscode Talker(53k atk) + Field + (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) /in Hand: Blue Tang /in GY: Sea Horse + Mandarin ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 4: Blue Tang + Mandarin = Blue Tang + Sea Horse = Blue Tang + WATER Extender NS Blue Tang and eff Send Sea Horse to GY LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff cl1 target Sea Horse Blue Tang cl2 Excavate top 3 cards (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) add 1 MARINCESS CARD (need lucky) and Add Sea Horse to Hand Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell ***SS Marincess Mandarin to Zone Sea Angel points to and Activate Field LINK-2 Crystal Heart and LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 to Coral Anemone (Coral Anemone is Unaffected by Card Effects) Coral Anemone eff Reborn Crystal Heart (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) LINK-4 Bubble Reef (summon in Right Extra Monster Zone) (Bubble Reef is Unaffected by Card Effects) Coral Anemone cl1 Add Blue Tang to Hand and Field cl2 eff Equip 2 Link Monsters from GY Gamestate: Bubble Reef(Unaffected by Card Effects) + Field + (Equip 1 LINK-1 and Crystal Heart) /in Hand: Blue Tang + (possible 1 Marincess Card) Opponent's StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish Other LINK-1 in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Your Next Turn: StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish LINK-2 Coral Anemone in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Bubble Reef eff discard Sea Horse SS Coral Anemone ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 4.1: Pascalus + Blue Tang/Sea Horse NS Marincess Pascalus (Right Monster Zone) and eff SS Blue Tang and Blue Tang eff Send Sea Horse to GY LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff cl1 target Sea Horse Blue Tang cl2 Excavate top 3 cards (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell and Activate Field LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 to Coral Anemone Coral Anemone eff Reborn Blue Tang (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) ***LINK-2 Crystal Heart and LINK-4 Bubble Reef (summon in Right Extra Monster Zone)(Bubble Reef is Unaffected by Card Effects) Coral Anemone cl1 Add Blue Tang to Hand and Field cl2 eff Equip 2 Link Monsters from GY Gamestate: Bubble Reef(Unaffected by Card Effects) + Field + (Equip 1 LINK-1 and Crystal Heart) /in Hand: Blue Tang + (possible 1 Marincess Card) Opponent's StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish Other LINK-1 in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Your Next Turn: StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish LINK-2 Coral Anemone in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Bubble Reef eff discard (Marincess monster) SS Coral Anemone ***At this point you can do the Bahamut Shark + Toadally Awesome combo ***In this case your end board would be Marbled Rock + Toadally Awesome (Summon in Left Monster Zone) as in Combo 3 ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 5: Pascalus + Water Extender NS Marincess Pascalus and SS Water Extender(Silent Sea Nettle per example) LINK-1 Blue Slug and LINK-2 Coral Anemone Anemone eff Reborn Pascalus and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add FIELD (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) Activate Field and LINK-3 Marbled Rock and Field eff Equip 3 Link Monsters Marbled Rock eff Add Pascalus to Hand Gamestate: Marbled Rock + Field + (Equip 2 LINK-1 and Anemone) /in Hand: Pascalus ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 6: One For One Activate One For One send 1 Monster from Hand to GY SS Marincess Mandarin from Deck LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff Add Mandarin to Hand (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) NS Mandarin and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add Field Spell and Activate Field Mandarin eff SS to zone Sea Angel points to(Banish it when leaves the field) LINK-2 Crystal Heart in Extra Monster Zone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 LINK-2 Coral Anemone and Field eff Equip 2 LINK-1 (Coral Anemone is Unaffected by Card Effects) Coral Anemone eff Reborn Crystal Heart (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) LINK-4 Bubble Reef (summon in Right Extra Monster Zone)(Bubble Reef is Unaffected by Card Effects) Coral Anemone cl1 Return Crystal Heart to Extra Deck and Field cl2 eff Equip 1 Link Monsters from GY Gamestate: Bubble Reef(Unaffected by Card Effects) + Field + (Equip 1 LINK-1) /in GY: Coral Anemone + LINK-1 /Banished: Mandarin Opponent's StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish Other LINK-1 in GY = DRAW 1 CARD Your Next Turn: StandbyPhase Bubble Reef eff banish LINK-2 Coral Anemone in GY = DRAW 1 CARD ***Bubble Reef eff discard (Marincess monster) SS Coral Anemone ///////////////////////////////////////// Combo 7: Blue Tang/Sea Horse + Swap Frog (Not Recommended) NS Blue Tang and eff Send Sea Horse to GY LINK-1 Blue Slug and eff cl1 target Sea Horse Blue Tang cl2 Excavate top 3 cards (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) add 1 MARINCESS CARD (need lucky) and Add Sea Horse to Hand ***SS Swap Frog by discarding Sea Horse and eff Send Ronintoadin to GY LINK-2 Coral Anemone and eff SS Swap Frog and eff Send Swap Frog to GY (LOCK Special of WATER Monsters) Swap Frog eff Bounce itself to Hand as cost Reborn Ronintoadin by banishing Swap Frog LINK-2 Crystal Heart and Anemone eff Add Sea Horse to Hand Sea Horse eff SS from Hand and LINK-1 Sea Angel and eff Add FIELD and Activate FIELD LINK-3 Marbled Rock and Field eff Equip 3 Link Monsters Marbled Rock eff Add Blue Tang to Hand SS Swap Frog by discarding Blue Tang and eff Send Swap Frog to GY Reborn Ronintoadin by Banishing Swap Frog RANK-2 Toadally Awesome (Summon in Left Monster Zone) Gamestate: Marbled Rock + Toadally Awesome + Field + (Equip 3 Link Monsters) /in Hand: (possible 1 Marincess Card) Opponent's Turn: Toadally Awesome eff detach 1 material SS Dupe Frog from Deck(don't need to tribute Toadally Awesome to activate its effect) /////////////////////////////////////////Explanation of some Archetype cards and generic support. Marincess Cards Marincess Pascalus for being level 4 helps to make Bahamut Shark. And its effect on the GY of adding the Spells/Traps back to the hand is very good for recycling the Marincess Wave which is the best interaction the deck has at its disposal. The problem with Pascalus is that it doesn't converse very well with the Extender Water you might be using on the deck and many builds even cut it out of the Main Deck. Marincess Sea Horse is the best card in the deck because it is Starter and Extender and makes 1 Card Combo LINK-4 Bubble Reef. The other main deck cards only fit as a Starter or Extender. Marincess Blue Tang can be said to be the best card in the Archetype also because even though it is not an Extender it makes the deck spin and you access the Extenders to continue playing being the best consistency card in the deck. Marincess Mandarine is easily Recycle from Banished Zone with LINK-4 Bubble Reef so you just need 1 copy. Battle Ocean can force an opponent's negate if their main monster has an ATK that can be overcome by equipping GY's Marincess to your Coral Anemone for example. A great interaction bait to get your play through. Marincess Wave isn't hard once per turn, so it's definitely an improved Infinite Impermanence and the best interaction the deck has available. In addition to being able to be activated directly from the hand, it protects all monsters you control with the best possible effect: "Unaffected by Opponent's Card Effects" for the rest of the turn. LINK-1 Sea Angel is the best way to make Marincess Mandarin come alive and being able to enter the field as extend by the Link arrow is excellent. LINK-2 Crystal Heart in the Extra Monster Zone helps you to play around Nibiru, the Primal Being a bit during your combos as it is Unnafected by MONSTER Effects, always remember this detail when using Crystal Heart as material from Coral Anemone or Boss Monster Bubble Reef he also gains protection. Monsters made in Extra Monster Zone using Crystal Heart as material are only "Unaffected by Opponent's CARD Effects" while you control Field Spell Battle Ocean so if you take AA-Zeus for example you lose your Boss Monster along with the rest of your field. If your unsuspecting opponent destroys the Coral Anemone in the Spell&Trap Zone and you have the Marincess Wave in the GY you can add it back to your hand to have one more interaction with the opponent this turn. LINK-4 Wonder Heart eff in Battle Phase its not Hard Once Per Turn, so you can always protect from destruction in Battle Phase while you have an Equip Marincess Monster. Don't forget its excellent Floating effect of Special Summoning a Marincess LINK-3 or less. LINK-4 Bubble Reef has a mandatory effect of gaining 600ATK for each banished monster until end of turn, so against decks like Tri-Brigade and Invoked that need to banish monsters to play it becomes a Boss Monster Unaffected by Card Effects with absurd ATK being practically impossible to take it out of the field in the Battle Phase ensuring it survives for the next turn. If you use a reduced Marincess engine in the Extra Deck like for example 2 Blue Slug and 1 Sea Angel you can do some of the different combos in the details than equipping the Field Spell back on the field because for example if you make the End Board of Marbled Rock you have two Deck Resource Recovery, 1 with Marbled Rock itself and another with Coral Anemone so you can choose to equip only two Link monsters in Marbled Rock and leave one in the gy like Sea Angel for example and return it to the Extra Deck with the Anemone eff and leave it to add a Marincess to Hand with the Marbled Rock to have an excellent grind game with the correct Resource Management. //////////////////////////////////////// Generic Cyberse Support Armored Bitron is a generic support of Cyberse that works in this deck like a Lonefire Blossom, and locks you into Cyberse for the rest of the turn. With him you always bring the Sea Horse from the Deck and with that you make 1 Card Combo normally. Plus it has an interesting GY effect on the deck that you shouldn't forget about. Shootingcode Talker is a great Generic Cyberse Monster option for Marincess' deck because it gives a 2 draw potential which is all the deck wants because keeping cards advantage over the opponent makes the gamestate controlled by the amount of tech cards that fits in the deck and the ability to recycle resources every turn making it one of the best grind games among Cyberse decks. Remember that Splash Mage locks you into Special Summoning Cyberse Monsters. If you use Transcode Talker eff Reborn Crytal Heart you can make Accesscode Talker(in the Extra Monster Zone) Unaffected by Opponent Card Effects. Transcode Talker and Accesscode Talker is the best generic extra deck package out there for Cyberse decks. It's very hard to see a Cyberse deck that doesn't use them. In this deck you should be careful with the restrictions of some engine cards that don't allow you to use these two monsters but overall it's an excellent addition to the deck, but you don't necessarily need them to play Marincess. Another generic support of Cyberse that can be used in this deck is Tri-gate Wyzard instead of Transcode Talker and its main effect for this deck is not the negation eff, but the effect of inflicting Double Battle Damage and the effect of banishing a card that the opponent controls . In general, the Cyberse Archetypes Extra Deck is very restricted and has little room to make changes, this Extra Deck from the decklist below can be assembled a little differently from the one presented, leaving at your discretion the changes you want to make such as placing the Transcode Talker and Accesscode Talker. /////////////////////////////////////// Budget Options Paleozoic Traps: Dinomischus, Canadia, Olenoides, Marrella to send the Marincess Wave to the GY. Dinomischus is one of the best trap cards in the game = can handle with monsters and floodgates and also have sinergy with Wave to return to field from GY as an extender. If you use a high amount of Paleozoic Traps it is also very good to use Paleozoic Opabinia. The deck doesn't have a lot of removal cards so traps like Compulsory Evacuation are very good options to overcome this deficiency. Other interesting cards: Gozen Match or Rivalry of Warlords, Mistar Boy, Aria the Water Charmer which is interesting because it can use monsters that are not Water or Cyberse as material, for example Nibiru, the Primal Being. /////////////////////////////////////// Disregard the Side Deck, they are just card options that can be used in the deck or that I'm not specifically using in my Marincess extra deck in Master Duel but that are very common and I can even say what standards to be used in Marincess decklists . Just understand that this profile deck is more to explain theory than the standard way to play Marincess, so various changes can be made to your liking. Bahamut Shark and Toadally Awesome is as well as the Trancode Talker and Accesscode Talker package indispensable for Water and Cyberse monster decks and needs no introduction. But if I'm talking so well about the Code Talker package and the Bahamut Shark package then why don't I use it in the deck? Simply because this is the purest possible version of Marincess, but for sure most decklists use at least half of the generic extra deck cards mentioned above. Frog Engine: Swap Frog + Ronintoadin + Dupe Frog - helps play around Nibiru, the Primal Being. And there's a good combo involving Swap Frog and Blue Tang. Swap Frog is not hard once per turn so whenever you give him Reborn he activates the effect as in the case of using the Coral Anemone eff. Frog's engine was used a lot in the launch of the deck where few useful cards existed and you needed something that generated pressure on the field. Over time, excellent supports came along to make the deck what it is today, and there are even more supports that were released in the OCG last year to improve Marincess' Archetype a bit more. That said, what happened was that with the arrival of new supports, the use of the Frog Engine became unnecessary and playing in the purest possible version is what gives Marincess more results. Silent Sea Nettle is the best Extender Water option to use on deck. Trap Trick is another good tech card option in the deck. Foolish Burial to send specially the effs of Pascalus and Sea Angel in the GY. One For One makes Mandarin 1 Combo card, so it's a good card to try out in your deck. Like any deck that makes use of equipment during its playthroughs, Forbidden Droplet becomes a very good card to use in that deck because its activation cost is almost free when sending Equip Monsters to the GY. /////////////////////////////////////// Final deck details: Floodgate monsters that stop Marincess' turn completely: Shenshen and El Shaddoll Winda. Of course El Shaddoll Winda stop every archetype in the game but several decks manage to have at least 1 out for the card within the engine itself and Marincess doesn't have that out at all. Shenshen as well as any Macro Cosmos-type effects are enough for you not to be able to play Marincess either. That's why it's quite common to use anti-Combo Decks cards in Marincess like Forbidden Droplet and Dark Ruler No More to deal with these cards. Blind Second cards like Lightning Storm and Evenly Matched hurt you a lot by losing a lot of engine cards in the process despite keeping the Boss Monster and having Follow Ups in hand. That's why I don't think it's wrong to use 3 Solemn Judgment from Main Deck. The deck lacks reliance against Hand Traps especially against Nibiru, the Primal Being and Psy-Framegear Gamma and also suffers a lot if the Normal Summon is disrupted or taken out of the field or flipped face-down. Interaction between Bahamut Shark + Marincess Wave + Marbled Rock: after activating Wave all your monsters become unaffected by card effects so the only way for your opponent to take Bahamut Shark out of the field is through the Battle Phase but Marbled Rock protects him from harm destroyed by battle and that way you guarantee you can activate Bahamut Shark on your next turn and bring another Toadally Awsome onto the field. Great Bubble Reef is an excellent card, don't underestimate the power of having a version of Code Talker Heatsoul in the deck's own engine. Decks that don't draw bother me because seeing new cards is always the difference between having chances in the game or not. That's why cards like Pot of Desires and Sekka's Light are absurd to the point of being limited. I think the Tecnoplay you should be looking to improve the most when playing Marincess is game 3 of the deck on how to play as efficiently as possible because this is a Salamangreat-style Cyberse deck that beats the opponent in fatigue with you remaking your entire field with low resources every turn keeping pressure on the opponent throughout the duel.

deck_excerpt: Melffy control deck that relies on a kalantosa, joyous melffy loop.
deck_description: The idea of this deck is to try to get the kalantosas out ASAP. Use them to go into joyus melffy to begin the loop of popping 3 cards. Melffy of The Forest can be used to search out Melffy Hide and Seek, and Melffy Time so you can set up for a huge impact for game. Hide and Seek is crucial to have on the field as it protects your beast monsters from getting wiped by things like raigeki or other effects once per turn; as well as allowing you to recycle beast monsters by returning 3 different ones from the grave to the deck. This includes rescue cat. There are 2 main win conditions to this deck. Constant control of the opponent's field by repeatedly bouncing joyus melffy to special summon 3 kalantosas and popping up to 3 cards on the field while you whittle them down; or controlling the field while stacking Melffy Mommy's material count, activating Melffy Time, detaching everything, and swinging for game.

deck_excerpt: My Platinum I Invoked Dogmatika Shaddoll list. Less of a build guide but more of a deck profile addressing staple choices and my thought processes whe
deck_description: Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, and I'm back with my favorite deck, fresh from just reaching P1 because I've sped run the ladder today because I've got nothing else better to do. As the title suggests, presenting Invoked Dogmatika Shaddolls, again. As per usual, the side deck are cards that I have either "sided out" (aka interchangeable cards per game solely depending on the feel of my draws and nothing else because there's no way to accurately predict which deck you're gonna be up against in a BO1 format) throughout my run in the ladder and I'll explain my "siding patterns" (kinda) because MD format sucks for not having a BO3 but I digress. The list: So first of all, I think I want to go with addressing the "side deck" alongside the main. • x3 Lightning Storm - This slot shares with Evenly Matched and Infinite Impermanence, one being a great board wipe and the other, a great hand trap. I haven't really encountered any trap heavy decks as of late, or even Eldlich in particular, so I decided to use Lightning Storm for the mean time. Seems like everyone got bored of playing that deck finally, thank God. • x2 Super Polymerization & x1 Foolish Burial - These cards' slots share with Crossout Designator, a more defensive tool in contrast to the more aggressive combination of the two. The thing with Invoked Dogmatika Shaddolls is that, you can play the deck however you want, be it going 1st or going 2nd, but you'd have to adjust both your side and extra deck for it. For going 1st builds, I'd personally pick Crossout Designator but Super Polymerization is also a good follow up card. It's just that I've noticed that the higher I climb the ladder, the more ubiquitous back row removal cards become. People aren't even using their Lightning Storm against monsters even if they're in face-up Attack Position, also I've had a couple of mirrors with this deck and Crossout can mess up your opponent on such scenarios. • x3 There Can Be Only One - This card, I'm a bit scared to use it honestly, because of mainly the previously stated presence of heavy back row removal and it's best going first, which is unlikely to be guaranteed for you because everyone's mostly gonna go first if they had the chance to choose, but it's strong nonetheless especially against mono-type strategies that like to swarm, like Phantom Knights, Lyrilusc Tri-Brigade, or Drytrons even. • x3 Maxx "C", Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring, & Droll & Lock Bird - Yes, I know I said I'm never gonna be using Maxx "C" because of how much I hate this card but I pulled one, okay? Might as well craft two more... but anyway. These three are a bit weird. Often there are times where Maxx "C" just feels like a brick, because it's an EARTH Attributed monster, same thing goes to Ash and Droll. Ash is generally useful, but that also means it's targeted by pretty much everyone, no doubt. Droll sometimes takes people by surprise, but is pretty useless against decks that play in the graveyard anyway. 2/2/2 ratio of each seems fine, but I'd probably only do that when I'm going first and I have Crossout. • x1 Starving Venom Fusion Dragon - This slot is the most contentious one of all because this slot is a flex spot for your generic Super Polymerization target. I've had more trouble deciding which card to place here than interchanging hand traps and staples in the main. This also used to be Predaplant Dragostapelia, but when I changed it, there aren't any Prank-Kids or Thunder Dragon players anywhere to be seen. Mudragon of the Swamp also took this slot before but I've seen less Lyrilusc Tri-Brigades after I mained it. Even El Shaddoll Shekhinaga used to be here, but then I can't make use of her outside Adamancipator, Traptrix, or EARTH Machines match ups. So this one's really up to you. Other options include World Chalice Guardragon Almarduke, Diplexer Chimera, and Earth Golem @Ignister, all of which are great more specifically against Code Talkers. • Psy-Framelord Omega - Absolutely mandatory. I'd rather have a 16th Extra Deck slot than give up this one, especially because this is the Extra Deck killer variant which plays Dogmatika Maximus. I also am not playing the Salamangreat Almiraj + Secure Gardna package and Elder Entity N'tss because it takes way too much space for an Extra Deck that is already tight enough and costs 1 extra Special Summon as opposed to just using Artemis, the Magistus Moon Maiden, which can also be made by Normal Summoning either Effect Veiler or any of your Level 4 or lower DARK Attributed Shaddoll monsters since they're all Spellcasters. • I actually am debating on cutting down Terraforming for Harpie's Feather Duster (as soon as I'm able to craft or pull a copy) or even a second copy of Resh Shaddoll Incarnation for insurance. I also am not playing Forbidden Droplet because Fusion decks already costs a lot of resources to make plays, although it's playable, so long as you know what to do about it properly. I also have cut down Invoked Raidjin and Invoked Caliga, because those two are much better on just Invoked Shaddolls list, where you could play more Shaddoll cards. What I have also noticed when climbing the ladder that might be helpful for you, if you're still reading this, is that people tend to be more complacent and slack off when the season's about to end even back then in S1 but especially now that Platinum 1 players can't get demoted anymore, so if you want to catch the "easier" wins, try grinding a week or two before the season ends like I did, because people will always instantly try hard with their meta decks either as soon as the new season starts or during the last week of the season where everyone suddenly tries to catch up for the rankings. This pattern has always been present throughout all games that have seasonal rankings, so yeah. Just something for you to keep in mind to consider. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can, especially regarding the current text font because I chose this one in particular because it's not as straining to the eyes, unlike the others so, yeah.

deck_excerpt: Great Dragonmaid deck with a lot of XYZ spam.
deck_description:
The Dragonmaid Deck focuses on summoning multiple low-level monsters which summon their counterparts from the graveyard or hand at the start of any Battle Phase (yours or your opponent's). If you are new to the Dragonmaid deck here are some tips for each card:
  • All low level Dragonmaid monsters summon at the start of the Battle Phase their "counterparts" from the hand or graveyard, returning that card to the hand (level 3 monsters summon level 8 monsters, level 2 monsters summon level 7 monsters; Chamber Dragonmaid can summon any high level Dragonmaid, including fusion monsters). You can use their effects during your opponent's turn if that turn you returned them to your hand to summon high-level Dragonmaid, summoning them from your hand by the effect of the previously summoned cards.
Kitchen Dragonmaid: When summoned, you can add the card you need to your hand and then discard a high level Dragonmaid monster which you can summon during the Battle Phase and return to your hand at the end of the same phase to pay the cost again next turn. Parlor Dragonmaid: When summoned, you can either: send a - high level Dragonmaid monster which you can summon during the Battle Phase and return to your hand at the end of the same phase. - low level Dragonmaid monster and then summon it by the effect of Nurse Dragonmaid / Dragonmaid Hospitality. Nurse Dragonmaid: When summoned, revive a low level Dragonmaid monster from the graveyard, you can activate the effect of the revived monster. Laundry Dragonmaid: When summoned, send the top three cards of your deck to the graveyard, it's not very advisable if you don't consider that you have good luck, you may end up sending key cards to the graveyard, if you send Dragonmaid cards you can recover them to your hand with the help of the Dragonmaid Welcome effect. Chamber Dragonmaid: When summoned, add a Spell/Trap Dragonmaid to your hand from the deck.
  • All high level Dragonmaid monsters have activatable effects from the hand, which you can use without fear since you can recover the card by summoning it with the effects of the low level monsters, and then at the end of the Battle Phase, you can return it to hand or perform an XYZ summon during your Main Phase 2.
Dragonmaid Lorpar: Negate the effect of a monster in the opponent's field this turn, it is not a quick effect so you must use it during your Main Phase. Dragonmaid Tinkhec: Increases by 2000 the attack of a Dragonmaid monster, it's a quick effect so you can use it if necessary during the Battle Phase; but you can use it during your Main Phase on a card that you are not going to return to the hand (a fusion Dragonmaid monster) and then summon it from the graveyard for the effect of a low level Dragonmaid monster. Dragonmaid Ernus: Special summon a Dragonmaid monster of level 4 or lower from the graveyard which will activate its effect and then summon this card at the beginning of the Battle Phase, as it's a quick effect you can use it during your opponent's turn. Dragonmaid Nudyarl: returns a monster in any graveyard to the deck, it can cause disruption in the opponent's strategy by returning key cards that he/she can use or recover, it's not a quick effect sadly.
  • Fusion Monsters
House Dragonmaid: Its first effect allows you to summon during any Standby Phase from your hand or Graveyard a Dragonmaid monster one level lower/higher than another you control, you must target another Dragonmaid monster to activate this effect, so if you only control this card you won't be able to use it; its second effect destroys an opponent's monster every time a dragon returns to the hand, making this a key card to clear the opponent's field. Dragonmaid Sheou: Its first effect is an upgraded version of House Dragonmaid's effect, it summons a Level 9 or lower Dragonmaid monster from the hand or Graveyard without any requirements; Its second effect negates any activated opponent's effects, destroys the activated card, then returns this card to the Extra Deck and Summons House Dragonmaid from the Extra Deck.
  • Spell Cards
Dragonmaid Welcome: Slightly increases the atk of your monsters depending on the amount of Dragonmaid you control, the important thing is its second effect, which allows you to recover Dragonmaid cards from the graveyard but you must control two Dragonmaid monsters to use this effect. Dragonmaid Changeover: To summon by fusion, you can retrieve it from the graveyard by returning a Dragonmaid monster you control to your hand. Dragonmaid Hospitality: Usually used to summon a low level monster and send its high level counterpart to the graveyard, so you can summon it in the Battle Phase. Dragonmaid Send-Off:  To activate effects in the opponent's turn, it can also save you a turn if you do not have a good hand, since the summoned card is not destroyed by battle or effects until the end of the next turn.
  • Trap Cards
Dragonmaid Downtime: Return an opponent's backrow card at the end of his turn so that he/she cannot activate it on your turn, use it on your turn to add any Dragonmaid card you may need. Dragonmaid Tidying: Disrupt your opponent's field/graveyard, then you can use its effect from the graveyard to summon a low level monster, trigger its effect, summon a high level monster at the beginning of the Battle Phase and summon it again from the hand if necessary, that way you don't have to return the summoned monster to the hand; you can only use one effect per turn.
  • Other Cards
Performapal Odd-Eyes Dissolver: Use it as a Continuous Spell Card to Fusion Summon once per turn.

Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring: Hand trap.

Maxx "C": Free draw every time the opponent special summons. Return of the Dragon Lords: Revive a level 7 or 8 dragon from the graveyard, protect a dragon monster from destruction by banishing it. Guardragon Cataclysm: Destruction of the opponent's field. Number 29: Mannequin Cat: Special Summon a monster from your hand, Graveyard, or Deck with the same Type or Attribute as one Special Summoned by your opponent, it's a great XYZ card for multi-Attribute Decks.

Number 76: Harmonizer Gradielle: Gains the attributes of all monsters it has as XYZ material and is not destroyed by battle or by effect of a monster with the same attribute as this card, once per turn you can select an opponent's monster in the Graveyard and set it to this card as a XYZ material, which makes it great for opponent's graveyard disruption.

Número 97 Draglubión: The reason why the deck has monsters XYZ Dragon Numbers.

Divine Arsenal AA-ZEUS - Sky Thunder & True King of All Calamities: Powerful generic XYZ cards.

deck_excerpt: Bored of attacking for game? What if you could draw 10 cards in one turn and banish all the cards in your opponent's deck instead? Let's look at the n
deck_description:
The new Mysterune deck has some interesting strategies. Where attacking your opponent to reduce their life points to 0 is made out of the question by almost all of the cards in the new and upcoming archetype, the interesting field spell that allows you to draw 3 multiple times in one turn (and not just on your turn) still seems more than alluring.    The deck focuses around banishing the top card(s) of your opponent's deck by activating a series of quick-play spell cards with considerably powerful effects including searching any Mysterune card; negating an opponent's monster's effects; discarding a random card from the opponent's hand when they add a card from their deck to their hand, and destroying a monster or spell/trap. Additionally, these effects all include an effect to banish a number of cards (ranging from 1-4) from the top of the opponent's deck. Each of these quick-play spell cards also has the option to instead summon a Mysterune monster from the extra deck to the extra monster zone. More on this later. To facilitate the continued activation of these quick-play spell cards, their field spell, Spring of the Mysterune, allows you to activate Mysterune quick-play spell cards from your hand during your opponent's turn. Furthermore, the field spell has a soft once-per-turn effect if you activate a Mysterune quick-play spell card that targets 3 Mysterune quick-play spell cards, puts them on the bottom of the deck, then lets you draw 3 cards. This is most useful during your opponent's turn as you can draw more quick-play spell cards to use in that same turn and disrupt your opponent even further.    As for the monsters you can summon, Geri, Fangs of the Mysterune allows you to add any non-quick-play Mysterune spell card from your GY to your hand, which can enable multiple activations of the draw effect of Spring of the Mysterune in one turn. Muninn, Wings of the Mysterune, the other monster you can summon, allows you to search any Mysterune continuous spell card from your deck to your hand by discarding one card – however, there is only one card that meets these conditions. Deceit of the Mysterune, the card in question, will banish a card from the top of an opponent's deck each time any quick-play spell card is activated, even if it doesn't resolve (but not if the activation is negated).    Other engines to facilitate the strategy are the Magicians' Souls engine, which can provide turn-after-turn advantage off of used spell cards such as Spring of the Mysterune after using its draw effect or duplicate copies of quick-play spell cards to send back to the deck for more draws. Magicians' Souls can also be used to summon Linkuriboh for battle protection or Relinquished Anima for monster removal (including your own Linkuriboh to clear the extra monster zone for a Mysterune monster) via equipping as a spell that can then be used with another copy of Magicians' Souls to draw more cards. Lastly, since both Magicians' Souls and Geri, Fangs of the Mysterune are DARK monsters, they can be used to summon Beat Cop from the Underworld, which can then tribute itself to clear the extra monster zone for another Mysterune monster – with the added bonus of protecting another card on the field.  To utilise your normal summon, Royal Magical Library and Planet Pathfinder also bolster the strategy by providing card advantage and consistency respectively all while enabling the summon of rank 4 XYZ monsters such as Daigusto Emeral with Geri, Fangs of the Mysterune to clear the extra monster zone for more summons, recycle used Mysterune monsters, and provide card advantage. Soul Absorption might seem like a gimmicky, 'win more' card, however, in this strategy you rely on drawing cards you can use immediately or during your opponent's turn, which doesn't always happen. If you have a single copy of Soul Absorption on your side of the field, you can gain over 10,000 LP in a single turn, ensuring that if you run out of 'juice' you know that you are very unlikely to run out of LP for at least a couple of turns.    Other tech options include:
  • Instant fusion – This allows you to summon any of your Mysteune monsters to a normal monster zone virtually for free. If you summon Geri, Fangs of the Mysterune, the monster will not be destroyed in the end phase due to its on-field effect.
  • Upstart Goblin – In this deck, consistency is everything. Besides, you don't care about your opponent's LP.
  • One Day of Peace – This kind of ticks 3 boxes in one go: You have more consistency, you are guaranteed another turn (everything in this deck), and your opponent is one card closer to decking out. If you're lucky, you can use this card to trigger Mysterune of Dispel and discard a random card from your opponent's hand.
  • Card Destruction – As mentioned before, sometimes you run out of 'juice' and don't have any more cards you could play. This card can come in handy when you're in a tight spot and of course, it furthers your journey to decking out your opponent.
  This strategy does suffer from consistency issues of course. Even if you are playing 10 copies of Spring of the Mysterune (3x the field spell, 3x Point of the Mysterune, 3x Planet Pathfinder, and 1x Terraforming), you will not always have access to it, in which case you very quickly run out of things you can do and become a sitting duck. The fact that all of the quick-play spell cards in the strategy are hard once-per-turn effects regardless of which effect you choose (their monster summoning effect or their deck banishing effect) means that drawing multiple copies of some cards (or of cards you have already used that turn) could result in dead cards, giving your opponent the opportunity to shut down your strategy.  Once you get your engine going, however, not much can really stop you. You can go a few turns and then run out of things to do, but when you pass to your opponent, they can have two-thirds of their deck banished that often include crucial cards for their strategy, preventing them from breaking your 'board'. Sometimes I forget to check how many cards are left in my opponent's deck and I realise that I've accidentally won while trying to set up for the next turn. You will consistently draw into whatever other tech cards & engines you add to this strategy since the Mysterune quick-play spells cards are always sent to the bottom of the deck; I feel that there are a few ways to take advantage of this – I even tried splashing the Invoked engine in with this deck but I am not good at that strategy so I couldn't make it work.   I hope that Konami releases more support for this new archetype in the future as it has huge potential – maybe a Mysterune quick-play spell version of D.D. Crow. I also hope that you enjoy testing out this deck and experimenting with different styles of play.    This post was made on 25/02/2022, some TCG card names may be outdated.

This version of the Prank-Kids field swarming archetype is heavily focused on getting an established board that includes Battle Butler within the first two turns of the duel. It can often times be susceptible to Ash, Maxx "C", and Nibiru due to its reliance on special summons and extra deck utilization. Therefore, this deck requires a bit of clever maneuvering to play through these hand traps. STRENGTHS The main strength of this deck lies in its ability to chain block and special summon the boss monster during your opponents turn. For this reason, timing on the activation of cards like "Prank-Kids Pandemonium" and "Prank-Kids Plan" is paramount to preventing your opponents combos and protecting your board.
  • Prank-Kids Pandemonium is the signature quick-play spell of the deck that acts as a Polymerization for Prank-Kids cards ONLY. Also limits special summons this turn to cards with "Prank-Kids" in the name. can be activated during opponents turn.
As mentioned before, a pure Prank-Kids deck can be vulnerable to hand traps. Playing around them can be simple though. Here are a few techniques that can be done with the various cards available in this deck.
  • bait ash with Terraforming, Prank-Kids Place
  • limit Maxx "c" by waiting until your opponents turn to summon Butler
  • Instant Fusion Rocket Ride if board is wiped by nibiru giving access to link material for Bow-Bow Bark
  • Called by the Grave for Maxx "c" and Ash
  BASIC STARTER COMBO
  1. summon prank kids lampsies, fansies, or dropsies
  2. link into meow-mu and special summon another of lamp, fan, or drop that you haven't used
  3. link meow-mu and prank-kid 'x' into do do doodle doo and special summon lamp, fan, or drop that you haven't used
  4. activate do do doodle effect to bring pandemonium to hand. Activate second effect to bring back two prank-kids monsters from graveyard and either set pandemonium or activate for butler

deck_name: Eldl~ish (zombie world eldlich stun - master duel platinum rank 1 list)
deck_excerpt: My personal take on zombie world/doomking balerdroch focused eldlich with my own techs and cuts. Master duel banlist. Huge rant. Much wow.  41-9 (82
deck_description: I know the list is nothing revolutionnary, but I feel like the couple changes I made actually have a pretty great impact. While not a pure personal tech as well, the three cards zombie world "engine", even though only three cards, really changes the whole dynamic of the deck. They may be only three cards, but everything in the deck tutors for them, making them omnipresent and actually play in every game - which kinda matters a lot in a single game format. I'dd add in a gameplay section but let's face it, this is still eldlich, deck is pretty self explanatory and easy to pilot. Go hard on zombie world though. Summary -Record / going first vs going second -Why the zombie world focus ? (the crazy impact just three cards have) -Techs and choices (introduction/follow-up to the zombie world focus ft rivalry of warlords + small rant on building for a single game format gozen match - summon limit - foolish burial goods - necroface) -Footnotes / short thoughts on extravagance vs prosperity Record 17-3 record from gold 5 to platinum (85% winrate) 24-6 from platinum 5 to platinum 1 (80% winrate) Overall season 2 record end tally : 41-9 (82% winrate) 1st vs 2nd split : 19-2 going first (90.4% winrate) 22-7 going second (75.8% winrate) I would like to point out that the deck, while aimed at going first and much stronger in that position, deals very well with going second. The list is a pretty conventionnal eldlich list, however with still a couple techs and personal choices which have actually won me some games and I don't think have cost me any (granted, of course, my sample size is pretty small) and centered around zombie world. Why the zombie world focus ? - the crazy impact just three cards have Useless story you really don't need to read I didn't start with a zombie world version of the deck, instead starting with a very usual pure stun list and learning the ins and outs of the archetype (I am a returning player, quit a bit before links arrived, about six years ago and came back with master duel). While I mostly enjoyed the playstyle of the deck, I felt that it was missing something, a spark, a power play on top of the pure floodgate based stun (which is also a bit passive to my taste - do not read bad, just, I usually enjoy playing a bit more actively) and some protection.  As well as some combo feeling I usually enjoy having in my decks on a more personal level. What really caught my eye with the eldlich cards isn't the great consistency, the mighty disruptive power meshed with the ability to play with so many strong floodgates, the oh so annoying resilience of the deck (though, oh my, what flavor, exactly what you should feel from a zombie deck) or even how well every card flows into the others (beautiful sight though, great design), but the fact that they have the ability to support all zombie archetypes. I heavily enjoy archetypes that can serve as generic support to a broad range of decks. I get my fun from building decks. I don't mind playing duels, just, I don't really care about it most of the time beyond seeing my ideas coming to life on the board, which is very fulfilling to me though. After playing just a couple of duels, I was already crafting decks in my head, from the obvious shiranui/mayakashi and more out there ideas such as skull servants (right here) or even just good old awesome zombie monster mash. Honestly, the ideas flowing in my head and trying to figure out how to make it all work made me excited about yugioh again. At that time however, and with the limited ressources master duel allows you to have, I wanted to focus on eldlich cards themselves and wanted to give them a little bit of umpf. And - I know this isn't really inventive or anything - it struck me : this world, IT'S A ZOMBEH WORLD ! I had all these zombie decks ideas all of a sudden, and it just felt like the natural step to take. The zombie world trifecta and how it actually changes the deck I did a little research and found out about balerdroch and banshee, and well, that's just what the deck needed. Balerdroch and banshee add a lot, and I mean a lot of power to the deck. Necroworld banshee alone makes it very, very, very (did I mention very ?) consistent to get zombie world out first turn (well, opponent's draw phase, which to be fair, is kind of the continuation of your first turn), which in turn makes rivalry of warlord that much stronger than it already is. That lock alone has won me a great deal of games. So much so that I will go out of my way to get zombie world out, no matter how minus I go (and, well, this is still eldlich we are talking about, you can never go that minus - just, can't go as plus as I could if I didn't force banshee that badly). I rarely set up multiple eldlich in board + grave, I usually only have the one actually, with two of them sitting patiently in the deck - waiting for the next game after I win the current one. I rarely ever have even just two golden lords in play (counting the grave). I do not try to slow roll it, or set up a potential otk, I go hard on zombie world most of my games, and always if I open rivalry. Again, the generic aspect of the eldlich cards is simply beautiful. Doomking balerdroch. And there he is, the almighty doomking himself, in all of his glory, the one and only balerdroch. Oh my, such a beautiful oppressive beast. Your opponents will scratch their heads over how to deal with the terror. The recurring non targeting banish and negate it grants you just gives you the weapons you needed to reach the next level. It gives you disruption and protection. One of the first cards that come to mind is ariel. Oh my, such a terrifying card, and I mean it. With balerdroch however, you can easily deal with her and protect your eldlich in the grave. And just like his cousin eldlich, he just comes back and back and back, and that's if they can even touch your board in the first place with balerdroch guarding it. He also makes the mirror a joke, which I like a lot. Makes it so much more comfortable. I have encountered eldlichs quite a couple times and have only lost the mirror once, where I went second and they just opened ice dragon's prison and solemn judgment, which both together shut me down (lost the 50/50 snipe as well) and I got otk'd on turn 3. Died to my own golden lord. Sad times. As a bonus he can negate an ash at all times regardless of zombie world. Beautiful. If ash herself doesn't prevent his summon in the first place... Not beautiful. Zombie world is really what ties it all together. Boosts rivalry of warlords to ridiculous levels. Lets balerdroch be the terror that he is supposed to be. And banshee just puts it on the field extra consistently. It also messes a lot with some decks, namely tri-brigade, which need specific types on the field/graveyard. Ending thoughts on the zombie world trio These three cards alone make the deck that much stronger in my opinion, especially in a no side deck best of 1 format - and by sheer virtue of simply existing. They prepare you to face any situation and remove bricks from the deck (more on that in the next section). Their presence alone elevates the deck and brings it a step further. If they are in the deck you easily tutor them with all the eldlich cards and if you draw them, well, great, you drew them and can use them, they don't sit dead in your hand like a coltwing would. They give you power, disruption, protection and resilience, at the cost of no consistency. If anything, it makes the deck more consistent. Techs and choices Useless and obvious rant (does pave the way for the rest and gives it more meaning...) There are two kinds of card I despise and try to avoid or minimize at all cost when building a deck : anything that's an inherent minus and potential bricks. Duh, I know. Don't get me wrong, I loove the halqifibrax auroradon line of play. The sheer combo nature of the line and what you can build from just one card amazes me and makes me feel things inside. I've tried myself to go as far as I could with a one card opening hand, and went with that combo to end up with auroradon and dracossack (aka accesscode talker the following turn), double hot red dragon archfiend abyss, yup, double, true king of all calamities, as you do, and even an d.d. crow in hand for good measures. It was slightly (heavily - read "I had a 16 cards deck which let me mostly control the mills") set up and still took some tries, but man, was it beautiful. However, as grand as the combo is, I hate having to run coltwing. It makes the whole line much stronger, but if you draw it, it just sits dead in your hand and it kinda ruins your play, kills a lot of possibilities. At the same time, you don't want to put more, as it is more potential bricks, you do really want it in the deck however, and, and, and, well, it is just pain and I try to avoid this kind of card as much as possible or mitigate them as well as I can. As for inherently minus card, unless they have specific synergy with your cards or happen to be unfortunately core to what you're trying to play, I don't even ever consider them. Seeing them in a list makes me unreasonably angry. When I see an exodia list with either mallet or reload I close the video or replay on the spot. Building for a single game format Especially in a single game format like we have on master duel, as much as possible, you want to cut bricks or minimize them, even more than usual, and really make your deck have an all around purpose instead of catering to niche situations/countering one specific strategy. Each game being 100% of its value, you cannot, in my humble opinion, afford niche techs (unless they adress your one weakness or something, but then again, is it even niche or a tech then ?). You also do not have the comfort of a side, making each card you actually put in your deck have that much more weight, both in what it brings to the deck but also in its drawbacks. It's all magnified tenfold. Each card's impact is greatly increased. It is actually very interesting how much building for a single game format steers away from catering to a Bo3 format, it has its own separate meta rankings both in playable decks overall and what cards are good or bad. Rivalry of warlords Anyways. One of the things I like a lot about banshee/zombie world, is that it actually minimizes that aspect of one of your best card, as well as trasncending it : rivalry of warlords. Which is what I meant by them making the deck less bricky and more consistent (as well as more powerful). It makes it an all purpose card, great against all decks besides the couple zombie decks you'll encounter, in which case, well, you have balerdroch... (the three card "engine" fixes its own weakness, uncanny.) and just locks most decks with next to no drawback anymore. Gozen match You'll actually notice I have dropped the usual gozen match from the deck. While I wouldn't mind it in a Bo3 format with side decking, for a single match format, well, for all the reasons stated above I have come to despise the card. How many games have I lost, before changing the deck for this current zombie world version, just from drawing two or more copies of gozen match and/or rivalry of warlords and them just not bothering the opponent whatsoever. Gozen match even more so (which is more so a current meta thing than it being inherently worst than rivalry - though it is after zombie world). I have thus come to cut it from the list (even before going with the zombie world trifecta) and my winrate did go a bit up from just that. And after the zombie world shift, winrate really soared (though it was always comfortably positive, you obviously do not need my changes nor my rant to get results from eldlich haha). Summon limit I have instead replaced it with an all purpose summon limit. Again, minimizing potential bricks. Summon limit has actually been great and I am really happy with it. I also love that it applies retroactively (acting as a one time negate sometimes, on top of the floodgate, say on a fusion or ritual spell activated after two monsters have already been summoned) and still counts monsters summoned to your side of the board (kaijus I'm looking at you...). Really screws up a lot of decks. While genuinely happy with it, it would however be the first card I cut to add more solemn judgment when/if I open more. Foolish burial goods I don't know why I haven't seen foolish burial goods in any of the eldlich lists I have checked, including tournaments topping lists. I'm genuinely surprised. It basically lets you tutor any of your traps and play with the ones you have already drawn without making them redundant, as it becomes any of the ones you didn't draw. It has made opening that much easier. I only run one for that same recurring idea, minimizing bricks, as you can only activate one a turn, and also, once you start cycling, you don't need to launch the engine anymore, the momentum of the eldlich cards is too great. It also baits ash blossom very nicely. All around a choice I have never once come to regret. Necroface Now a more out there tech : necroface. While foolish burial goods just makes too much sense to me, necroface is admittedly a bit iffy. I didn't start with necroface at all. More so with the pure stun list, I have had my fair share of games going the long run, and nearly, or some times even actually, running me out of ressource. Some of the games I've had that come to mind were against virtual world or prank-kids, that just kept on coming and coming and getting to the board, no matter how many times I dealt with it. Necroface was the best solution I've found. I have looked into a couple other choices such as magna dragon zirnitron or gizmek makami, however none have the impact necroface can have on a game. While it has sit in my hand standing idly by and taking up a draw for no result some amount of time, when it did, I've usually felt at ease nontheless. A necroface going through really, and I mean really rejuvenates the deck, letting you steamroll the traps some more, and essentially doubling your stamina, letting you for a whole second game... in the very same one. Also recycles golden lord if all three get banished as a bonus or your banished extra deck cards which sometimes comes into play, usually to go for a zeus. It is there primarily to shuffle your spells and traps back however, in order to give you that sometimes needed second wind (which is a proactive play that can always occur and thus not making necroface a straight brick whereas having your golden lord banished, all three at that, is not something you should hardly cater to as it does not commonly happen - don't plan for fringe scenarios if it costs too much consistency or doesn't add anything besides adressing that one scenario). As such, drawing into it isn't such a big deal, even only one or two turns into the game, as you'll already get value from it, and getting that one or two extra conquistadors can really change the face of some games. It also has the potential to screw with some decks, namely virtual world and also the eater of millions/gizmek orochi/gren maju da eiza deck that is actually decently popular and some others. Even besides those decks, on multiple occasions, has my opponent just surrendered on a necroface summon. They jusy couldn't run me out of ressources anymore. I may edit with some of the replays I have to showcase necroface's potential impact if I ever record them. All in all, a bit out there and nothing crucial, also, sadly, no way to tutor for it, but I have been happy with it, and have actually literally won games on its back, where I would have lost otherwise, against those aforementionned decks and a couple times off the extra conquistador(s). 10/10 would recommend. Footnotes The deck is not fully optimized I am working with the cards I actually have A couple of footnotes. The extra deck is comprised of what I actually own on master duel. I also have only the one solemn judgment, I'd add a second one, if not even a third one - cards to cut first should probably be summon limits (one or two), maybe one huaquero (I am a partisan of the triple huaquero however), maybe even an eldlich the golden lord honestly or even one extravagance - mayybe necroface but it really gets closer to any other eldlich list at this point. Try the creepy doll, I promise you won't regret it. Glow-up bloom adds consistency as well, not needed, but definitely improves the deck. I would definitely run it if I had it, especially with an avendread savior. I don't recommend crafting it however, unless you are bathing in crafting points. Where I would probably cut the third eldlich the golden lord in order to add more solemn judgments, I probably wouldn't if you have glow-up bulb. If you have pleiades, please add it to the deck instead of tiras and adreus. Also, add avendread savior if you own any copy. It can replace any of the links really (or those same rank 5s), the least important ones being cerberus and even borrelsword honestly. To be fair though, the extra deck really doesn't matter much, I seldom use it. Which is actually part of the reason why you run extravagance over prosperity in the deck. Extravagance vs prosperity When your extra deck matters and your plays revolve around a couple key cards in said extra deck, extravagance is obviously never a consideration. However, when a deck does not rely on the extra deck, that is where the discussion becomes interesting. Here is my take on it. The way to look at it is very simple really : extragavance generates card advantage where prosperity adds (a lot of) consistency. If you really need to dig for that one card to unlock your plays, prosperity is the choice. If your deck is greatly consistent, extravagance will give you more of an edge. That's really all it is, card advantage vs consistency. In a vacuum I usually like prosperity way better than extravagance. It essentially gives you a scry mulligan, which is just insane to think about even if it is only for one card. However, eldlich is so greatly consistent already that it makes much better use of the card advantage extravagance provides, and really doesn't need the consistency boost you gain with prosperity. Do NOT prioritize building the extra deck if you are low on ressources When I even use the extra deck in the first place, what really matters usually is mostly being able to send conquistador and huaquero to the grave proactively to trigger them during the end phase, be it with linking them away or detaching them for an xyz effect. As such, any generic rank 5 or link 1/2 are fine. If you can actually get a good effect on top, sure, of course, but it is not needed. Small note however, as I went over it earlier, the deck really consistently gets zombie world on the field, as such vampire bram and avendread savior are pretty "key" in that regard as they bypass the rivalry lock, being zombie monsters. Of course, if you have a golden lord in the grave, the issue is non existent in the first place. Thank you for checking my list ! And that's pretty much it. If you have had the strength (the madness ?) to read it all, well, I thank you and hopefully it was even slightly insightful. If you have any questions (or remark/advice), leave them as a comment or even just dm me, I'll try to answer ! Cheers and get your game on

deck_excerpt: Nekroz. Dogmatika. Impcantation. Nuff said.   Meant to compete at a decent level
deck_description: Actual description incoming (maybe) Meant to actually compete decently Couple bullet points I will expand on (non exhaustive) when I have the time/motivation : -Almost cut the nekroz part, but does make the deck flow better, easier to start dumping the extra deck to the grave and get all of the plusses - really important to start going off with dogmatika maximus (also also, areadbhair does add a nice power boost) -Despite being a 60 cards list without a huge mill aspect to it, deck is very consistent -Also, rather resilient against hand traps. Actually have a non impcantation nekroz dogmatika list (with the usual 40 cards / without herald of perfection - which also cuts eva and lee) which is mostly stronger technically (?) but weaker to interruption as a counterpart. Neither list feel less consistent than the other one. The straight nekroz dogmatika does have a better turn 1 usually though (bar too much disruption, again, weaker to interruption than the impcantation list which really lets you bounce back and back). Still debating which list I like best -Despite having baronne de fleur, this list is meant to follow master duel's banlist. Read "one nadir's servant, two benten and two called by the grave" -Herald of perfection is usually summoned the following turn, first turn usually sets up for it while trying to build as disruptive a board as possible. You do get it out first turn sometimes. Technically you mostly always can, but without fairies in hand. First turn sets that up, herald seals the deal the following turn -Lee the world chalice fairy is there as an extra monster you get search with eva, as well as being a recurring fairy monster that you can add back to your hand from the grave, as you barely run any fairies for herald (you tutor for them easily though). She can also get rid of an impcantation monster on the field to let you use the extra deck if need be, if you want to go for a fusion play with verte anaconda/super poly/fallen of albaz or even a level 10 synchro play (which is pretty easy to get out - the deck is a bit weaker on master duel due to the lack of baronne de fleur for that reason) -If you didn't need to use your normal summon, vanity's ruler is rather easy to get out turn 1, sometimes at the cost of a negate though -Still working on some techs/cuts/ratio, so far feels pretty nice though. Able to compete with the likes of swordsoul somewhat convincingly (haven't tested on master duel itself yet, don't have all the cards, list is built with master duel's banlist however - I know technically baronne de fleur isn't out on master duel yet). I have mostly tested against swordsoul tenyi outside of master duel, as I wanted a tough competitor, and really go to war against something a minimum meta. Against them, nearly always win going first which makes me hopeful for the idea. Mostly lose going second though which makes me worries. Have had going second wins however, but you do have to put up some kind of fight. Against weaker (read non meta decks), the list has been wrecking nicely. Overall, happy with how it's turning out so far

deck_excerpt: Skull servants taking over the golden land !
deck_description: Actual description incoming (maybe) Meant as a fun deck (that still gets wins !) Couple bullet points I will expand on (non exhaustive) when I have the time/motivation : -You can go with eldlich as primary and skull servants as secondary I guess, but I choose to do the opposite, I have more fun that way. Most of the time I even purposefully link eldlich away so as not to even have it on board and just beat down with skull servants -Deck is surprinsgly consistent, been having tons of fun with it, really takes full advantage of the eldlich cards offering generic zombie support. I have gotten huge king(s) of the skull servants turn 1-2 nearly every game if not every game (bar too much disruption), really happy with how it turned out and how well it flows. Deck convincingly wins on its second turn at worst -You could make the deck stronger and more catered towards a meta perspective (read "add a small zombie world package" - expanded thoughts in my actual meta zombie world eldlich decklist right here) but then you wouldn't summon the almighy skeletal king as much and you'd lose the spirit of the deck. Also, the skull servants would become more of a gimmick and somewhat getting in the way of some consistency in regard to the "meta plays" only adding a big (BIG) beater (well, giving easier OTKs isn't something to just dismiss though) -Deck OTKs nicely, not too much disruptive power however, despite the eldlich package. Decently resilient however ? -"side deck" are considerations and/or for when the cards come out on master duel
Non SR-UR cards needed, with this deck you can play the solo mode and even win some match on ranked.  Easy to play and cheap.  You can always use better cards if you have it.  have fun!

deck_excerpt: Chain burn featuring paleozoic for draw power, defense, power plays and most importantly MORE CHAINS! ~ paleo fitness, burn all of that fat ! (read "
deck_description: Actual description incoming (maybe) - couple advice/things to keep in mind below the bullet points Meant as a fun deck Couple bullet points I will expand on (non exhaustive) when I have the time/motivation : -I don't even know why this isn't a thing, I actually took some time to think about how to make chain burn as consistent and resilient as possible (tried to make the deck as good as possible as a friend really wanted to play a burn deck), and it dawned on me : paleozoic, it really just makes too much sense to me. The paleo cards add tons of chain links for more burn and easily triggered accumulated fortune, they give draw power themselves through pikaia and opabinia, and it gives protection with their own bodies and dinomischus or canadia, even hallucigenia. And to top all that, they also give power plays with (pretty darn easy) access to zeus and toadally awesome which is no joke ! It is no meta deck of course, but it flows very nicely and feels great to play. I do mostly mean that paleo burn doesn't even show up when you look for burn decks. Again, nothing meta, but boy is it fun ! -You could add another dinomischus or even a third one, but after some testing, I do mostly care about the name (all being different so as not to interfere with chain strike and accumulated fortune), which is why you have one of each, in order to get all of the chain links while not preventing the activation of accumulated fortune and chain strike, which are still the core of the deck. I do still have two of marrella and pikaia, as the former really sets everything up and the draw from the latter is a bit too good. Usually one dinomischus has been more than fine, especially as you can search for it (and activate it from hand after you tutor it !) with opabinia. -Other than that pretty usual list, but the paleozoics really make the deck what it is. Toadally awesome is, of course, awesome. And again, zeus is really easy to get out with the deck, and you don't even have any drawback from it as you can always chain all your spells/traps, because, you know, this is chain burn we are talking about, so you can still set everything and the 3000 atk against an empty board, in a heavy burn deck, is very spooky. Just cleaning the board lalone ets you get many more turns, hopefully enough to burn them down ! Overall, very happy with how it turned out, which is why I am sharing Couple advice/ideas : -As much as possible, avoid setting multiple of waboku and threatening roar, each one being a whole extra turn. Do it however if it lets you summon two paleos from the graveyard, which opens up a zeus/opabinia/toadally awesome. Also, remember that the paleozoic traps as monsters are unffacted by monster effects, making them pretty darn resilient and hard to get rid of when under the protection of waboku or threatening roar, so no stress and easy xyz plays on your turn ! -Don't forget that you cannot burn after card of demise for the rest of the turn and cannot special summon the turn you want to use it (even previously in the turn), be wary ! -Don't forget either that accumulated fortune and chain strike cannot be activated if multiple cards with the same name have been activated earlier in the chain - which is why you run all the paleozoic traps. Basically, if you have both marrellas and/both pikaias in the grave, don't activate both before using accumulated fortune/chain strike. Remember as well that you can activate two chain strikes or two accumulated fortunes in the same chain, as the second one only sees one activated, thus no two same names -Lava golem could be an interesting option, but usually you don't care about the opponent's board, most of the time they can't even attack you and negates aren't too annoying, if anything giving you more chain links. It could get rid of some annoying cards all the while burning though. Still debating - while it does admitedly add power and the potential extra burn to finish the opponent off - whether it is fluff that you don't really need at the cost of consistency Happy burning ! You'll love them hating you ~ paleo fitness, burn all of that fat ! (read "your opponent's thick layer of hp they really don't need" be a good friend, help them get rid of it !)

deck_name: Testudo erat numen (ft barrier statue of the torrent) Special summon lock.dek
deck_excerpt: You don't get to summon ! And you don't get to summon ! And You don't get to summon ! (but I do)
deck_description: Actual description incoming (maybe) Meant as a fun deck (surprisingly strong going first ?) your opponent won't have fun though :) Couple bullet points I will expand on (non exhaustive) when I have the time/motivation : -Honestly ? Surpringly consistent. Really really wants to go first though. Not very resilient if they get their special summons or a raigeki or something. That is, however, if they even get to play in the first place :) -You have pretty powerful board set ups for what the deck is about. Ties of the brethren really makes the deck (and moon mirror shield puts the nail in the coffin), it's all built around that card. Brothers in arms making the enemy cry, but that's fine, we're (nearly) all aqua, we'll thrive with their tears and feed on them :) -Nothing meta of course, very weak to interruption (read ash blossom) and destruction of any kind (besides battle), and way weaker going second. You will make people miserable pretty consistently when going first however, if that's the way you have fun, this deck is pure pain for the opponent :) -You can still special summon so as to make your opponent hate you even more. Dweller (your best friend - cheats the 1800 atk limit letting you attack over everything all the while boosting your board's attack power and offering you protection) and abyssalacia both notably are always available for you to summon no matter which lock you have up. Make them feel pain as you do what they wish they could :) -Don't be afraid to normal summon testudo erat numen (or barrier statue) if that is your only play, always if you have aquarium stage/ties of the brethren/moon mirror shield/mirror force of course, but you should also consider it without any of them. It can still mess the opponent up a little bit and can buy you a whole turn. Let them feel the wrath of the turtle ! :) (still working out some ratios, namely the left arm offerings and the level 4s, should also consider called by the grave) (I have a most likely more powerful and more consistent version of the deck in the works with the same idea, with icejades as your level 4 aqua monsters, however I am not done with it for one, and icejades aren't out on master duel yet, may post it anyway ! Worst comes to worst, on a content update for the game where icejades would be added) (I also have a list which tries to make transmodify work on top of ties of the brethren and thus have more ways to get out a summon lock either through the barrier statue or the other testudo and also both testudo monsters are mostly a perfect special summon lock together. However, while cute on paper, it really just makes the deck less consistent and more convoluted. Also, the other testudo is awkward against 1800 beatsticks - which are legion - as he dies to them in battle even though it is mutual destruction whereas our cute tiny one doesn't bat an eye if in defense mode. The "perfect lock" also messes you up a little bit as you can't special summon either if you pull it off - read "can't get dweller out". If I ever make it work I'll post it/edit this deck) ~tortoise was god

deck_excerpt: Budget FTK Exodia for Master Duel
deck_description: Basic Gameplan: Get a Royal Magical Library out and then start chaining draw spells until you draw Exodia. Shining Angel helps tutor for Royal Magical Library. Either attack into their monster, or chain them while they are attacking you until you can keep a Royal Magical Library out for your turn. Upgrades, for if you have more SR CP: Take out Hand Destruction for Dark World Dealings, to make it easier to pay the cost of discarding cards while you are going off. Take out Gold Moon Coin for Allure of Darkness, for card parity instead of card disadvantage. This also gives us a use for the third Red-Eyes. Take out 2 Broken Bamboo Swords for 2 Cursed Bamboo Swords, to turn the Dark World Dealings into card advantage.
