deck_excerpt: Pure Galaxy-Eyes Deck (Post January 2022 Banlist) - Detailed card explaination in the description.
deck_description:
Galaxy-Eyes Card Choices / Explaination  
Monster Cards
  • Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon(x3)
    • This card is the most wanted card in your deck, hand, field and GY. In the deck it can be searched by Photon Vanisher, Photon Orbital and Galaxy Soldier if needed. In the hand it can be special summon by tributing the tokens summoned by Photon Sanctuary, Galaxy Soldier can use it as discard material and Galaxy Brave can reveal this card to special summon itself. On the field, it can allows Galaxy-Eyes Afterglow Dragon to special summon itself on the field. In the GY, Galaxy Knight can special summon it.
  • Galaxy Knight(x2)
    • This card is the only card you want to summon. If Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon is in the GY it can special summon it. This allows enables a RANK 8 XYZ summon. This card should be searched throught the effect of Galaxy Soldier or Photon Orbital.
  • Galaxy Brave(x3)
    • This card acts like the Blue-Eyes Alternative Dragon but for Galaxy-Eyes. Can only be special summoned using photon cards in your hand. Can used to RANK 4 or 8 XYZ summoning.
  • Galaxy Soldier(x3)
    • One of the best cards to have in your hand. This card can special summon itself and once special summon it allows you to search a card from your deck to your hand. This card also allows Galaxy Knight to special summon Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon if Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon was discarded. Galaxy Soldier enables ther deck to run Cyber Dragon Infinite in the extra deck.
  • Photon Orbital(x3)
    • One of the best cards to have in your hand. Doesn't require you to special summon it, just needs a Galaxy or Photon monster on the field. This card can search and Galaxy card from your deck and is your best searcher. Can be equipped to and XYZ summoned for battle destrction protection.
  • Photon Vanisher(x3)
    • A decent card to have in your hand. Enables the deck to run RANK 4 XYZ monsters. This card searches Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon from the deck to the hand. This benefits Galaxy Soldier and thus benefits Galaxy Knight. This card also special summons ifself.
  • Photon Thrasher(x3)
      • A decent card to have in your hand. Special summons itself and enables RANK 4 XYZ summons. Benefits Photon Vanisher and Photon Orbital.
  •  Astral Kuriboh(x1)
    • One of card. It is not a Galaxy or Photon card. It is a free Level 8 special summon, allowing you to go into RANK 8 XYZ monsters. Cannot activate Galaxy Trance if this card is special summoned
 
Spell Cards
  • Photon Sanctuary(x3)
    • A free special summon for Galaxy-Eyes Solflare Dragon, Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon, Photon Vanisher and techinically a free search via Photon orbital. Unable to XYZ summon this tokens. Locks you in to special summoning light monsters. Cannot special summon Number 97: Draglubion
  • Galaxy Expedition(x2)
    • This card extends your plays for RANK 5 or 8 XYZ summoning. Unable to special summon level 4 monsters.
  • Galaxy Trance(x2)
    • Double Edge Sword. Locks you into Galaxy and Photon special summons. Unable to use Astral Kuriboh or Divine Dragon Knight Felgrand. Free RANK 8 special summon.
  • Trade-In(x3)
    • This deck runs multiple level 8 cards. Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon wants to be in the GY for Galaxy Knight to use. Decent draw power and deck thinning.
  • The Melody of Awakening Dragon(x1)
    • One of card, can get you Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon AND Galaxy-Eyes Afterglow Dragon together, if needed. Can brick or become redundant.
  • Reinforcement of the Army (x1)
    • Limited to 1. Searches Photon Vanisher or Photon Thrasher.
  • Upstart Goblin(x1)
    • Limited to 1. Galaxy-Eyes does not care about giving 1000LP as the deck is able to 1 shot your opponent with large ATK stats. Makes deck into a 39 card deck for more consistency.
Trap Cards
  • Tachyon  Transmigration (x3)
    • Better than Infinite Impermance if going first. Negates all of opponents effects in the chain. Not searchable.
Extra Deck
  • Galaxy-Eyes Solflare Dragon (x1)
    • Can be special summoned using Photon Sanctuary. Returns a card from the GY to the hand. Useful for Photon Orbital's protection effect, or its own destrction effect, in which it can bring back Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon from the GY to the hand.
  • Galaxy-Eyes Cipher X Dragon (x1)
    • Can we used a alternative detacher for Galaxy-Eyes Afterglow Dragon's effect if Galaxy Trance was used and you can no longer use Divine Dragon Knight Felgrand as a detacher and negation. Protects all light XYZ monsters from being targetted by card effects.
  • Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Blade Dragon (x1)
    • Destroys any card on the field. Can we used after Galaxy-Eyes Full Armor Photon Dragon.
  • Galaxy-Eyes Full Armor Photon Dragon (x1)
    • Destroys any face-up card on the field. Can use Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Blade Dragon for a double destruction effect.
  • Number 62: Galaxy-Eyes Prime Photon Dragon (x1)
    • Enables you to one-shot and monster with 3200 ATK or less, using Galaxy-Eyes Afterglows effect once detached.
  • Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Dragon (x1)
    • Allows you to go into Galaxy-Eyes Full Armor Photon Dragon, Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Blade Dragon and Galaxy-Eyes Cipher X Dragon. Can control an opponents monster and special summon Galaxy-Eyes Cipher X Dragon using that one monster.
  • Number 107: Galaxy-Eyes Tachyon Dragon (x1)
    • Full monster board negation effect. Allows you to get rid of monster effects that dont allow a card to be destroyed by battle or card effect. Allows the use of Tachyon Transmigration from the hand.
  • Number 90: Galaxy-Eyes Photon Lord (x1)
    • Monster negation effect. Allows you to search cards for a follow-up play, cards being Galaxy Trance. Can use search effect to enable Galaxy-Eyes Solflare's destrction effect, by searching Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon.
  • Number 97: Draglubion (x1)
    • Can special summon Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy. Cannot activate Galaxy Trance if this card is special summoned.
  • Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy (x1)
    • Spell negation effect. Protects lower ATK stat monsters from being attacked.
  • Divine Dragon Knight Felgrand (x1)
    • Monster negation effect. Is able to be used as a detacher for Galaxy-Eyes Afterglow's effect. Cannot activate Galaxy Trance if this card is special summoned.
  • Cyber Dragon Nova (x1)
    • For going into Cyber Dragon Infinity, using Galaxy Soldier.
  • Cyber Dragon Infinity (x1)
    • Negates monster and spell/trap effects. Can remove monster cards from the field. Cannot activate Galaxy Trance if this card is special summoned.
  • Starliege Photon Blast Dragon (x1)
    • Special summons a free photon monster from your hand. Preferably, Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon. Alternative use for Starliege Lord Galaxion if you want to actiavte Galaxy Trance.
  • Starliege Lord Galaxion (x1)
    • Special summons Galaxy-Eyes Photon Dragon for free from the deck. Cannot activate Galaxy Trance if this card is special summoned.

Summoned Skull "Archfiend" Deck

deck_excerpt: Skelly lads got hands, Zeus is in there too i guess
deck_description: This is the deck i used to get platinum in master duel, kinda started off as a meme but Zombie is my favorite archetype and Skull Servants is quite strong if it builds momentum.  PS: I did make some better versions of this deck so it's easier to get zeus off, will share soonTM  Strat is quite simple:  Main Deck:  3x Skull servant - here just as fodder, can be used for Wightprince effect or summoned with Unexpected dai to make a Xyz summon and get Zeus on the field.  3x Wightprincess - defensive option/combo starter, either summon her and use the effect to throw Wightprince to the graveyard and start the combo or keep her around to use her quick effect to throw sand at the eyes of anything with a high level.  3x The Lady in Wight - the shield of the deck, can protect the King against MOST stuff that would break him, can be easily put on the field with the effect of Wightmare after being banished with Wightprince effect in the graveyard.  3x Wightbaking - this one is the goat, either keep him around to save any of the cores with his quick effect or throw him to the graveyard for his other effect and grab Wightprince (to be discarded) and Wightprincess (to throw sand) or Wightmare to get Lady in Wight in the field.  3x Wightmare - the only thing he's here for is unbanishing a extra skull servant or sumonning a banished Lady in Wight or King of skull servants, or you just normal summon him as fodder for a link/xyz summon.  3x Wightprince - either use him as discard/link summon fodder, just throw him to the graveyard to use his effect.  3x King of the Skull Servants - he's the sword of the deck, can be easily normal summoned since it's a lvl 1, can also be summoned with Wightprince graveyard effect.  3x Maxx "C" - this is necessary against most tier 1-2 decks, plus getting the right cards with it can be a insta-win (unless they negate you to oblivion).  3x Ash Blossom - good combo, unfortunately, i don't want to see 10+ minutes of summoning and resummoning, L + negated + you get no cards.  2x  Mezuki - good to be used with Avendread Savior effect, good atk, and is also a way to get Lady in Wight in the field.  1x Raigeki - board control is important.  1x Harpie's Feather Duster - board control is important.  1x Monster Reborn - either used to unbrick or to get the King back in the field  1x Foolish Burial - use with Wightbaking to get Wightprince + Wightprincess and you're off to a great start  1x One for One - mostly a combo starter  2x Tri-Wight - let's you recicle some monsters to Link/Xyz summon, also a easy Zeus summon  2x Unexpected Dai - also a easy way to Zeus  1x  Lightning Storm - board control is important  2x Burial from a different dimension - use along with Wightprince grave effect to get the King without the -3k attack demerit from having banished the cards  2x Twin Twisters - another way of discarding a combo starter and dealing with Skill Drain/Imperial Order and other hard counters  1x Mirror Force - Classic one, still useful  1x Evenly Matched - you normally only need 1-3 cards on the field, so this is also a good way to deal with extensive combos and full boards  2x Infinite Impermenence - really useful, some effects can be a insta-lose  1x Dark Sacrifice - a way to save the cores, and throw Wightbaking to the grave at the same time  1x Solemn Judgement - omni-negate, can be a insta-win if they can't recover  2x Uni-Zombie - combo starter  Extra deck:  1x Zeus - he's just here for the board control  2x Linkuriboh - normal summoning Wightprince/Wightbaking into Linkuriboh is a decent first turn option most of the tim.  1x Slacker Magician - can be easily used to summon Zeus since she can attack anything and don't worry about being destroyed  1x Number 39: Utopia Roots - also a good option for a Zeus summon, it's also a good option for defense.  2x Number 48: Shadow Lich - good Offense/Defense option if you need to rely on classic beatdown.  1x LANphorhynchus - it only needs two monsters of any king/level so it's good to get rid of vulnerable monsters on the field.  1x Knightmare Phoenix - good ofense/utility and can discard something to the grave.  1x Knightmare Unicorn - same as Phoenix but works for any card instead.  2x Avendread Savior - his effect being able to discard a card from the deck to lower a enemy attack is useful for combos and for defense (wightbaking/mezuki as the main targets)  1x Accesscode Talker - good ofensive option if the opponent has ways of dealing with the king  1x Saryuja Skull Dread - one of the less used cards, but it's kinda useful in late game situations  1x Rasterliger - budget Accesscode Talker

deck_excerpt: A Red-Eyes burning control deck, with fun and interesting combos that help you create a full, strong board, but all break your opponent's board.
deck_description: With this deck, special summoning is no issue, the cards on the main deck very rarely require a tribute or normal summon. With all the cards in place, both Red-eyes and supporting cards (Vishuda, Nessie, Dogman, Dark Magician, Alternative Black Dragon, etc.) you can keep summoning monsters from both your hand and GY. Also, your spells and traps, give some base security when special summoning, especially Return of The Red-Eyes, or when you need to maintain your rhythm in summoning (Allure of Darkness). However, your main objective is to bring out mainly Red-Eyes Flare Metal Dragon and Dark Dragoon, as Flare Metal will burn your opponent per effect, and Dark Dragoon can break your opponent's board. Your Link Monsters can also support your deck by co-linking and thus drawing cards, but also destroying and negating your opponent's monsters and card effects. Usually aim for Verte Anaconda, as its effect can secure you Dark Dragoon and keep summoning cards (if you copy Red-Eyes Fusion's effect, which disregards its downside).

deck_excerpt: Being a menace and making people angry can be fun sometimes.
deck_description: Before getting started: Originally I planned on playing a (mostly) pure 'Lair of Darkness' deck, a deck that solely revolves around it's field spell, but it's just not all that good. Next I combined them with Rikkas, since their main gimmick is to tribute monsters, and for the most part, that worked out decently well (if anyone wants that version, I can upload it). Firstly, what *is* a Lair of Darkness deck? It's a deck centered around it's field spell, a field spell that lets you tribute your opponent's monsters. Although that sounds amazing, the deck can brick, very hard, this deck aims to improve consistency and/or stall enough to where you can get your plays going. I'll touch up more down below the explanation of the monsters/spells/traps. Without further ado, let's go through what the deck consists of, and why they're there.   Monsters: (I will NOT be covering Maxx "C", Monster Reborn, or Raigeki here) Tour Guide From the Underworld - Tour Guide is a staple in virtually any fiend deck, as it allows you to special summon 1 level 3 or lower fiend monster from your deck when it's normal summoned. She's a great extender and an amazing combo starter for this deck, as the fiend monsters (every one of them, aside from Tour Guide herself) don't *need* their effects (I'll touch up more on this later). (3) Lilith, Lady of Lament - Lilith is arguably the boss monster of this deck, although her stats aren't as good as 'Darkest Diabolos', her quick effect (she's the only one in this deck with one) allows you to tribute 1 dark monster (more on why this is good later). If her effects aren't negated, you can tribute 1 monster to reveal 3 normal traps and have your opponent choose one of them at random to set on your field (so keep in mind, if you want to add more Trap Trick in, that's totally fine). Ahrima, the Wicked Warden - Ahrima is honestly what makes the deck a lot more bearable, you can discard him from your hand to search out 'Lair of Darkness', making him invaluable to have. When he's on field, you can also tribute 1 dark monster to search out your 'Darkest Diabolos', which you'll almost always want either in-hand or in your GY. Darkest Diabolos, Lord of the Lair - Diabolos is the other boss monster of this deck, and you'll always want at least 1 copy of him in your deck list (you can add more, but he can be bricky at times). He can't be tributed and your opponent can't target him with card effects, both very good effects for the most part, but aside from that and being a beatstick with 3k attack, he's very easy to get on the field, as he special summons himself from the GY or hand when one of your monsters is tributed (yes, even getting Kaiju'd works). To top it off, when he tributes, your opponent has to put a card from their hand on either the top or bottom of their deck (their choice).   Spells: Foolish Burial - Mostly included here for 2 reasons: you can use it with Monster Reborn, and to send Diabolos to the GY. Terraforming - A must-have for any field spell centric deck, it just searches out your field spell. Pot of Extravagance - This deck can be very bricky at times, and you definitely don't want any of your main deck banished, so this and Pot of Prosperity are the next best thing. The only reason I included this instead of Prosperity is because of allowing you to draw 1 more card, you can swap these if you want, though. Lair of Darkness - The main center piece of this deck and something you'll always want on the field, it's the field spell. When this card is on the field, all face-up monsters become DARK attribute monsters, making your life a lot easier. Once per turn, you can tribute 1 face-up DARK monster your enemy controls, which is great removal as it's not destructive, it doesn't target, and it allows you to potentially get some of your effects off. To add on to those 2 effects, it also creates tokens up to the amount of times the turn player tribute summoned. That means if you tributed 4 times, you get 4 tokens. Note that if you tribute on their turn, they get the tokens.   Traps: Dimensional Prison - This trap allows you to target and banish an opponent's attacking monster, making it decent at stalling and helpful for situations where you need it. Trickstar Reincarnation - Normally you'd use this with the other Lament sister, Malice, but I'll touch up on her down there. This trap card is limited to 1 (thankfully), because it allows you to banish your opponent's entire hand (they get to draw the same amount, so it's usually run with 'Droll & Lock Bird', but they'd end up bricking us). Metaverse - Another limited 1, kind of Terraforming's older brother, it allows you to take a field spell from your deck and either add it to your hand or activate it. Waking the Dragon - In a deck with as many traps as this, and with how often people run things like 'Harpie's Feather Duster', this is a no-brainer. When your opponent removes (in any sense, banished, destroyed, or gently sent to the GY), you get to special summon 1 extra deck monster. Grinning Grave Virus - GGV is something that can make your life worse or better, depending on what's sent to the GY. It allows you to tribute 1 DARK monster with 3k or less ATK, and then have your opponent destroy 1 card for every 500 ATK of that monster from their hand and/or deck (so if you tributed a monster with 1k ATK, they'd destroy 2 cards). If you, however, tributed a monster with 2k or more ATK, you get to look at all the cards your opponent draws until the end of their 3rd turn after you activated it. Not only that, but all monsters they draw are immediately destroyed, and they can't activate their effects in the GY the turn they were destroyed by that effect. Trap Trick - Trap Trick is another must-have for this deck, as it allows you to banish 1 trap from your deck to set a copy of that trap (you have to have 2+ copies), which you can activate that turn. Ice Dragon's Prison - It'd be weird if I didn't include this in the deck profile, it's a trap that allows you to target a monster in your opponent's GY, special summon it to your field (its effects are negated), and then banish a monster they control of the same type (ie. if you use this to target a Dragon in their GY, and they have Dragon on field, you can banish both of the cards.) So at worst it's a worse Monster Reborn. Solemn Judgement - This deck doesn't have much of anything in terms of negation, so this is probably your best bet for that, highly advised to run with at least 2 copies. Skill Drain - I know people hate Skill Drain and that's just another reason I put this in here, it's something that not only stops your opponent from using on-field monster effects, but it doesn't really affect this deck much at all (more on that). Summon Limit - Pretty self-explanatory, neither player can summon more than 2 times per turn (negated summons still count), and it's not like we're summoning a bunch of monsters anyways, aside from tokens.   Extra Deck: Naturia Exterio - Naturia Exterio is an amazing card to have on field since he's like a Drytron for activated spells/traps. You can banish 1 card from your GY, send the top of your deck to the GY, and then negate an activated trap/spell (doesn't work on already activated traps/spells). Best part? It's not a once per turn, as long as you have banish targets and a deck, you can negate. Black Rose Moonlight Dragon - You don't necessarily need this, but it does help a lot in keeping your opponent in check, since it (on special summon as well) allows you to send 1 level 5 or higher special summoned monster your opponent controls to the hand. With summon limit, it becomes a lot more oppressive. Geomathmech Final Sigma - Sigma is a win-con by himself a lot of the times, since he's unaffected by card effects outside of other Mathmechs (which, who runs?). Any battle damage this card inflicts is also doubled, which at 3k attack, is pretty decent. The catch being that this card *has* to be in the Extra Monster Zone for those effects. Beat Cop from the Underworld - Beat Cop is a great addition here, since she not only can tribute a monster your opponent controls, but when you do tribute a monster with her (so long as you used 2 DARK monsters with different names), you can put a Patrol Counter on a card, allowing it to be safe from destruction, by the amount of counters on it (your main target for them would be Lair of Darkness). Wee Witch's Apprentice - You can definitely take her out or substitute her for something else, but she's mainly just another way of getting back a monster from your GY, which you can also use tokens.   Extra Information: This deck has a lot to it for the most part, a lot of it comes down to knowing your opponent's decks, since you'll want to make the most out of your 1 tribute summon. I'll add some 'I-think-you-should-know-this' info down below. What happens if my monster effects are negated? Outside of maybe 'Tour Guide' who special summons Lilith or Ahrima, you don't really need them, as you can still activate their effects and tribute monsters, they just don't get the benefits of them tributing (ex: you can tribute a monster with Lilith, but you don't get to excavate trap cards if her effects are negated). Why do you run 'Waking the Dragon' in this deck? Simple, it's a trap heavy deck and centered around a field spell, people are going to want to pop every trap and the field spell at any chance they can get, why not reap the benefits if you don't have an out to them like Solemn? Why Skill Drain at 3? Isn't that a bit bricky? Absolutely, it can be a brick, but like Solemn and Summon Limit, you can't search for them as you can with normal traps, so you'll want to increase your chance of having it in your starting hand. No hand traps outside of Maxx "C"? The deck needs all the consistency it can get, putting Ash Blossom, Called by the Grave, or any other hand traps would just clutter it or make it harder to stall. Why is the Extra Deck so small? Mostly because I'm leaving it to you, so I can be lazy, as I'm not all that knowledgeable on the best targets for 'Waking the Dragon' (and no, I won't just Google "best targets for Waking the Dragon'). No Sangan?!?! Swap out Sangan for a Skill Drain if you want, but I just prefer stalling until I get that monster on field. Where are the other cards, 'Alice, Lady of Lament' and 'Diabolos, King of the Abyss'? They're probably hanging out with 'Trouble Sunny', who is also not in the game. Give us them, Konami. Recurring Nightmare? You can tech this in, but it's not searchable and for it to appear in your hand often you'd have to add 2 or 3, so it's not really worth it in my opinion. Weaknesses: So we've covered the good, what's the bad? Well firstly, since it *is* based around its field spell, it can be vulnerable if you don't have negates or anything to stop the removal of it, which can stop your play dead in the tracks if you don't have that good of a hand. Although this deck can go second and still win, it'll have some trouble, as we rely heavily on our normal summon and not having our stuff, y'know, destroyed. The deck also struggles with cards being sent to the GY and/or being banished, as there are hardly any ways to get them back, so that means if an enemy is about to banish your on-field Lilith, let her tribute herself and/or a monster that will be removed. Pot of Extravagance is both a blessing and a curse for this deck, as you can banish your main 'Waking the Dragon' targets, so be weary on using it. Backrow heavy decks are also an annoying matchup against this deck for the most part so keep that in mind.   Last thoughts: This deck is an absolute blast to play for the most part, which if you didn't like playing Eldlich because it's just "bring back goldie boy, activate trap monster", you might like this. I have not done any playtesting in Platinum with this deck (I don't want to) so I can't say this is a Plat 1 deck, but it is very annoying when you have the right setup going. I hope I don't see this deck in Ranked, please keep it away from me, thank you.

deck_excerpt: Despite what was said I think Nekroz deserves a second chance to prove itself as an Anti-Meta contendor
deck_description: Video link available below ( https://youtube.com/watch?v=RI6phHJHzpY&feature=youtu.be )  Back in 2015, what was thought to be the bane of all of Yu-Gi-Oh came to be in form of a ritual deck that did all kinds of things that no one expected besides pissing off Extra Deck monsters to hearts content. Now here we are in 2022 and it is still doing the same thing, only yet it is a lot more fun to have around than Monarchs (no offense to Lithium2300). Now with the recent "important" competitive taking place, and with the winter 2021/2022 competitive dueling season wrapping up, the meta have went full circle to undergo a 180° to where the reliance on Extra Deck monsters is now more than ever *(including with the recent shortcomings for the Adventurer and D/D decks that got the deserved boost from it's players at YCS Las-Vegas).    How does Nekroz play into the picture as an Anti-Meta contendor with the sudden dependency of the Extra Deck? Simply put it that it has the ritual monsters that can skelter your opponents ability to utilize their ED monsters to their fullest potential; such examples include "Nekroz of Unicore" (which entirely locks their effects if special summoned from the Extra Deck) and "Nekroz of Areadbhair" (used to tribute unnecessary Garnets from your hand or unwanted monsters from your field to negate and banish monsters such as DPE). Besides the usual Unicore and Areadbhair, also in the lineup is "Nekroz of Brionac" (TL;DR, Knightmare Unicorn, but without a discard cost and can target 2 monsters that were Special summoned from the Extra Deck), and "Nekroz of Trishula" (Banish 3 cards, but 1 each from your opponents hand, field, and Graveyard), "Nekroz of Clausolas" (Negates Effects of monster Special Summoned ftom ED and reduces attack to 0). Besides those, "Shurit, Strategist of the Nekroz" (once having very significant importance) still maintains relevancy to the deck only as a hit switch as an urgency tool for Areadbhair, Unicore, or even Trishula. As for the ritual spells, a 2-2-1 ratio (that being cycle, Kaleidescape, and then mirror) has been the most common ratio in modern Nekroz builds for a reason I am assuming involving them being a brick of sorts.    As for Impcantations and the Dogmatika engine, the debate surrounding the two is that some say one engine is better than the other. To be fair, both have their fair share of problems, and both have their strengths. For Impcantations, I decided to go with a ratio involving with *(2 Candoll, 2 Talismandra, 1 Penciplume, 1 Bookstone).* The reason for not running Chalislime is because I feel it is not worth prioritizing the Impcantation engine solely for the sake of getting Nekroz monsters out; however I do keep in notion that I still use the Impcantation Ritual Spell card anytime I have the monsters not being conceived as Garnet pieces. As for Dogmatika, the only pieces I have going for it is Ecclesia, Titaniklad, and Nadir Servant. This is because of the components needed for Dogmatika Punishment which helps mill out all kinds of Extra Deck monsters I could use in any compacity.   Finally comes the Other stuff which aren't too special; however the most notable cards include "Tri-Brigade Ferrijit the Barren Blossom" (because it is a Draw 1 that allows me to put any pieces back that I will need later on); "Triple Tactics Talent" mainly due to the fact I'm not running any hand traps for Nekroz doesn't traditionally run handtraps in their main deck unless necessary; and "Diviner of the Heralds" to mill cards like "Elder Entity N'tss and "Herald of The Arc Light" on summon.
raw power blue eyes white dragon.
Write your deck strategy here....

This Deck uses the Felgrand-Arkbrave engine and is supported by Blue-Eyes and Galaxy archtype. Main goal is to get Arkbrave Dragon and Divine Dragon Lord Felgrand to the Graveyard as soon as possible and get the following basic combo working:
  • 1. Arkbrave is sent to the GY and specials Felgrand from GY
  • 2. Felgrand destroys an opponent monster and specials Arkbrave from GY
with this engine running you want to get more Dragons into your GY so you can then special summon any other level 7/8 Dragon from it and finally Xyz summon all Galaxy Dragons. some other "combos" & tips:
  • Summon Paladin of Felgrand and equip Arkbrave or Felgrand to it, then activate Ruins of the Divine Dragon Lords on the equipped card, spawn token & send equipped monster to GY, activate Paladin's effect and special summon the Dragon from GY
  • Melody of Awakening Dragon can draw BEWD and Alternative BEWD, then the latter can be special summoned instantly
  • Use Dragone Shrine first on Dragon Spirit of White as it is counted as Normal Monster, so you can send another Dragon to your GY
  • Galaxy Soldiers can special summon themselves and Xyz summon Cyber Nova Dragon and then Xyz into Cyber Dargon Infinity
  • Synchro Summon Blue-Eyes Spirit Dragon using White Stone of the Ancients and directly special summon Azure-Eyes Silver Dragon
  • Recycle your Dragons through Xyz summoning and detaching them, so you can special summon them again from GY and activate their effects another time
  • Dragunity Arma Leyvaten and Arkbrave Dragon can loop each other infinitely

deck_excerpt: Megalith is one of the most interesting archetypes to learn in the game.
deck_description: Megalith is a Ritual deck with unique in-game mechanics with the peculiarity that the Archetype's own Ritual monsters can Ritual Summon without the use of Ritual Spell which is a great adaptation of Yugioh's second oldest game mechanics along with the Fusion monsters that were at the start of the game one minus 2 for anyone who wanted to use the mechanic as they needed 3 cards to play: 1 Ritual monster, 1 Tribute monster with a level EqualorHigher than the Ritual, and a specific Ritual Spell to do the Ritual Summon. Thus Megalith is a privileged deck because it "steals" the Ritual Mechanics as it doesn't follow the standard for Ritual Summoning. At most, what managed to surpass this deck was Drytron that "steals" in the mechanics when Ritual Summoning using the monsters' ATK and not the level. It should be clear that Megalith is by no means one of the hardest decks to learn in the game at the level of a D/D/D for example. People say this because it's true that no one who plays versus Megalith knows what you're doing but overall the deck is not beginner friendly but very welcome for those who like creativity in Yugioh! //////////////////////////////////////////////// ////Understanding Megalith Archetype Cards: In general, Level 8 Archetype monsters Ritual Summon a "MEGALITH" Monster from your hand when discarding itself from the hand to the GY and Megalith Aratron has a Quick eff of Ritual Summoning which allows you to use it on your opponent turn to make moves. Level 4 monsters Ritual Summon "ANY Ritual Monster" from your hand activating their effect in the FIELD and MUST USE themselves as part of the Tribute for the Ritual Summon, meaning you must first bring them to the field to after being able to use their Ritual Summon effects and they have to be part of the Tribute for the monster they will bring from their hand, among Level 4 who have Quick eff to do Ritual Summon is Megalith Och and can be used on the opponent's turn. Megalith Phul is the combination of all the qualities of the previous monsters by Ritual Summoning a "MEGALITH" Monster from your hand or DECK, being a Quick eff that can be used on the opponent's turn and doesn't even need to be used as a tribute of the monster that will bring to the field. An important detail is that all Megalith monsters can only use their Ritual Summon effect Once per Turn, however all Level 4 monsters have the effect of when they are Ritual Summoned NOT HARD ONCE PER TURN, so if you manage to do 3 Ritual Summon from Megalith Hagith, Megalith Ophiel or Megalith Och on the same turn they will activate their advantage effect every time, which makes them a bit broken and allows for a lot of different combos. And finally, along with all this, we have Megalith Unformed, which is a Quick-Play spell that, like Megalith Phul, Ritual Summons "MEGALITH" Monsters DIRECT FROM THE DECK, only here you must tribute a monster(s) with DOUBLE Level of the Megalith you are going to bring from the deck, so if you Tribute a Level8 monster you bring any Level4 Megalith and by Tributing any Level4 monster you bring Megalith Phul to the field, and if that wasn't enough Ritual Summon from the DECK to Megalith Unformed It is NOT Hard Once Per Turn and can be used multiple times in the same turn increasing the deck's power significantly. The deck has incredible Recovery thanks to the Impcantation engine and the engine's own cards like Megalith Phul, Megalith Portal and Megalith Emergence. High number of Starters and consistency cards and great interactions with the opponent and finally it is extremely budget. That's why you don't need to maximize Ophiel and Hagith, which is common for people to do, because their main role in turn 1 is to access Megalith Phul and then thanks to the engine's excellent Recovery you can always get them back to hand and do Ritual Summon every turn to gain advantage so it's best to leave both their slots for Tech Cards to improve the deck by going second. Megalith Phul in my opinion is the best Ritual monster in the game, he adds any Ritual monster in the GY to the hand by manipulating its level to match the added target. And it has a Quick effect of Ritual Summoning Megalith straight from the DECK and doesn't even need to tribute it for that, so it generates a lot of advantage and interaction with the opponent throughout the game. A key part of the Megalith archetype. Megalith Och and Megalith Phaleg are surgical cards with Phaleg needed to finish and Och needed to control the game with Ritual Summon monsters outside the archetype. You want to use them whenever you need them and you don't need to see them in the first hand so we only use 1 copy of each. Trap Megalith Emergence is the best way to allow you to RANK-4 plays in the Grind Game by reborning a Megalith every turn. It also synergizes with the FIELD Spell Megalith Portal which triggers eff of adding any Ritual Monster from the GY to the hand even if a Megalith is Special Summoned to the field and not only it was Ritual Summoned then the Trap triggers the Field Spell effect leaving your insane Grind Game even against the best Grind Game decks in the game you can manage very well. Megalith Bethor is the win condition of Megalith's archetype being the only interaction via engine available, when Ritual Summoned it targets and destroys opponent's cards by the number of Ritual Monsters with Different Names in its GY and can often destroy the opponent's entire field of just one time. And since the deck has several ways to Ritual Summon the opponent's turn, it's not difficult to bring it onto the field to be an interruption to the opponent's turn 2 plays and leave the simplified gamestate in your favor. And that's the strength of Megalith: its versatility in Ritual Summoning on the opponent's turn and interacting in different ways depending on the Deck they're using. //////////////////////////////////////////////// ////Generic Ritual Support to help Megalith: Among the generic support of Ritual, the Impcantation engine stands out for generating an absurd advantage so that you can make Ritual Summon with the lowest possible investment, which makes perfect sense when it comes to the second oldest game mechanic that needs to be updated to be competitive. Impcantation Chalislime is the best starter in the engine because it has the effect of discarding a card from the hand to Special Summon an Impcantation straight from the DECK having 3 targets in the Megalith deck: Impcantation Candoll that when Special from the Deck adds a Ritual Spell that we only have the Impcantation Inception, the Impcantation Talismandra which adds a Ritual Monster from the Deck to the hand like Cyber Angel Benten, and the Impcantation Penciplume which adds a Ritual Monster from the GY to the hand. These monsters also have hand effects to reveal a Ritual Monster or a Ritual Spell to Special Summon BOTH it and an Impcantation from the DECK. All these monsters have restrictions on the use of their effects: Chalislime makes you lose 2500LP if you don't Ritual Summon after resolving its effect, and the Impcantation non-Ritual Monsters can only use 1 of the effects per turn, Only Once that Turn in addition to having continuous effect in the field that you cannot SPECIAL Summon from the EXTRA Deck. Finally, to complete the Impcantation engine we have the absurd Archetype Ritual Spell called Impcantation Inception, it Ritual Summons Any Ritual Monster by TRIBUTE ALSO "IMPCANTATION" Monsters but in addition it has an excellent GY effect if you send an "Impcantation Card " from the hand or field to the GY to SPECIAL Summon an "Impcantation" from the DECK and return it to the hand which generates a lot of advantage and game volume. Herald Engine: Diviner of the Herald is the best Normal Summon possible for Ritual decks because it does the same thing as Manju but with several more details, such as the fact that it can send both Herald of the Arc Light or N 'tss from the Extra Deck to be an interaction going second, and it even raises its own level by the monster sent to the GY being in these examples becoming Level6. It is also a TUNER monster which allows you to make Synchro plays and there are several excellent options available mainly because it becomes Level6 which allows you to make Baronne de Fleur on your End Board which is just the best Synchro monster in the game currently. Third it also has an effect when Tributed to Special Summon a Level 2 or lower Fairy monster from the Deck which is interesting to find synergies with the card, the main target to bring is Eva which can add interaction to the hand when sent to the GY as Herald of Orange Light and another Diviner of the Herald. Besides, we have to talk about the Herald of the Arc Light, which is an Extra Deck monster that you want to send to the GY because it has an effect equal to the Manju of adding a Ritual Monster or Ritual Spell from the Deck to the Hand, We also have the LINK-2 of the Archetype Herald of Mirage Lights which is a very interesting card for being able to negate the opponent's Spell/Trap by sending Fairy Monsters from the hand to the GY and has an excellent Floating effect of being able to add up to 2 Ritual cards from the GY to the hand greatly improving your Grind Game. Manju and Senju are the Normal Summons of the deck and by themselves are great Starters to make plays. Cyber Angel Benten is in the deck only because it is a search of Normal Summon Manju or Senju when Tributed, you can also choose to use Vanity's Ruler which is a very powerful floodgate to prevent only the opponent from Special Summoning and also helps you play around Psy-Framegear Gamma and Nibiru, the Primal Being. Benten is a card that will always appear in Ritual decks in at least 1 copy and for sure she is still in the game even with the abuse that Drytron did the card is very good for the other Ritual decks that people forget she is is also important. If there was a side deck in Master Duel you could use Benten to add Artifact Lancea. Preparation of Rites fetches all Rituals level 7 or lower which means Adding all starters in the deck and can also add Ritual Spell in GY to hand and it's not even hard once per turn. Among the interesting generic Ritual Monsters to use in the deck we have the following main options: Black Chaos MAX, Lord of the Red, Leviathan @Ignister, Shinobaron Peacock and Shirobaroness Peacock. Black Chaos MAX is basically a Ritual Monster version of Azathot and that Megalith manages to loop to the field every turn quite consistently. In theory Black Chaos MAX is very good to turn off the opponent's turn and the game comes back to you and OTK it but it proved to be very difficult to do with the tests I made because practically you must first access it through Megalith Och, second get it by Manju/Senju or Talismandra and otherwise you can't do anything else besides the setup to Ritual Summon it on the opponent's turn, so you spend a lot of resources that when it comes back passes the turn you can't finish the opponent. Lord of the Red and Leviathan @Ignister I see them as the best interaction cards to use in the deck and the Shinobaron Ritual Monsters are also excellent forms of interaction, especially Shirobaroness Peacock which shuffles spells/traps back into the deck and both it has the effect that in the End Phase they go back to the hand and create two Level4 Tokens on your field to facilitate Ritual Summon on your next turn but I don't think they are necessary cards in the deck for the following reason: The biggest problem with these generic Rituals is that they only it has the function of entering the field and you spend a lot of resources for that which is the problem with Ritual mechanics about being too expensive. It's better when playing Megalith you do little, but that little if the opponent deals with the field I still have a lot of resources to get back into the game and if I need to enter the Grind Game with the opponent. The same goes for those who use Halqifibrax engine or FTK combos in the deck because one of two options will happen: either you instantly win when the Combo passes or lose to Hand Traps and Blind Second Cards like Dark Ruler No More that's when you can play for as much of Brick that adds to the deck when trying to make these moves. So it's much better to maximize Megalith's moves, which is a very well done archetype where all the cards talk very well with each other and make a respectful setup against any opponent than opt for those other engines that are not productive and don't generate you advantage in the same way that the purest version already does. Other Generic Ritual Monsters include: Sauravis, the Ancient and Ascended and Nekroz Rituals like Nekroz of Unicore, Nekroz of Trishula, Nekroz of Clausolas. The deck's Extra Deck is mostly made up of TOOLBOX XYZ RANK-4 that deal with almost any problem on the opponent's field and generate good interactions with the opponent like the Abyss Dweller and Gallant Granite adding Nibiru, the Primal Being, we also have some useful Link Monsters in the Deck but which in general are less important than XYZ monsters, a good option is to use Nephthys, the Sacred Flame that when done with 3 Ritual Monsters it simply cannot be destroyed by battle or effects, cannot be targeted by cards and gains 2400ATK reaching 4800ATK which makes it an extremely difficult card for Control decks to take out as Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon and Black Luster Soldier, LINK-3 are also a great win condition against Control decks. In general most of the cards are not mandatory so you can leave the Extra Deck as budget as possible. //////////////////////////////////////////////// ////Combos: In the beginning, when I started to learn how to play Megalith, all the moves I made I always chose to access Megalith Unformed through Megalith Hagith as quickly as possible and keep Looping Hagith and Megalith Ophiel, Ritual Summoning them several times in a row to set up a minimal field and this worked because it was at the time of Block Dragon existence in the game so even though it's not the most efficient way to use its resources because turning the engine doing Ritual Summon by the effect of Megalith and doesn't by the spell Unformed gives you much more advantage, Block Dragon it simply regained all the advantage with its absurd effect of being able to add 2 to 3 Rock Monsters to the hand. Over time I learned to use Megalith Unformed more as a card for you to have on the end board to use on your opponent's turn. Of course, the card is excellent and you can use it as a combo starter, but as I got better with the deck I saw that looping Hagith Add Unformed and spending in many cases up to 3 Unformed on turn 1 is not the best way to make combo. With that I stopped using 3 copies of Hagith and Ophiel because you can use them several times per turn without needing the third copy as you have several ways to recycle them to your hand with the deck engine during your combos. And the Combos I do now with the deck play much better around cards like Dark Ruler No More and Forbidden Droplets in addition to Kaiju, which was only possible in the LINKROSS Format version because of Block Dragon, that is, the Combos were not the best way to play Megalith but you never got punished because you had the victory button called Block Dragon. I would be using Diviner of the Herald instead of Manju if there was Baronne de Fleur in Master Duel, but for now Manju is enough for the deck but it's definitely a change I'll make in the future. Some of the combos must be repeated but at least it's good for you to train to learn Megalith because that's how you learn something. Some combos may be wrong so try redoing them to see if they are correct. Some combos I did Adding Aratron to the hand, but since I don't use him in the decklist anymore you can just add Bethor to the hand instead for example. //////////////////////////////////// Combo 1: (Chalislime + Discard) + Hagith + Ophiel Chalislime eff Discard Random Card SS Candoll Candoll eff Add Inception Activate Inception Ritual Ophiel and eff Add Phul Ophiel eff Ritual Hagith and eff Add Portal and Activate Portal Hagith eff Ritual Phul and Phul cl1 tgt Hagith and Portal cl2 tgt Ophiel Add Ophiel and Hagith to Hand Phul eff Tribute itself Ritual Och from Deck Och eff Draw 1 Discard 1 Och eff Tribute itself Ritual Hagith and eff Add Emergence(Trap) Inception eff in GY send Chalislime to GY SS Talismandra and Return to Hand Talismandra eff Add Black Chaos MAX Activate Inception Ritual Ophiel and eff Add Aratron Gamestate: Hagith + Ophiel + Portal + Emergence /in Hand: Aratron + Black Chaos MAX /in GY: Phul + Och Opponent's Turn: Activate Emergence and eff Reborn Och in Defense(return to Bottom when leaves the Portal) Portal eff Add Phul to Hand(Follow Up) Och eff tribute itself and Ophiel Ritual Black Chaos MAX Black Chaos MAX eff tribute itself Skip Opponent's Turn(can't activate Monster Effects) If Opponent's Set 5 backrow: Aratron eff discard itself and tribute Black Chaos MAX Ritual Phul Phul eff Add Aratron becomes Level8 Phul eff tribute itself Ritual Bethor from Deck Bethor eff Destroy up to 4 cards Gamestate: Hagith + Bethor + Portal + Emergence /in Hand: Aratron /in GY: Phul + Hagith + Ophiel + Och //////////////////////////////////// Combo 2: Chalislime + Inception Chalislime eff Discard Inception SS Talismandra Talismandra eff Add Ophiel Inception eff in GY send Talismandra to GY SS Candoll and Return to Hand Activate Inception tribute Candoll Ritual Ophiel and eff Add Phul Ophiel eff tribute itself Ritual Phul and eff Add Ophiel becomeLevel4 Phul eff tribute Chalislime Ritual Hagith from DECK Hagith eff Add Portal and Activate Portal Hagith eff tribute itself Ritual Ophiel Ophiel eff cl1 Portal eff cl2 tgt Hagith Add Bethor from Deck and Add Hagith from GY Bethor eff discard to GY and tribute Phul Ritual Hagith Hagith eff Add Emergence and Set Emergence RANK-4 Dweller/Gallant Granite Gamestate: RANK-4 Dweller/Gallant Granite + Portal + Emergence /in Hand: nothing /in GY: Phul + Bethor + Inception + Chalislime //////////////////////////////////// Combo 3: Hagith/Ophiel + Unformed (This combo can also be done if you open from any Level8 Monster or 1Level6+1Level2 Monster + Unformed because you access Ophiel who adds Phul to the hand making a full Megalith combo) Activate Unformed tribute Hagith Ritual Phul and eff Add Hagith ***Phul eff tribute itself Ritual Ophiel from DECK and eff Add Hagith ***(you could also add Megalith Och with Ophiel's effect and the end result would be the same because Hagith tribute itself Ritual Och and Och tribute itself Ritual Hagith and that way you can add both Portal and Emergence to the hand , and the interesting thing about having access to Och is that on your opponent's turn you can use Megalith Emergence Reborn Och and Portal Add Phul to Hand and use Megalith Och tribute itself(Return to Bottom of Deck) Ritual Phul from Hand and Phul eff Add Hagith and then you can still use Phul eff to bring Bethor from DECK, the good thing about playing this way is that Megalith Phul stays in the GY for Follow Up on the next turn instead of going back to the bottom of the Deck) Ophiel eff tribute itself Ritual Hagith and eff Add Portal and Activate Portal Hagith eff Cards Opponent Controls cl1 and Benten eff Add 1 Light Fairy from DECK cl2 //////////////////////////////////////////////// //// Final Deck gameplay details: Megalith's Quick effects to Ritual Summon like Megalith Phul and Megalith Och allow you to play around target effects like Infinite Impermanence and Effect Veiler to Ritual Summon them as tribute so they don't get negated and resolve their effects. Ritual Summon's Quick effect can also be used just to take advantage of negate and destroy monsters effects so you can chain the effect and use the Ritual monster as Tribute like Ophiel effect and Opponent's chain Herald of Orange Light, you can cl2 use Megalith Phul eff to perform another Ritual Summon before Ophiel is destroyed gaining value even after taking interruptions. These same interactions apply to Megalith Unformed to play around interactions that target or destroy your Megalith monsters or even Manju's Normal Summon. Funny thing about Megalith Portal Field Spell is that it triggers eff to Add 1 Ritual from GY to Hand even if your opponent Special Summons a Megalith Monster so in Mirror Match it has interesting applications. ***One move I make a lot is to Reborn Megalith Phul with Megalith Emergence but this move makes when Phul leaves the field he goes back to the bottom of the deck which is something you don't want so a way to solve this is you start using Megalith Och more during your combos because you can Reborn it and add Phul to your hand and use it as a tribute to Phul's Ritual and it will be the Megalith Och that goes back to the bottom of the Deck and not Phul and you have the setup to do Bethor on the opponent's turn in the same way. Turn 1 the deck has no way in the engine to play around Nibiru, the Primal Being unless you make a Rafflesia and use Gravedigger's Trap Hole which only works in specific hands having to do 3 or 4 card Combo which is very ineffective though at least if you can add Trap Megalith Emergence to the hand and Reborn Megalith Phul on the opponent's turn you will be able to Tribute the Nibiru Token that is Level11 to bring Megalith Bethor on the opponent's turn and destroy several opponent's cards, that is , even after taking Nibiru there are ways to have interaction and recovery on the opponent's turn with the combination of Megalith Portal and Emergence. Always try to play around Nibiru turn 3 onwards if the gamestate is already simplified and you just need to finish the game with Megalith Phaleg because you can definitely bring him to the field with a maximum of 4 summons. One cool thing about this deck is that you do a Turn 1 combo to add Nibiru to your hand with Gallant Granite because you don't care about having the field cleared by Nibiru since with 1 card like Emergence you can already recover the entire Megalith engine again to start plays. ***A tip about playing around Nibiru is not to use the Impcantation Inception effect on the GY if you already have a way to continue the combo without having to use it, just in case you take Nibiru, the Primal Being you use it as a Push to continue your moves and at least least able to add Trap Megalith Emergence to the hand with Megalith Hagith. But if you are going to play Talismandra Add Cyber Angel Benten you can use Spell Impcantation Inception eff in GY without any problems because to have a push after Nibiru will be easy since Benten Adds Manju/Diviner of the Herald. It's always very important when you have Chalislime in the GY to add it back to the hand with Megalith Phul or Megalith Portal for the next turn to send it to the GY to add the Impcantation Inception back to the hand and Special an Impcantation from deck. Interaction Inpcantation Inception vs D.D. Crow = Even if Inception gets banished from the GY you will still Special Summon an Impcantation from the Deck. Always check how many Ritual monsters you have in the GY to know who to Tribute with Megalith Phul effect to bring Megalith Bethor straight from the deck. Megalith Emergence is certainly one of the best Grind Game cards in the game, it's absurd how this card alone can make your engine play again and even loop Megalith Bethor because it returns the monster that gives Reborn to the bottom of the deck so every turn you get to use Phul to bring him back to the field and destroy all your opponent's cards. Megalith has a lot of 2 Card Combo or 2 Card Combo and 1 Discard and the more cards you have in your hand the end result of the Combo will not be better, but more resilient to interactions. Depending on the hand you open you can break the opponent's established fields with various interations knowing how to start plays so that you can extend after the opponent's interruptions. Gallant Granite only has the function of Adding Nibiru to the hand, so since its usefulness ends as soon as it's used you can RANK-5 Drill Driver Vespenato on top of it that has an amazing floating effect. It's a pretty good addition to the build as well. Always remember that if you choose to use Diviner of the Herald instead of Manju you can very easily make Baronne de Fleur to have an interaction with the opponent in the form of Omni Negate which is something Megalith was never able to do until the Baronne de Fleur was released in the game. Speaking of synergy between Diviner of the Herald and Baronne de Fleur if you needed to use Baronne de Fleur's omni negate on your turn you can in the opponent's Standby Phase use the effect of returning to the Extra Deck and Special Summon Diviner of the Herald and use its trigger effect and send a second Herald of the Arc Light to the GY and add another Ritual Monster to the Hand. I'm still using Manju because I'm playing Megalith in Master Duel and there's no Baronne de Fleur in the game but for sure when he gets to Master Duel I'll use it in the deck along with Diviner of the Herald since it's the only way to you make an Omni Negate in Megalith's deck. Apollousa is a card that ends the Megalith, alone she can for all her play attempts. Interestingly if you use I:P Masquerena + Apollousa in Megalith's Extra Deck Apollousa has a great synergy with Megalith Phaleg because it increases her ATK and that way you have a lot more negates to use. Speaking of LINK-4, the best option to finish games with this deck is Borrelsword Dragon and not Accesscode Talker. If you use the Herald of Orange Light in the deck, Cyber Angel Benten can make really cool interactions, for example, even getting you to play around Droll & Lock Bird, which is the best hand trap against Megalith and Ritual decks in general. Just in your first deck search do, for example, Ritual Summon Megalith Phul tribute Benten and do cl1 Benten Add Herald of Orange Light and cl2 Phul tgt Benten and add it to hand and that way when opening a new chain for your opponent to activate Droll & Lock Bird you can deny it with Orange Light. However, as there is only one Benten in the game, having it available in the starting hand without having to pick it up is a very small chance and this interaction will rarely happen. This same interaction can be given throughout the game with the Megalith Portal when you do the first Ritual Summon of the turn because your Megalith will activate effect being cl1 like Ophiel for example, Benten cl2 Add Orange Light and Megalith Portal cl3 Add Benten and that way you have protection from Droll & Lock Bird. After understanding the combos better, despite Megalith being quite complex, you can see that there are several cards in the deck that play the same role in the combos with few changes in the way of building plays and the only real brick of the deck is the Impcantation Candoll that neither it's so harmful if it comes in the hand as Manju/Diviner of the Herald can also add Impcantation Inception to the hand and even some hands can do Megalith Combo without needing the Impcantation engine because Level8 Megaliths can start their moves also. Thus, this is one of the most consistent Ritual decks in the game and, along with Drytron, the one that best interacts with the opponent during both turns. Certainly a fantastic deck, don't expect Konami to release something similar in the game, because it makes no sense to leave aside the Ritual Spell to make Ritual Summon, which is the great advantage that Megalith presents. //////////////////////////////////////////////// //// Disregard the Side Deck, they are just card options that you can test in the deck or that is very common to see Megalith players using. Curious about the Megalith deck in Master Duel is that you can practically play it with full power in the ONLY N/R format, which makes this certainly the best deck in this format because of how powerful it can be compared to other decks. You don't have Chalislime and Benten for example but there are still a lot of good combos left to do.

deck_excerpt: Toadally Awesome, Herald of the Arc Light and strong Paleozoic plays
deck_description: This is the first prototype of a paleozoic deck including one or more synchro plays. Don't take the lists too seriously, it's just a skeleton. As a paleozoic frog player I think that one of the biggest problem of the deck is that we can't always end our board with Toadally Awesome. Toadally Awesome is a strong card that gives us an omni-negate that could stop strong combo piecies of the opponent or just protects our board or more importantly here our backrow. Cards like Absolute King Back Jack and Rise to Full Height already help a lot against s/t removals, but we aren't always be able to recover. I think that Herald of the Arc Light could help the deck offering the same Toadally Awesome's protection. The key card behind this idea is Hop Ear Squadron. It can special summon itself from hand targeting a monster on our field during the opponent main phase and after that synchro summoning using it an the targeted monster. The plan is to put on board a paleozoic trap monster(really easy to do in the paleo rise/mill build) then during your opponent main phase summon  Herald of the Arc Light. Melffy Catty is here in order to search Hop Ear Squadron and it's also a level 2 body for xyz summons. As I said earlier, this is only a list to show the idea or the deck. In the side I put some techs I'll test. I think I'll cut the frog engine. Put suggestions in the comments and stay tuned for next updated builds!
Work in progress.

deck_excerpt: Attack on your opponent's turn and float forever with high-level Archfiends!
deck_description:
Hey everyone! Archfiend Guy here, bringing you all the Archfiend deck that I reached Platinum level with in Master Duel! If you are interested in an in-depth video of the deck, which breaks down the deck profile and related combos, then you can watch my deck profile video Deck style: Beatdown (Mid Range) Important Concepts:
  • Potential vs True monster count
    • Archfiends float 1 or 2 at a time rather than spam multiple monsters. Because of this, your true monster count (what your opponent sees on your side of the field) is not reflective of your potential monster count (the number of monsters you have the potential to summon on any given turn). This makes it hard for your opponent to identify when they can push for game, as the number of monsters you can summon can be anywhere from 2 to 10+! Accesscode Talker usually cannot break through an Archfiend defence and it's important to tell you this before anything else as it is the main mechanic of Archfiends.
Description: The main focus of Archfiends is to summon high attack monsters to beat over your opponent's monsters to win the game. They have the unique gimmick of being able to attack during your opponent's turn by using Dark Spirit of Banishment. Due to their high attack power, they usually have enough strength to attack over most monsters in the game. Additionally, Archfiends float very well thanks to their boss monster, Archfiend Empress. This monster, upon destruction, can summon any level 6 or high fiend from your GY to your side of the field. This effect is not once per turn! This means you can revive Archfiends multiple times in a single turn, so long as you keep reviving Archfiend Empress, which is easy to do with the Dark Spirit monsters, and Call of the Archfiend. Archfiends also have access to Berserk Dragon, a 3500 ATK level 8 Zombie that can attack every monster your opponent controls! Its summoning Quickplay spell card, A Deal with Dark Ruler, is an Archfiend card, so is searchable through Archfiend Heiress. Thanks to Archfiend Emperor's ability and our link monster, Masterking Archfiend, Berserk Dragon is live often and has great OTK potential. Archfiends also have the fusion monster, Archfiend's Manifestation, which is a 3k beater that can float into Summoned Skull. Archfiends don't activate many effects on the field. Instead, they revive from the GY through the Dark Spirit monsters activating in the hand, or via Call of the Archfiend. They are mainly big beatsticks that build tall, not wide. This means that you tend to only have around 1 or 2 monsters on the field at any given time, and because of this, you can run powerful floodgates such as Skill Drain, Gozen match, Summon Limit and Mystic Mine. Generally, you want to grind out the game and win through attrition, similar to Unchained. Once your opponent has exhausted their resources trying to break through your wall of Archfiends, you can safely attack for game. Conversely, you can also OTK using Berserk Dragon or the Numeron Dragon OTK. The "goto" strategy every game: Your priorities should be focused on putting at least two level 8 fiends into the GY, one of which being Archfiend Empress, and putting both Dark Spirit of Banishment and Dark Spirit of Malice into your hand. Once you have this setup established, you can efficiently float through several means of destruction. Furthermore, once your Archfiends die through a card effect, your Dark Spirits will recycle themselves back into your hand, which allows you to float consistently every turn. An ideal game state is to have both Dark Spirits in hand, with Cherubini on the field alongside Archfiend's Manifestation and Archfiend Empress. Cherubini protects both from destruction and Archfiend Empress can also protect Manifestation by banishing dark monsters from the GY.
Potential Combos
Tour Guide and Scarm in hand Summon Tour Guide and Special Summon Fiendish Rhino Warrior from the deck. Then overlay into Dante, detach Tour Guide and mill three with his effect. Resolve any extra effects. Overlay Dante into Beatrice by discarding Scarm. During the End Phase, use Scarm to search for Dark Spirit of Malice. On your opponent's turn, use Beatrice to detach Rhino Warrior, send Dark Spirit of Banishment first, then Archfiend Empress/Curse Necrofear second. Add Dark Spirit of Banishment into your hand. Or, if you like, search Dark Spirit of Banishment off of Scarm instead, and dump Archfiend Empress + Curse Necrofear second.
Void Apocalypse, Archfiend's Oath, Archfiend Empress, Frightfur Patchwork and Fiendish Rhino Warrior in hand Activate Frightfur Patchwork to search Edge Imp Sabres and Polymerization. Activate Void Apocalypse and discard Edge Imp Sabres, then send Dark Spirit of Banishment. Activate Edge Imp Sabres and return Archfiend Empress to your deck. Activate Archfiend's Oath and call Archfiend Empress to return her to the hand. Normal Summon Fiendish Rhino Warrior and link both into Cherubini. Activate Rhino Warrior's effect to send Archfiend Heiress. Search for Summoned Skull. Activate Cherubini to send Scarm. Activate Polymerization to summon Archfiend's Manifestation. Similarly, you can use Oath to call the incorrect card to mill Empress, depending on your circumstances, which will return Dark Spirit of Banishment to your hand.
Polymerization + 3 monsters in hand Use Polymerization to summon Trishula, the Dragon of Icy Imprisonment. Depending on the fusion materials, you will now be able to resolve a number of effects. Archfiend Heiress can search for whatever you need, Rhino Warrior can mill monsters, etc.
Instant Fusion, Frightfur Patchwork, Plaguespreader Zombie and Summoned Skull in hand Activate Instant Fusion to summon Theseus. Normal summon Edge Imp Sabres and Synchro Summon Chaos Ruler. Excavate 5 and add a monster if you wish, mill the rest. Activate Polymerization sending Summoned Skull and Plaguespreader to summon Archfiend's Manifestation. Activate Plaguespreader Zombie's effect to summon itself and Synchro Summon Beelze using it and Manifestation. Depending on what you excavated, you can also set your GY up with level 8 Archfiends, as well as putting Dark Spirits into your hand.
Tour Guide, Frightfur Patchwork + 3 monsters Summon Tour Guide and summon a Dark Spirit. Link into Cherubini and use its effect to send Fiendish Rhino Warrior. Fiendish Rhino Warrior to send Curse Necrofear or similar. Return the Dark Spirit to your hand. Activate Polymerization using (e.g.) Heiress, Empress and something else as material to summon Trishula. Use Heiress to search for whatever you need (e.g. Call of the Archfiend)
Instant Fusion, Edge Imp Sabres, Void Apocalypse in hand Activate Instant Fusion to summon Theseus. Normal summon Edge Imp Sabres and Synchro Summon Chaos Ruler (add Tour Guide and mill a Rhino Warrior). Rhino Warrior to send a Dark Spirit. Activate Void Apocalypse to discard (e.g. your other Dark Spirit) and send a level 8 fiend to the graveyard. Return both Dark Spirits to your hand.
Both Dark Spirits, Plaguespreader Zombie, Edge Imp Sabres in graveyard, Archfiend's Oath and a level 8 fiend in hand. Activate Edge Imp Sabres to return the level 8 fiend on top of your deck. Activate Archfiend's Oath and call the wrong card, milling that level 8 fiend. Return both Dark Spirits to your hand. Summon Plaguespreader by putting one back, then Normal Summon the other Dark Spirit. Synchro Summon into Beelze, Scarlight or similar.
Tour Guide in hand Summon Tour Guide and summon a Dark Spirit. Link both off into Cherubini and send Fiendish Rhino Warrior. Use Rhino Warrior to send a level 8 fiend. Return the Dark Spirit to your hand.
Archfiend Emperor and A Deal with Dark Ruler in hand, one other Archfiend card in hand or GY Normal Summon Archfiend Emperor and use his effect to destroy himself. Return any Dark Spirits that might be in your GY. Activate A Deal with Dark Ruler to summon Berserk Dragon from your hand or deck. Attack everything
Hope this helps, everyone! This deck is TCG legal, so not exclusive to Master Duel. Float forever. Archfiends never die!

deck_name: MLDR(Mirror Force Lair of darkness Rainbow Neos)
deck_excerpt: One of the first deck i created it's a realy fun and enjoyable deck.
deck_description:
One of the first deck i created i named it MLDR(Mirror Force Lair of darkness Rainbow Neos). The strategy is simple basicaly you use Mirror force to defend your self, Lair of darkness as a way to tribute opponent monster and break board and Rainbow neos to clear monsters, S/T or GW.

The starters :

  • Tour Guide From the Underworld (special summon one of your fiend monster to go into extra deck plays)
  • Sangan (can be used to searsh one of your monsters)
  • Lilith, Lady of Lament (can be used as a disruption went there is Lair of Darkness in the field and set a trap)
  • Ahrima, the Wicked Warden (can be used to searsh the Lair of Darkness also have a usefull effect that can draw of searsh a dark monster)

The extenders :

  • Alice, Lady of Lament (she is very usefull if you have other Lady of Lament in the GW and she can used to go for link play but special summoning her self)
  • Lord of the Heavenly Prison (he can protect backrow from destruction and can special summon himself also alow you to set a S/T)
  • Neos Fusion (if you draw if it can be used as a was to finish us play and go for game)
  • Nine-Tailed Fox (realy usefull in the grid game as a way to alwass have a way to tribute opponent monsters)

The boss :

  • Darkest Diabolos, Lord of the Lair (can special summon it self went a dark monster is tribute on your field, have a decent attack)
  • Rainbow Neos (can clear the board and help you otk)
  • Mirror Force Dragon (realy cool can protect you for some turn)

Board breaking :

  • Super Polymerization (realy usefull if you opponent have a set up board with negate also can serve as disruption going first)
  • Rainbow Neos (can clear the board and help you otk)
  • Predaplant Verte Anaconda (to go into Rainbow Neos or Super Polymerization also can change an opponent monster to dark that help you if you dont have Lair of Darkness)

Disruption :

  • Super Polymerization (if you opponent play dark monster or if you have Lair of Darkness can fuse you opponents monsters)
  • Number 3: Cicada King (can negate a monster effect on the field also gain some defence usefull for going first)
  • Eradicator Epidemic Virus/Crush Card Virus (can tribute an opponent monster while there is Lair of Darkness also can help you get information of the hand)
  • Lilith, Lady of Lament (can tribute an opponent monster while there is Lair of Darkness as a quick effect also set a trap)
  • Malice, Lady of Lament (can tribute an opponent monster while there is Lair of Darkness as a quick effect also can set a trap from banich or GW, but be carefull you need to have a trap in ether the GW or the banich to activate the first effect)
  • Predaplant Triphyoverutum (can sometime come with Super Polymerization can negate the summon of a monster from the extra deck)

The combos :

Tour Guide From the Underworld Going First Combo :
  1. Normal summon Tour Guide From the Underworld
  2. Special summon Any level 3 fiend monster
  3. Xys summon into Number 3: Cicada King
Tour Guide From the Underworld / Any 2 effect monsters Going Segond Combo :
  1. Normal summon Tour Guide From the Underworld
  2. Special summon Sangan
  3. Add 1 monster with 1500 or less ATK from your Deck to your hand
  4. Special summon Predaplant Verte Anaconda
  5. Go into ether a Rainbow Neos or copy Super Polymerization to break your opponent board
Sangan Simple searsh a monster combo :
  1. Normal summon Sangan
  2. Go into Salamangreat Almiraj
  3. Add 1 monster with 1500 or less ATK from your Deck to your hand

   Weakness :

  • The deck can struggle in the grind game
  • Harpie's Feather Duster and S/T in general can put you in a bad sitiation specialy if they get rid of Lair of Darkness
  • Hand trap can stop you easily

  Strength :

  • Thanks to Super Polymerization and Lair of Darkness you can out most of the boss monster
  • Most of the time you dont summon that much so poeple cant Nibiru you most of the time
  • Lair of Darkness can work as a floodgate
Thank you for reading this if u enjoy drop a like dont hesitate to comment.

deck_excerpt: Recommend this deck to beginner and intermediate player. Not an OP deck, but has consistency and be able to adopt many situations. Full-power board at
deck_description:
What you have to do with this deck is tryna get Numeron Network in the first turn, the chance is pretty high as you have 3 Numeron Network, 3 Planet Pathfinder, 1 Terraforming which easily help you get the field spell in the 1st turn. There's also 3 Numeron Wall, help you get the card into your hand if you didn't get it on your 1st turn, also help you negate the attacks from the opponents(don't worry if you didn't get them on your 1st turn, the other cards in the deck are Red-Eyes Insight, Red-Eyes Fusion, other negate and Eldlich traps will help you survive the 1st turn) Once you have Numeron Network on your hand, Xyz summon 4 Numeron Gates(try to OTK your opponent first if you can attack), Sp.Summon a link monster. I prefer Saryuja Skull Dread, as it is the best link monster if you arre going first and he will give you a good hand(draw 4, shuffle 3 into the deck). Then do the following things, depends on what you draw:
  • Negate traps : set it on your field, end turn, tryna use them reasonably
  • Eldlich traps : set it on your field. Use them to Sp.Summon Eldlich the Golden Lord. If you still survive, you can keep Huaquero of the Golden Land and Conquistador of the Golden Land face-down, flip it at the opponent's end phase to get 2 level 5 material for Constellar Pleiades
  • Red-Eyes Insight : Send Red-Eyes Wyvern to the GY to get Red-Eyes Fusion. In case your Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon die, Red-Eyes Wyvern will banish himself to send Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon back to the field.
Turn 2 : Congrats on surviving the 1st turn. Now if you have both Huaquero of the Golden Land and Conquistador of the Golden Land on the field. Sp.Summon Constellar Pleiades from the extra deck. Now you have 1 more powerful monster on the field. But this also mean, you can't use Red-Eyes Fusion on that turn(if you have the card on the hand), as the card doesn't allow you to Sp.Summon or Normal Summon the same turn that the spell is activated, you have to leave it until turn 3. But you can use materials on the field, for Predaplant Verte Anaconda. At this point Saryuja Skull Dread's second effect maybe useful if he is still alive, use him and another sp.summoned monster by his effect to call out Predaplant Verte Anaconda, then Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon Super Polymertization is for removing 1 opponent's boss monster at least to get Starving Venom Fusion Dragon, using Predaplant Verte Anaconda's effect or the spell itself. Your most powerful board will have : 1 Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon, 1 Constellar Pleiades, 1 Starving Venom Fusion Dragon, 1 Predaplant Verte Anaconda(now he's wasted), some Eldlich and the boys.  Time to counter attack and smash your opponent, it will be hard for them to fight again this. The deck may not be the strongest deck. But the monsters are one of the coolest in the game, and I've been YGO-chilling with this deck for a few days and feel sooooo great and satisfying. You can also choose other cards in the side deck and replace them into the main deck, depends on your dueling style. Also help me improve this deck, as this is the first time of mine making a deck and it is needed to be improved. I appreciate all of your recommendation. Enjoy the game Duelists. GET YOUR GAME ON! P/S : I forgot to said that Eldlich cards can help you destroy or banish card on either field. Now that's another tool of card destruction. Read the card texts to know about these effects.

deck_excerpt: Another Ogdoadic Deck. The Sneks are cool, alright?! We can't all run Swordsoul and Floowandereeze!
deck_description: The second variation of the Chaos Ogdoadic deck I made previously. This time, the deck contains a sort of Hieratic engine, only to promote tributes and special summons. This way, it is much easier to focus on searching Dragons (i.e. Levianeer) and going full combo without getting severely punished. It is also much easier to make an I:P Masquerena along with a Hieratic Seal of the Heavenly Spheres, because bouncing a card and getting an Apollousa on your opponent's turn seems pretty promising. The deck was also made this way to absorb impact from hand traps (i.e. D.D. Crow and Ash Blossom) while not being COMPLETELY all gas. Don't count your snakes out, either. Snake Rain + Water Lily is still a promising combo in this deck, as doing so turn 1 will leave more opportunities open (i.e. search Serpent Strike instead of 2nd Water Lily) to make a Hope Harbinger and Hyperyton.

deck_excerpt: Variation Three of my Ogdoadic Treasures...More refined, less bricky, and less diluted as well. Please comment on your favorite out of the three, and
deck_description: The third and possibly final variation of the Chaos Ogdoadic deck I made. The deck is tightly packed and more refined, but it doesn't have as much combo potential as the other two variants. It has the XYZ OTK engine in there, even though that is nothing special at this point. Also, less engine space means more room for hand traps. This way, it is much easier to focus on reptile control, but still not being completely punished by your opponent for trying to play the game. It is still easy to make a good enough board, and possibly a Hieratic Seal of the Heavenly Spheres, because, well, who doesn't want card bounce? The deck was also made this way to filter though the most prevalent engines while still not being COMPLETELY all gas. Your SYnchros really put in the work here, and can even be used for your XYZ and links once they fulfill their purpose. This is just a test, however, and personally, I think this is the second-best out of the three (I like Dangers, alright?). I might go with the Brave Token engine in the future, but for now I am focusing on Chaos Dragons.

This deck has all the cards that he used in Duelist Kingdom But to make a 40 card deck we have add cards we think he would of had. We hope you like it. and don't forget that the ban list doesn't apply.

Check out our YouTube Channel for more. JollieScarecrows
