deck_excerpt: Platinum rank consistent deck with friendly advices and gameplay video.
deck_description:
Live☆Twin/Evil★Twin is a waifus deck with great field control, with a destruction of any card on the field or draw per turn; you'll generally want to go first and have your boss monster on the opponent's turn thanks to the effect of I:P Masquerena. There are a lot of cards you can take into account when building your deck, making the archetype really flexible, focus on link summons and keep in mind the support of their Magic/Trap cards. Your Boss Monster in this build will be Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax, so you want to get him on the field as soon as possible, summoned with I:P Masquerena of course. Summoned this way Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax: It will be immune to destruction by effect, cannot be selected and the opponent cannot select another monster for an attack other than this one, plus if it fights with a special summoned card it will gain as much attack as that monster's attack during that damage calculation, which makes it your biggest attack/defense and a big headache for your opponent; Remember that it can still be banished or returned to the hand with effects that do not select or sacrificed by Kaijus monsters, in which case its effect will be triggered and you will be able to return to the deck a card if it was sent to the graveyard. Here some starting combos, tips on how to start yours plays: Important notes:

- Don't activate the effects of Evil★Twin Link monsters (this turn you can only summon Fiends Monsters from the extra deck) until you have summoned I:P Masquerena or you will have ruined the combo. - You can search from the deck "Live☆Twin Sunny's Snitch" with the effect of "Secret Password", which adds you a Live☆Twin monster when activated. - If your opponent denies you the effect of your Cyberse-type Live☆Twin remember that their Non-Cyberse-type versions can be special summoned if her twin is on the field.

Starting hand: 
  1. A Cyberse-type Live☆Twin card + Parallel eXceed: Cyberse-type Live☆Twin Normal Summon -> Non-Cyberse-type Live☆Twin Special Summon (they have effects that can be activated from the graveyard) -> Evil★Twin Ki-sikil Link Summon -> Parallel eXceed effect activated, Special Summon it and activate its effect again -> Parallel eXceed Special Summon from the deck -> I:P Masquerena Link Summon (Using both Parallel eXceed) -> Evil★Twin Ki-sikil effect , summon a Lil-la from the graveyard -> Evil★Twin Lil-la Link Summon (Using Evil★Twin Ki-sikil and your Lil-la monster) -> Evil★Twin Lil-la effect activated, Special Summon Evil★Twin Ki-sikil from the graveyard - > Evil★Twin Ki-sikil effect activated, Draw a card -> Turn end -> Opponent's turn Main Phase 1, Summon Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax using I:P Masquerena and Evil★Twin Lil-la -> now you can activate Evil★Twin Ki-sikil's effect, revive Evil★Twin Lil-la, and destroy a card with her effect.
  2. A Cyberse-type Live☆Twin card + A Non-Cyberse-type Live☆Twin card: Cyberse-type Live☆Twin Normal Summon -> Cyberse-type Live☆Twin Special Summon from the deck -> Non-Cyberse-type Live☆Twin Special Summon from the hand -> "Link Disciple" Link Summon -> "Link Devotee" Link Summon -> "Link Disciple" effect activated, tribute "Link Devotee" -> Draw a card and return one to the deck -> "Link Devotee" effect activated, summon two "Link Token" -> I:P Masquerena Link Summon (Using both Link Token) -> Evil★Twin Ki-sikil Link Summon -> Evil★Twin Ki-sikil effect , summon a Lil-la from the graveyard -> Evil★Twin Lil-la Link Summon (Using Evil★Twin Ki- sikil and your Lil-la monster) -> Evil★Twin Lil-la effect activated, Special Summon Evil★Twin Ki-sikil from the graveyard -> Evil★Twin Ki-sikil effect activated, Draw a card -> Turn end -> Opponent's turn Main Phase 1, Summon Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax using I:P Masquerena and Evil★Twin Lil-la -> now you can activate Evil★Twin Ki-sikil's effect, revive Evil★Twin Lil-la, and destroy a card with her effect.

More combos in the video...

Some tips: - You can steal an opponent's monster on their turn with the effect of I:P Masquerena to Summon Underworld Goddess of the Closed World. - Evil★Twin GG EZ is a great card that can negate destruction, sending one of your Evil★Twin to the graveyard, which is perfect since you can bring it back to the field and trigger its effects. - You can carry a copy or not of "Evil★Twins Ki-sikil & Lil-la", it's not essential, but keep in mind that it's a great come-back, it's Special Summoned from the graveyard so you can discard it to pay any effect.

deck_excerpt: Dinos are still good, trust me.
deck_description: Dinosaur went from being a going-second aggro-combo OTK deck to a going-first combo deck that sets up a respectable number of negates and interaction after the release of Pot of Prosperity. With the limiting of Miscellaneousaurus, the deck lost a lot of its overwhelming consistency, but lost absolutely none of its explosivity. The "Scrap" package of 2 Scrap Raptor (a Dinosaur monster, which can be summoned off of Babycerasaurus) and 1 Scrap Chimera allows for a turn-1 3-material Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess, a 2-negate Borelload Savage Dragon, and a PSY-Framelord Omega to simultaneously recycle your Misc into the GY to allow for follow-up on turn 3 and ripping a card from your opponent's hand for a turn, allows for great turn-1 set-ups and keeping your opponent off-kilter for long enough to get back to your turn, and go in for the kill. Plus, you still get to summon your Ultimate Conductor Tyranno in the midst of all of this combo goodness! The deck is incredibly powerful, albeit quite expensive, and a little bricky for the current format. Still, it's a great choice for people who think their fellow duelists aren't ready for the power of DINO DNA, BABY!

deck_excerpt: "Salamangreat"... Once a naughty word, and the boogeyman of Yu-Gi-Oh!, now a decent budget deck for locals.
deck_description: Salamangreat is a classic from 2019's so-called "Eternal Format". Once feared and loathed by much of the competitive landscape, after several nerfs and not being able to keep up with 17-negate boards, it fell far out of favor. It's still a fine rogue pick for your locals, though, and fairly inexpensive. The loss of 2 Pot of Desires hurt the deck's card advantage quite a lot, but an additional copy Salamangreat Circle is an incredible boon for the deck. The compact engine allows the deck to play a robust hand trap package, and the particular hand traps you want to play in the main deck can be tailored for your local meta. Salamangreat has the ability to put up a fight through the long game by constantly recycling interruptions and keeping the hand traps coming out off the top of the deck, threatening to grind out any deck not prepared to play a turn 3 or 4. Plus, since every monster in the deck (that you want to summon, anyway) is Cyberse, you can comfortably play under a floodgate like Rivalry of Warlords and still easily assemble lethal with a double-attacking, 5300 ATK Accesscode Talker courtesy of Transcode Talker bringing back your Update Jammer. Overall, this deck is a great budget option for the locals player who just wants to get out there and jam some games. Give it a shot, and surely you'll love it.

deck_excerpt: E-Tele at three means Galatea without a normal summon :)  Halq is a good link
deck_description:
Your goal is to end with a DPE + Babel minimum on board + Dingirsu in the GY. Standard full combo endboard is DPE + Babel + set Scythe + PUNK trap. Opening E-Tele is full combo. Opening Girsu or Scrap Recycler is standard board. Opening E-Tele+ MKPurple/Girsu/Recycler is full combo that plays through Nibiru. For full combo (E-Tele+MKPurple/Girsu/Recycler+3 random cards):
  • E-Tele -> PUNK Ze-Amin -> search Foxy Tune
  • Foxy Tune ditches itself and a card (ideally Orcust Knightmare/World Wand/Cymbal Skeleton) -> Madame Spider -> search PUNK trap
  • Spider + Amin = Crystron Halq->Halq summons Orcust Brass Bombard
  • If MKPurple in hand
    • Summon MKPurple under Halq after setting PUNK trap in same column
      • (we're trying to avoid normal summoning to force out Nibiru)
      • THIS IS OUR FIFTH SUMMON. If we do not have MKPurple, Galatea is our fifth summon.
  • If Girsu or Recycler in hand
    • Hold in hand on proceed to:
  • Halq + Bombard = Galatea (Current board is set PUNK trap & Galatea, maybe MKPurple)
  • Normal Summon Girsu/Recycler -> send Orcust Knightmare/World Wand/Cymbal Skeleton (in that priority order)
  • Girsu/Recycler+Galatea = Artifact Dagda (if you have a way to trigger Dagda, one of the following)
    • A spell (E-Tele/Babel/Foolish Burial/Fusion Destiny)
    • Extender (E-Tele/Psychic Wheelder[summon with the PUNKs]/Orcust to special with Bombard)
      • Assuming you have an extender for this example
  • Knightmare(GY) -> World Wand to GY
  • World Wand to GY summon Knightmare(banished)
  • Summon [extender]
  • Knightmare + [extender] = Galatea(ED2)
  • Galatea -> shuffle back dark machine & get Babel
    • Chain Dagda -> set Scythe
  • Galatea = Dingirsu overlay
  • Dingirsu + Dagda = Predaplant Verte
  • Verte -> Fusion Destiny (& materials)
  • End board:
    • FIELD: Babel, DPE, Verte, set Scythe, PUNK trap
    • 2 random cards still in hand
If you didn't have a way to activate Dagda, you can make I:P instead to Unicorn on their turn. Compared to current common Orcust endboards, this isn't much fancier aside from having one more monster negate (PUNK trap) and Scythe lock possibly. The benefit of this build is that the Halq combo attracts the Ash, Imperm, and Nib before you have to Normal Summon (assuming you open E-Tele). Common 40-card Orcust builds play 6 starters to get to Galatea (Girsu, Recycler) This 51-card build plays 12 starters (Girsu, Recycler, E-Tele, Ze Amin) + letting you play around interruptions.

deck_excerpt: The third variant for Buster Blader featuring Rokket & Crusadia archetypes. This will be the last build I'll be exploring for Buster Blader. For ful
deck_description: This is the third and last variant I'll be exploring for Buster Blader. Playing this deck, I believe that dropping Formula Synchron & Satellite Warrior for Hot Red Dragon Archfiend Abyss & Crusadia Magius would be way more beneficial for Borreload Savage Dragon since you'll be sending Crystron Halqifibrax to the grave. Having Protector Whelp of the Destruction Swordsman on the field would help in case you can't attack with Buster Blader, the Dragon Destroyer Swordsman. You can use Protector Whelp of the Destruction Swordsman to burn you opponent for Buster Blader, the Dragon Destroyer Swordsman's attack points. Plus, having an extra negate with Hot Red Dragon Archfiend Abyss feels way better. The reason why we need a 2nd copy of Crusadia Magius is in case the 1st gets destroyed. As usual, even with the previous builds, we utilize Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax with the protection of I:P Masquerena for going 2nd, to stall and to beat over and all special summoned monsters.  https://youtu.be/9qq6DrxCONQ

deck_description:
Get Oppressed People, People Running About and United Resistance on the field by:
  • Summoner Monk > Dark Doriado > Enchanting Fitting Room
  • Treasure Panda
  • Tri-Wight (summon normal monsters in the grave that were used for link summoning or White Elephant's Gift)

Activate Huge Revolution (during your main phase) or Fuh-Rin-Ka-Zan (if you also have an earth monster) Use Trap Trick to set HR for your next turn or Storming Mirror Force if you need to stall. Side Deck: cards that let you draw, link 1 monsters (send normal monsters to the grave) and cards that let you activate a trap card on your turn. Example Duels: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLme-UEOUq2NlWb7tWa53StX1x6J8CnM8a

Use the Gravekeeper's engine to run out your Supernaturalist with your other cards while you set up your 3 tombs to summon the Pharaoh. This deck is very fun to play and can hang pretty well with Non-Meta contenders, but this deck cannot hang with Meta decks.

deck_excerpt: This is an updated dinosaur deck for the March 2022 format.
deck_description: This deck is very consistent because it can easily utilize cards like Small World and Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer. Your main 2-card combo is Souleating Oviraptor and Babycerasaurus which if played correclty, can end on DPE, Verte, and UCT. This deck also utilizes cards like Fossil Dig and Small World to easily search your starters and extenders. Overall, I think that the deck is very consistent and can compete with the current meta if played correctly.

deck_excerpt: This is my updated Swordsoul Tenyi build for the March 2022 format.
deck_description: Your main end board is Chixiao + Baronne/Qixing Longyuan and a couple other cards depending on what cards you open. You can also try and go for the Draco Berserker OTK if you are going second. Most of the time, you want to open cards like Mo Ye, Longyuan, and Ecclesia to get your combo going. Cards like Emergence and Vessel provide you with a consistent way to search your monsters from your deck, allowing you easy access to both your starters and extenders. 1/4 of your deck (10 Cards) is composed of handtraps, which means that even on your opponent's turn, you can still negate your opponent's card effects and stop your opponent's plays. Overall, I think that the deck is very consistent and fun to play, so I highly recommend that you try it out for yourself.

deck_excerpt: Remember Gouki Extra Link? Who needs warriors when you have Cyberse?
deck_description: "Code Talker" This is an archetype that is rarely looked at and thought of as an archetype. Most people know our friends, Decode Talker and Accesscode Talker, who are members, but no one really knows the mountains of direct and incidental support this archetype has received over the years. Obviously Decode Talker is no longer the powerhouse he was in Master Rule 4, being the best generic Link monster to give yourself two more zones for Extra Deck monsters, but Accesscode has become the de facto boss monster for any deck playing Link monsters these days. Painfully generic and able to break boards and OTK like no one's business. But what if I told you there were more "Code Talker" monsters, and that they can be used to Extra Link, just like back in the good old Gouki days, only with fewer bricks in deck. I can't describe the entire combo line, nor can I commentate on the sheer number of extenders the deck has access to, but DistantCoder, the Code Talker master, has been honing this deck for a couple years now, and he has a couple videos, which I will link here (deck profile) and here (combo tutorials). However, these are for an older build. The new build, posted below, can now make a triple co-linked Tri-Gate Wizard and a Linguriboh for extra protection, and I'll post a video of my own from DuelingBook to illustrate the new combo line here. One thing that is worth noting, though: Small World is incredible in this deck. Since all monsters are Cyberse, but they all have different levels, stats, and attributes, you can go from any monster in hand to any monster in the deck. It's simply a great card that allows even the brickiest of hands (of which there are truthfully very few) to reach full combo and lock the opponent out.

deck_excerpt: You have options vs a multitude of decks, but be careful about going all out when you see cards like skill drain, although the deck is strong if you c
deck_description: Your main goal is to get Red Supernova Dragon out. You accomplish this by using your chain resonator along with a Lv4 fiend monster. if you Have a synkron resonator in your hand or a way to get one after using you chain resonator then you are golden just hold it in your hand for now.. You can use your chain resonator along with your fiend type you can summon tour red rising dragon, then you use its effect to bring back your chain resonator. activate your chain resonators effect and summon one red resonator and one synkron resonator. You then want to use your red rising dragon along with your chain resonator to summon out your chaos ruler. Use his effect if you want to. then you can now summon the synkron resonator from your hand or use your synkron spell cards to get one. once that last synkron resonator is on the field you can use your chaos ruler and the remaining synkron cards to summon, Red Supernova Dragon.

deck_excerpt: Broken Meta Dinosaur Deck. Synchro players and link players are shaking 'cuz Ultimate Conductor Tyranno is hunting.
deck_description: If you want to play Dinosaurs I think that this is the best way possible for them to be played. I'll go card by card and explain why is it in a deck 'cuz why not explain maybe newer players why is something like it is and also explain to other real players why I think it is the best choice to be like this.  First we got Main Deck:  2x Animadorned Archosaur-You do not want to draw this card most of the times, but it still can be a start of your combo in this deck with Babycerasaurus in your hand since it does trigger Babycerasaurus and also adds to your hand Double Evolution Pill but mostly, you want to get it from Miscellaneosaurus to your field after you use Miscellaneosaurus's hand effect that sends Misc to the graveyard and protects 90% of your deck from hand traps and then gives you ability to summon your Archosaur from Misc's effect.  1x Artifact Scythe-it stops most of the decks from playing the game, and in this deck, it doesn't have to be a brick in the hand 'cuz most of the times you do not want to go for Dagda+Anaconda 'cuz it takes away to much of your combo materials and stops any other plays you could've done instead of those two, so if you draw Scythe and you are not unlucky like me to draw: Scythe, Celestial, Dasher 1/3 duels (around once per match) then you should get to a good combo even if you draw scythe.  3x Babycerasaurus-you drew this and Archo, go for Double Evolution and Souleating Oviraptor, you summoned token through Lost World to your opponent's field and used Token Collector effect, you get a free Baby effect. This card is not once per turn and in this deck except this two ways you will most likely easily get to this card through Misc, Ovi, you will gain effect of it through Archo, Fossil Dig can give it to you, Lost World can trigger it with Token Collector in duo and that in the deck is alredy 30% of the cards that can give you advantage of this card that is not a once per turn card, which means it can be used with it's effect multiple times per turn so it being at three and adding 37.5% of drawing it on top of all of abilitys to tribute it and trigger it is incredibly powerful in this deck.  1x Destiny HERO - Celestial-part of the DPE engine that is also a +2 in every deck that uses DPE engine  1x Destiny HERO - Dasher-part of DPE engine which also gives you free special summon on your draw phase and is mostly used for Celestial's draw effect.  1x Dinowrestler Pankratops-this card is a one time Zoodiac Drident, it is a good going second card, but is also a good going first card since it can be summoned with the effect of petiteranodon.  1x Dogoran, the Mad Flame Kaiju-classic Kaiju, following the type since it can, good going second interuption with opponent's monsters like DPE, Dragoon (yes, I am seeing some Dragoons), Prank-Kids Battle Buttler etc.  1x Giant Rex-sometimes you will decide that you are on your period and that you want Laggia or Dolkka on your field after summoning the all mighty Ultimate Conductor Tyranno so when you banish this card with Double Evouliton Pill or for Ultimate Conductor Tyranno summoning condition it is automaticaly summoned to your field, and since sometimes you will have 1 Oviraptor on your field which is also level 4, this card is perfect for xyz summoning. It can also make Exciton Knight, Abyss Dweler or Dugares, which can with it's draw effect dig even more through your deck.  1x Miscellaneosaurus-first of all, it can be searched with something like Oviraptor. Now when you have it you can use it's hand effect to make your dinosaur effects unafected by any of your opponent's hand traps and effects which is perfect 'cuz then your opponent is not able to ever again interupt you during that turn. This card is also limited, otherwise if it was not and was unlimited like in the past, it would be played at 3.  1x Petiteranodon-if you use your Babycerasaurus's effect to summon this little guy and you tribute it on your opponent's turn with your Ultimate Conductor Tyranno, you get a free Pankratops that is one time Drident. Most of the times you do not want to draw it and want it on the field with Babycerasaurus's effect.  3x PSY-Framegear Gamma-if you are going second, this card is like one time impermanence, and if you are going first and your opponent uses something like ash blossom on your fossil dig or Engage or Terraforming, you can after negate also go into Framelord Omega which is like an upgraded version of zoodiac Drident which is curently banned.  Souleating Oviraptor-this is 1 of few starters you have, it searches your Misc, Misc triggers and summons Archo, Archo gives you Double Evolution and maybe triggers Baby, or if you are half unlucky Petiteranodon, then Oviraptor activates and get's rid of your Archo and gets back hopefuly Baby and on and on and on with all other combos.  1x Token Collector-if you use Lost World to summon token for your opponent to their field and then trigger Collector, you get a free monster on the field and since Lost World protects the tokens, you can for free destroy Baby from your deck to get a free monster to your field, and if you did not draw Souleating you can get it of the Baby, which is a good 2 card combo that I think cannot be negated with anything else except for Ghost Ogre.  3x Ultimate Conductor Tyranno-boss monster+soft once per turn book of moon+attacks all monsters your opponent controls+prevents link summoning.  1x PSY-Frame Driver-without it Gamma is unable to activate, so you have to have at least 1 in the deck.  1x Called By the Grave-it can on your turn negate a hand trap that is a monster and goes to gy as a cost like ash or ghost ogre (so imperm can still go through it, also can PSY) and it on your opponent's turn can also negate some kind of a graveyard effect or if your opponent has a copy of a card in his graveyard and a copy of the same card on the field, you can negate the card on the field by banishing the copy in the gy.  2x Double Evolution Pill-this card is on 2 'cuz we play 2 searchers, also you do not want to draw this card, you want to search it 'cuz of destroying part of Archo so it can trigger Baby or Petiteranodon.  3x Fossil Dig-it searches any starter combo piece you need in this deck, so it is pretty welcome at 3.  2x Fusion Destiny-as much as you want to get to it through Anaconda, that much you will want it in your hand and you will need as much copys as possible to legaly be in your deck.  3x Lost World-it gives your monsters protection from some effects like Forbidden Chalice and also can be combined with Token Collector to go for free Baby effect that can for free give you Souleating that can give you misc that gives you protection and Archo that gives you double Evolution Pill that can summon Conductor and also you can go into Abyss or Exciton or link Souleating and Token Collector into anaconda and Archo into linkuriboh and with Anaconda get the DPE. In my opinion it is solid two card combo.  1x Sky Strike Mecha - Hornet Drones-in my opinion Sky Striker engine is still a good engine since it can itself give you Dagda: with Engage you add Drones, with Drones you get a token and go to Kagari that gives you back drones and summons 1 more token which is level 1 so you can go into linkuriboh and then go to Dagda and all of this with this little engine. And now with no Normal Summons you go further with Dinos and at the start you get Scythe seted and since you will most of the times go into Anaconda for DPE, you alredy gave yourself an ability to lock your opponent's extra deck.  1x Sky Striker Mobilize - Engage!-this card searches Hornet Drones and is the part of the Sky Striker engine  2x Small World-this card can literally search any card you want from your deck. There was not anymore place so it is on 2 and I think you will never see more than 2 except in 60 card decks.  1x Terraforming-is here to search Lost World and you alredy readed the combo.  Now for the Extra Deck:  1x Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer-it is a non-target destruction effect card that summons itself back in the next standby phase and is a part of DPE engine which is pretty powerful since it can be done over and over again every single turn and since you will mostly send Dasher and Celestial, both having a good effects so you can summon DPE, you will really be in plus with engine based around summoning this card.  1x PSY-Framelord Omega-it is a synchro version of DPE, just a little bit worse, but it instead of destroying (since some cards have good graveyard effects) it banishes from hand (which means your opponent would start with 1 less card).  1x Abyss Dweler-it stops Tenyi Swordsoul, Eldlich, Drytron comebacks, Tri-Brigade, DPE engine, Scythe engine...that is a lot of things that are in the current meta and only one card that is easy to summon can stop those from being what they are from 60% to 100%.  1x Evilswarm Exciton Knight-just a clean up after you seted everything with Tyranno's effect so you have a free attack into opponent's LP.  1x Evolzar Dolkka-negating a monster effect is pretty strong nowadays since most combos start with monsters and their effects and since this is not once per turn and the card has 2 materials, you can negate monster effect twice which can sometimes completely shut down whole combo.  1x Evolzar Laggia-this is 1 time walking Solemn Judgment (or the NO card) and Solemn Judgment itself is pretty powerful card, so negating a Normal Summon can, first be funny and second be really helpful. Negating a Golden Land/Eldlixir spell/trap is pretty good if playing against Eldlich, perfectly if you negate Eldlixir of Scarlet Sanguine that summons the Eldlich from the deck.  1x Gallant Granite-this searches Nibiru, if your opponent plays Prank Kids this is good and can be helpful in game two and three.  1x Number 60: Dugares and Timeless-this card's first effect is something you are looking for since it can make your combo longer sometimes if you of course draw the right cards.  1x Artifact Dagda-this puts Scythe on your field and after summoning DPE and resolving Scythe your opponent can just surrender, unless he is playing Altergeist or Eldlich or Dinosaurs that can get out of that situation and go into a fair respectfull board.  1x Dharc, the Dark Charmer, Gloomy-since Phantom Knight's are still a meta, it can take your opponent's Phantom Knight and make your combo a little bit longer, can give you Unicorn...  1x Knightmare Unicorn-it shuffles 1 card your opponent controls into the deck. Yes it targets but most of the cards are not unafected by targeting nowadays.  1x Linkuriboh-was always a good battle protection card and will always be a good battle protection card, and it can be also summoned with Archo as material.  1x Pentastag-you used Conductor's effect but you want to do more then 1000 damage, so if you summon this card that way that Tyranno is linked to it, you have a 3500 atk beatstick that can do piercing on every opponent's monster.  1x Predaplant Verte Anaconda-part of DPE engine.  1x Sky Striker Ace - Kagari-part of the Sky Striker engine  And now for the Side Deck:  3x Artifact Lancea-this stops Tenyi Swordsoul and Tri-Brigade decks, also stops Floowandereeze decks and it is that way good.  1x Nibiru, the Primal Being-is searchable, so you only need 1 if going first and you know your opponent plays something like Phantom Knight's or Prank-Kids, it is good to use this card on time.  2x Token Collector-in case opponent plays Swordsoul deck, this is a perfect card to stop that deck.  3x Twin Twisters-this card is good in this format since trap cards got some popularity and this card can destroy spell and trap cards, two of them, so Eldlich, Altergeist or something that plays traps is gone to this card most of the times.  3x Ice Dragon's Prison-mostly for Eldlich decks since Eldlich players for some reason play only two Eldliches, instead of 3 (dumb move Eldlich Players), you can banish both of those with this. Also Swordsoul can be stoped in some way with this and Phantom Knight's can be interrupted...  3x Summon Limit-goodbye Prank-Kids, goodbye Phantom Knight's. goodbye Tenyi Swordsoul, goodbye to any meta that special summons a lot, this card is their end.  I like this deck. It is the first Dinosaur deck I ever made and I hope there is not something bad within it. If you know a way how to make it even better tell me in the comments please.

deck_excerpt: Kill babies, summon dinos, bring out True King of all Calamities. GG
deck_description: The strat is all about starting off with a baby and dragonic diagram. Use the field spell to destroy the baby and add Lithosagym to the hand. The baby will let you special summon Oviraptor which you use to bring a baby to the hand. Then normal summon the baby and use oviraptor to destroy it and special summon the other baby from the grave. Then use that other babies effect to bring out another baby to the field.  Then use Lithosagym to kill both babies and bring himself out (allowing you to banish 3 cards from the opponent's extra deck. Then since both babies were killed, use them to bring out aeolo and another level 4 dino (misc or giant rex usually) and then turn your 2 level 4's and aeolo into Trishula to banish a card from your opponents hand. Then use both level 9's to bring out true king of all calamities.  Depending on the other cards in your hand you can also potentially get out Ultimate Conductor Tyranno and a baby for further plays.

deck_name: Blue Eyes Engine in Master Duel
deck_excerpt: The Blue Eyes Engine in Master Duel. A deck focused on using Blue Eyes to summon out powerful monsters from your Extra Deck. It's not really a great d
deck_description:
A super common way for you to special summon cards in this deck is from the graveyard, so do not be afraid to discard cards. Depending on what you have in your hands will greatly change how you play this, but this deck is also the famous "Brick-Eyes" where you can get a hand first round and realize, "If he has Ash Blossom in his hand or Solemn Judgement on the field I lose." This deck prefers going second as it has several easy set-ups into an OTK, but also can be completely wiped by any amount of negation. When going first, you have 4 plays;

  1. Get 2 level 8 cards on the field, Summon Draglubion, use its effect to special summon Heart-eartH Dragon, attach 1 of your Numeron Dragons as material. Heart-eartH dragon cannot be destroyed by battle and any damage you would take from battles involving the card your opponent takes instead. When the opponents turn ends their entire field will be banished, which leads you to using Draglubion to summon your other Numeron Dragon, attaching anything to it as material and than attacking your opponent directly for 18,000 damage. Even if they do get rid of Heart-eartH Dragon you can still summon Numeron Dragon, which means as long as there is a card in attack position on your opponents field you probably win, so this is still a very good first turn play.
  2. Summon Blue Eyes Spirit Dragon in defense position. It can negate a graveyard effect once per turn and if it is targeted for an effect, you can tribute it to switch into Azure Eyes or Black Rose, which will essentially negate the targeting effect and prevent all of the dragons on your field (including itself) from being targeted until the end of your next turn.
  3. Summon Chaos Max Dragon, it has a huge attack, your opponent cannot leave defense position monsters on the field and it cannot be targeted or destroyed by card effects. This isn't a sure fire win, it isn't your best option, but it is an option.

  When going second:

  1. Get Numeron Dragon on the field along with as many XYZ monsters as you can manage.
    1. Try not to special summon more than 4 times if you can help it, as the rock is a threat, but if you need to than you need to
  2. Get Neo Blue-Eyes on the field using either Greater Polymerization or Predaplant and just beat the living hell out of your opponent. It will be able to attack 3 times, cannot be destroyed by monster effects and deals piercing damage. It's a big 4500 beatstick that can deal 13500 damage in a single round
  3. If you're running it, get Accesscode Talker out, best to do this through link climbing. This means climbing up from Link 1 or 2, to 3 and than into Accesscode. You'll than have 2 or 3 non-targeting pops to destroy cards on the field 5300 attack monster on the field.

deck_name: Galaxy-Eyes 2022 with Gameplay [ver.2] -  Master Duel Fomat
deck_excerpt: This is an updated version for my previous Galaxy-Eyes deck profile for the game Yu-Gi-Oh Master Duel
deck_description:
https://youtu.be/n9R7tBW_3oI
Updates
Infinite Impermanence (x3 -> x0) Called by the Grave (x0 -> x2) Tachyon Transmigration (x0 -> x1)
Reasons
Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring and Maxx "C" are the most used staple cards in the Master Duel format. Maxx "C" generates so much value by punishing your opponent for playing the game. On the other hand, Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring is a way of hindering your opponent while they try build their board. Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring is also used because its able to neagte the second most played stable Maxx "C", which would be the most played card if only Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring didn't counter it. In order to combat this, I replaced a mid-tier stable for a hard counter for Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring and Maxx "C". It's called Called by the grave. The Master Duel format only allows for 2 copies per deck so I replaced the 1 copy of Infinite Impermanence with Tachyon Transmigration as running 1 copy of a hand trap isn't ideal, but running a card that is better for going first, providing a free omni-/multi-negation is better than a card that can only target monsters.
https://youtu.be/21uyQPhzs3s

Spam synchro boss monsters / Sphreez OTK. I don't play Caam because you're never winning long games against control and you only want to Egul for OTK. Can't be tutored otherwise and it bricks your hand. Twin Twister fine replacement for Droplet. Nibiru can be slotted in somehow I'm sure ... maybe by taking out gusto gulldo/egul or wind witch pieces. Lava golem also nice because you don't rely too hard on normal summon.  No Handtraps - just Maxx C to draw and Kaiju on your turn :)  Bricks a lot - Gusto griffin without discard / Gusto gulldo / egul / Pilica turn 1 with no tuners in hand or grave  Combos:  Gusto griffin+wynn/droplet (or twin twister) > gusto vedir or pilica  Ice bell > ...  Speedroid > ...  Pilica + ... > Sphreez > Tailwind (on Pilica for Gulldo, Sphreez for Egul) > slam for OTK
My main goal with this deck is to go 2nd and pull out Assembled Nightingale out and direct attack with max damage using the different spells that are in this deck :)

deck_excerpt: Sector Security is knocking on your door
deck_description:
Goyo is an archetype comprised of extra deck monsters only, and is used by Sector Security in both 5Ds and Arc-V. Being an extra deck only archetype, we use other cards to turbo out these Synchro monsters. This variant is a going first build that attempt to end on Goyo Emperor + Goyo Defender, and 1/3rd of the time also ends with an Apollousa.   Combo 1 Requires Deep Sea Diva / Righty Driver / Battlewasp - Sting the Poison Ends on Goyo Emperor + Goyo Defender
  1. Normal summon any of the 3 starters and special summon the corresponding card
  2. Synchro the two into Goyo Defender
  3. Use Goyo Defender to summon Goyo Defender
  4. Repeat step 3 with the new monster
  5. Link off two of the Goyo Defenders into Predaplant Verte Anaconda
  6. Use Verte to send Synchro Fusion, banishing 2 Goyo Defenders from the GY to summon Goyo Emperor
  Combo 2 Requires Deep Sea Diva / Righty Driver / Battlewasp - Sting the Poison + Synchro Fusion Ends on Goyo Emperor + Goyo Defender + 3 material Apollousa
  1. Normal summon any of the 3 starters and special summon the corresponding card
  2. Synchro the two into Goyo Defender
  3. Use Goyo Defender to summon Goyo Defender
  4. Repeat step 3 with the new monster
  5. Link off two into Isolde
  6. Isolde send Living Fossil to summon Renaud
  7. Renaud adds back Living Fossil
  8. Use Living Fossil to revive a main deck monster
  9. Link Everything except Goyo Defender into 3 material Apollousa
  10. Activate Synchro Fusion from hand, banishing two Goyo Defenders from the GY to summon Goyo Emperor
This is the first variant I've worked on, but there are more on the way, including Junk Goyo and Goyo Auroradon. If you like the Goyo archetype and want to see more, check out the Goyo Discord server.

First of all, Floowandereeze suck going second. It's mandatory to play 2-3 DRNM+Mine (or cut drnm for chalice).  You will brick more in this version than in duality+extrav/prosp build, but you can make some changes, like:  -> adding 3 simorgh+field combo for protection and "advent of adventure" targets (same with 1 more empen or more D.D Crow's)  -> main 2-3 Harpie F.Storm instead imperm (it can add survivabilty in case of going first)  -> main duster with or without cyclone to kill backroll decks  <hr />  -> Since it has no extrav or prosperity, extradeck got sum rarely usable shit.

deck_excerpt: Together with high impact staple trap cards and crippling floodgates, Machina functions as an anti-meta deck that controls the duel, simplifies the ga
deck_description:
With the release of the Structure Deck Mechanized Madness to the TCG in April 2020 and support in main sets, the previously directionless Machina finally had a game plan and a clear win condition. Excellent support for the archetype included Machina Citadel, which functions as a quick effect board wipe of all your opponent’s monsters which is a very potent form of interruption. Machina Overdrive enables a circular resource loop between the banished pile, GY, deck and hand, while Machina Redeployment greatly increased the consistency of the deck. Newer support from main sets like Unclaspare (R4NK enabler, free special summon and foolish burial) and Ruinforce (4600ATK beatstick and banish recursion) have also greatly increased the power for this archetype. The resulting support turns Machina from an archetype that was a jumbled mess into a compact powerful fighting force that can succeed in a grind game. Together with high impact staple trap cards and crippling floodgates, Machina functions as an anti-meta deck versus the combo-heavy meta! Control the game, simplify the game-state, then OTK your opponent in one fell swoop with your high ATK Machina army! If you want to see the deck in action, feel free to watch my Youtube video!

ARCHETYPES AND RATIOS

The MACHINA cards in the Main Deck consist of 17 cards: 1 Ruinforce, 2 Citadel, 2 Fortress, 1 Metalcruncher, 3 Gearframe, 2 Unclaspare, 3 Redeployment and 3 Overdrive.  This set of cards form the core of the deck, and once the cards in rotation, the monsters should rotate between the hand, field, GY and banished pile. The HIGH IMPACT TRAPS in the Main Deck consist of 9 cards: 3 Paleozoic Dinomischus, 3 Torrential Tribute and 3 Solemn Strike. These trap cards are called “high impact” since they all can profoundly change the duel with their immense power. These cards are the most interchangeable cards between the sidedeck and maindeck. The FLOODGATE TRAPS in the Main Deck consist of 9 cards: 3 Gozen Match, 3 Rivalry of Warlords and 3 Skill Drain. All these “floodgate” traps hamper or even completely stop your opponent’s ability to make plays, while at the same time allowing the Machina pilot to pop off. Be careful when using these cards, floodgates may stop your own gameplay as well! The CONSISTENCY cards in the Main Deck consist of 8 cards: 3 Pot of Extravagance, 3 Urgent Schedule, 1 Foolish Burial and 1 Super Express Bullet Train. Pot of Extravagance may as well be a Pot of Greed since the Extra Deck isn’t needed much, giving the pilot a solid +1 for little cost. Urgent Schedule (With its main target being Bullet Train for extra resources) definitely gets your gameplan rolling as well, enabling a variety of plays with 2 free bodies on board. The Extra Deck cards in this deck are mostly fodder for Pot of Extravagance and aren’t used much, but they still have some utility. It can be used for niche scenarios, field removal and to Machina on the field to the GY. Zeus also can be easily made with 2-4 matierials to wipe the field. It consists of: 1 Zeus, 2 Liebe, 1 Super Dora, 1 Gustav, 1 Drill Driver Vespenato, 2 Gear Gigant X, 1 Heavy Armored Train Ironwolf, 1 Accesscode, 1 Knightmare Unicorn, 1 Knightmare Phoenix, 1 Dharc, 1 Qliphort Genius and 1 Double Headed Anger Knuckle. The Side Deck features cards that hard-counter popular strategies that are bad match-ups for Machina Control. It was made with Eldlich and Virtual World in mind.  It consists of: 3 Artifact Lancea. 3 Droll and Lockbird, 1 Harpie’s Feather Duster, 2 Twin Twisters, 3 Evenly Matched and 3 Solemn Judgment.

COMBOS AND GAMEPLAN

The simple bread-and-butter “combo” this deck has involves normal summoning Machina Gearframe. It represents a “ROTA” and a “Foolish Burial” jump-starting your entire strategy while obtaining follow-up for the next turn.
  1. Normal summon Gearframe. Search Unclaspare.
  2. Unclaspare summons itself when searched (locking you into machines), and on summon, sends a Machina from deck to GY.
  3. With Unclaspare’s on-summon effect, send the Machina of your choice (Citadel is usually the target, since it’s the deck’s main win condition).
  4. XYZ summon Gear Gigant X with Gearframe + Unclaspare. Detach material to search for another Gearframe from deck for next turn follow-up.
The cool thing about this deck is that it doesn’t feature long and complicated combos, since it’s mostly a “set 4 -> pass” style of deck, making it simple to use! Even if this combo is interrupted, there are multiple ways to get Machina in the GY from deck with Foolish Burial, Urgent Schedule, and Machina Overdrive. Besides, you’re in no rush, since floodgates should bring your opponent’s plays to a standstill giving you plenty of time to set up. The entire premise of this deck is to control your opponent with backrow, then beat them down with stronger monsters in a simplified gamestate. Remember to use every backrow to its full potential, using them at the most opportune time to stop an opponent. Even if your opponent destroys your Machina, they all have floating effects that occur in the GY. Fortress destroys a card on the field when it is destroyed by battle and can handrip a card from the opponent’s hand if targeted by monster effect. Citadel summons itself from the GY when an earth machine is destroyed and can wipe the field by destroying your own machine – furthering your plays! Ruinforce can summon itself multiple times a turn given there is machines in the GY for it to banish and is an absolute POWERHOUSE during the battle phase. If your opponent doesn’t outright surrender to the floodgates and Machina recursion, the duel tends to develop into a caveman style “unga-bunga” beatdown. If you’re a Yugiboomer like me who likes a simplified gamestate without much combo where all you do is destroy monsters by battle, Machina Control is the deck for you!

THE ART OF FLOODGATES

Hey Machina Pilot, you cannot just flip over floodgates rashly, here are a few tips to maximize pain on your opponent with floodgates!
  • Most Meta combo decks straight up lose when any one of the floodgates are flipped over. Protect your floodgates, and they’ll protect you!
  • Monster reliant decks like Drytron, Tribrigade and Adamancipator die to Skill Drain.
  • Multi-attribute decks like Virtual World, Flundereeze, Swordsoul and Dragon Link flop to Gozen Match.
  • Multi-type decks and engines like Adventurer, Shaddoll-Invoked, Prank Kids and Sky Striker struggle vs. Rivalry of Warlords.
  • Many decks use Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer. To prevent this guy from coming back during standby phase, flip over Gozen/Rivalry during the draw phase.
  • Many decks use the Adventurer engine. To prevent the engine from being used, chain Gozen/Rivalry to Rite of Aramesir. The player would be locked into the token’s type and attribute which are Fairy/Earth.
  • Many decks use Predaplant Verte Anaconda. When the fusion danger noodle is summoned, chain Gozen/Rivalry to prevent the Dragoon or DPE from coming out!
  • When an opponent reaches a part of their combo that doesn’t match their archetype’s type/attribute, flip over Gozen/Rivalry. For example, when Virtual World/Adamancipator/Swordsoul summons Halqifibrax, Gozen/Rivalry would lock them from summoning any other monster!
  • Careful when using Gozen Match, it will lock out the earth/dark portions of your Machina Deck. It is better to be locked under Earth than Dark, since the Earth attribute offers more options for the Machina Pilot.
  • When using Skill Drain, try to already have Ruinforce, Citadel, and Fortress in rotation in the GY, field and hand. These all cycle around to summon each other forming a resource loop, while their effects on the field are negligible. This trio are superior in a game of beatdown, since they are relatively easy to summon and are high ATK.
  • Decks with built-in backrow destruction like Eldlich and Virtual World are bad-match-ups for this deck. Be sure to side appropriately when facing these them!
  • If you’re facing a lot of backrow removal, side in Solemn Judgment or Anti-Spell Fragrance to ward off those pesky Lightning Storms, Cosmic Cyclones and Twin Twisters.

GENERAL TIPS

  • Try to force out a simplified gamestate, where a grindgame is dominant. What this deck lacks in combo potential, it makes up for it in defensive control.
  • Since this deck can summon 2 rank 10s easily with Citadel, Ruinforce, Super Express Bullet Train and Urgent Schedule, Machina Control can make Zeus. 2 material + Rank 10 Train + Juggernaut Liebe -> 4 material Zeus.
  • This deck obviously prefers to go first. However, trap cards are surprisingly good at breaking apart established boards! Most meta boards can be broken using floodgates backed up by high impact trap cards. Bait out negates, then obliterate your opponent’s board with the appropriate card like Torrential Tribute of Gozen/Rivalry. After your opponent’s board is sufficiently softened up, that’s when you can start using your Machina strategy.
  • This deck can OTK in a blink of an eye, since due to the sheer offensive firepower of Ruinforce. This deck can also generate a lot of monsters with high attack on field with free special summons, while your opponent is hindered by your floodgates.
  • Machina Control is fairly cheap as far as meta decks go. All that’s needed is the 17 card Machina core + Trap Cards + 15 Extra Deck fodder for Extravagance. Expensive cards can be replaced by cheaper alternatives and the deck won’t lose much power.
  • Other cards for consideration in this deck that work excellently in Machina Control are Anti-Spell Fragrance, Lord of the Heavenly Prison, Ice Dragon’s Prison, Heavy Storm Duster, Waking the Dragon and Trap Trick.

CONCLUDING COMMENTARY

Nostalgic machine archetypes always have a special place in my heart ever since I’ve had cards like Machine King, Roulette Barrel and Mechanical Chaser from my childhood. My favourite archetype, Ancient Gears also are strong with recent support, but aren’t enough to reach meta status. Cyber Dragon reaches Rogue status, but only with the support of cards like Dragoon and DPE which aren’t native to the archetype. I wanted a pure machine deck that could do well while staying true to its roots! When support for Machina with Mechanized Madness and other main sets arrived, I was super excited! Seeing Machina top tournaments for the first time with pilots like Kyle Galliw and Elias Tsirogiannis using a Machina cards was inspirational, to say the least. Using their decks as a base, I’ve made my own updated version of their lists, designed to absolutely tear into the current meta! With Machina Control, may you strangle your opponents to the Shadow Realm with your paralyzing floodgates, high impact traps and seemingly endless Army of Machines. Dictate the pace of the game, simplify the board, then beat your opponent down with your Machina! And with that, I’m totally bringing this deck to terrorize my next locals. >:D GLHF Duelists!

deck_excerpt: A more "pure" build of the new predaplant support that focuses on a going second strategy
deck_description: The main strategy of predaplants is to summon as many of you're fusions as possible to viscously beat down you're opponent. And with the new support this is now easier then ever. One key note is to make use of "predator counters" which reduce you're opponents monster level to 1 and allow more effects to happen (basically uses you're opponents resources). Although it's not crucial to utilise them it boosts the ease to make and strength of you're end board. This naturally makes the deck better going second. The ideal end board involves as many fusions as you can spit out. Mainly; dragostapelia, triphyoveryutum and predator fusion dragon. I do however run a neos package, this summons rainbow neos which can remove all you're opponents monsters or backrow without destruction or targeting, which helps enable OTKs. And as a plus rainbow dark dragon can be summoned with this deck if you happen to open up with it, but this rarely happens. You could equally use DPE or dragoon. This build is a more "pure" ish build although I do recommend checking out "Branded Predaplants" which is a better version of the deck.

deck_excerpt: Competitive Spirit Charmer  - Easy to obtain/cheap - Strategies are straightforward  - Spellcaster/Dragon type Deck Difficulties: ⅗ combo type Ch
deck_description: Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Master: Charmers Deck The “Charmer”, or known as the “Spirit Charmer” is a standalone archetype of Spellcaster monster themed on controlling monsters with the same Attribute as them which is unfortunately not playable in any way without an exceptional support from another card. Surprisingly the new Archetype called “Magistus” came out soon after the “Spirit Charmer” was released in 2021. The “Magistus” archetype had a perfect synergy for the “Charmers” especially since they only rely on base from Attribute and Types. This deck is strong enough to be used in high Tier level on Master Duel or Tournaments(hopefully).... This build is very easy to obtain/play it and can be used for any newcomer duelist because most of the cards are actually straightforward for the combos which I already listed the key cards for anyone interested to play Charmer Deck. Start with only using 3 simple Key Cards which is the only best I ever come out with for the Full Charmer's combos. Just following the recommendation cards that are listed below. ___________________________________________ [Key Cards]: 3 Main Engine - Spirit Charmers - Performage Damage Juggler - Zoroa, the Magistus of Flame [Recommend] to Search/Use - Lyna the Light Charmer (Hand) & Awakening of the Possessed (Spell/Trap Zone) - Performage Trick Clown (Hand) - Artemis, the Magistus Moon Maiden (Spell/Trap Zone) = Crowley, the Magistus of Grimoires (Hand) ___________________________________________ Once you finally set up your cards. You will proceed with the next step by activating “Crowley, the Magistus of Grimoires” effect to send out “Lyna, the Light Charmer” from your hand to the GY. Then use "Crowley, the Magistus of Grimoires" effect to become Earth Attribute that allowed you to Summon “Awakening of the Possessed - Nefariouser Archfiend'' card from either hand or Deck by sending both “Crowley, the Magistus of Grimoires” and “Performage Trick Clown” from the field to the GY, which make them to trigger of their effects by Chain Link 2 and bringing it back “Lyna, the Light Charmer” from the GY to the field along with “Performage Trick Clown” by it own effect. Now you have finally had a chance to Summon “Familiar-Possessed Lyna” from either hand or Deck by its own effect. After that use “Familiar-Possessed Lyna” effect to search out “Dogmatika Ecclesia, the Virtuous” from your Deck then add it to your hand which is the only best Spellcaster monster with 1500 DEF/Level 4/Light Attribute monster that can be able to search out by "Familiar-Possessed - Dharc" effect when it Summoned by it own effect. Reminder: Do not activate "Dogmatika Ecclesia, the Virtuous" effect during your turn when it Summoned to your field, it will disable you for summoning from the Exta Deck unless if you have too. (This is an Optional) ___________________________________________ Tips: You might not actually get them from the opening hand with exactly cards. So I prefer you to try something else with different cards in your hand if one of the Key Cards are missing. You should better rely on your additional cards in your hand that might help you to set up your cards. Keep it in your mind that "Spirit Charmers" is just an additional card to use Familiar-Possessed - Lyna's Effect to search out "Dogmatika Ecclesia, the Virtuous" from your deck to the hand. ___________________________________________ [Additional] for more Consistency You can use "Summoner Monk" as additional for "Zoroa, the Magistus of Flame" or any Level 4 monster from your Deck like "Rilliona, the Magistus of Verre" or any Performage monster depending what card you need. Requirement: 1 any Spell card, except "Spirit Charmers" card, if not, you can use it as well if you have too. I include “Summoner Monk” from my Deck Profile since It actually works very well for any Level 4 monster. ___________________________________________ The End Board got changed frequently due to lack of cards since I actually used Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon lately in the actual game which is not my original plan for this deck. So I came up with the new play style by giving you more options to play either "Number 106: Giant Hand" or summon any link 2 like "Predaplant Verte Anaconda" depending on any situation if you have more additional cards on your play to expand it. I want to try something new in Master Duel with different cards that I have so it got changed especially from the Extra Deck. You can still use I:P Masquerena as usual to link summon “Selene, Queen of the Master Magicians” or "Knightmare Unicorn" during your opponent's turn. You can also add as many hand traps you want as long the key cards had three copies for each the following Recommendation. https://youtu.be/qWxPcD355y0

deck_excerpt: Dark Magician with the Invoke engine
deck_description: After playing with a much wider circle of people and gaining some experience with other archetypes, I decided to revamp my Dark Magician deck and looked for an engine to put in it and after testing with a friend I settled on Invoke and gutted most of the Dark Magician tech cards since they really don't do much. The deck does a good job setting a solid first turn board, searches out the pieces well and can play through an Ash without falling apart completely. The most basic opening play requires Magicians' Souls (Searchable by Illusion of Chaos and by extension Preparation of Rites) and Aleister the Invoker (Searchable by Magical Meltdown and by extension Terraforming) Normal Summon Aleister and search for Invocation (*If the search was hit by Ash Blossom just move on to the next part) Special Summon Magicians' Souls by sending Dark Magician Girl to the graveyard from the deck Link Summon Artemis, The Magistus Moon Maiden with Magicans' Souls Link Summon Predaplant Verte Anaconda with Artemis & Aleister Activate Invocation and summon Invoked Mechaba (If Aleister was hit by Ash you skip this step) Activate Verte in order to pitch Red-Eyes Fusion, Dark Magician & Red-Eyes Black Dragon and fusion summon Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon Activate Invocation in the grave shuffle it back into the deck and take Aleister back to hand. The combo nets you 2 omni negates and ends with 4 cards in hand and sets up your graveyard to draw 2 cards off of Soul Servant (which you might have opened with in which case the hand would be 5 cards) That is the main opener but there are other shorter ones, and they weave into each other to mostly always end on at least Dark Dragoon. For the side deck. If you would rather run a standard Ash + Crossout set up simply remove the Solemn Strikes, Timaeus and Apprentice for the general package. Timaeus and Apprentice will usually be the first to be sided out for whatever you want, and I wouldn't argue with going down to 1 Eternal Soul for the 3 of whatever you need as an out generally I side in Dark Ruler No More if I have to go second (These can also be replaced with Droplets, but the deck already discards for the negates and I don't have any Droplets)  other than that the side is pretty standard backrow hate except with Dark Magic Attack cause it's a searchable Duster.

deck_excerpt: A fun going second deck where the opponent's monsters can join in the revolution for a great time.
deck_description:
Example Duels - https://youtu.be/eQj6V8KheG0 Generally we want to go second (everyone wants to go first in Platinum anyways) to use spells bait out negates, go to the battle phase with no cards on your side of the field use Evenly Matched. From here you can start link climbing to get rid of the last card your opponent has and react to their next plays. If you draw Huge Revolution. you can set it to bait out back row removal/activate on your next main phase or keep in hand for Knightmare discards. We have several card draws from Card Destruction, Upstart Goblin and Sky Striker Mobilize - Engage!. The link monsters you make are generally countered by Kaijus so we have Super Anti-Kaiju War Machine Mecha-Thunder-King. It will let you banish their Kaiju and you can special summon a monster from your grave. Your opponent will try to hit into it (Numeron players) or summon their own Kaiju. You can special summon a low attack monster (reduce Numeron damage) or bring back that high attack link monster they used as tribute. If you think they have Nibiru, the Primal Being, try to get out Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess. Pay attention to where the opponent's monsters are placed incase there is an available Relinquished Anima or Geonator Transverser play. We can also steal a monster from their side using Sky Striker Mecha - Widow Anchor and have 3 spells in gy. If we have enough monsters, we can summon Underworld Goddess of the Closed World using one of their monsters as material. They think its their monster but in reality it is OUR monster. :) Combos:
  • Summoner Monk > Treasure Panda (several spells/traps in your gy) or Dark Doriado (Enchanting Fitting Room in hand)
  • Sky Striker Mecha - Hornet Drones > Token > Link Spider > special summon normal monster from hand
  • Unexpected Dai > Link Spider/Relinquished Anima
  • I:P Masquerena > High attack Link 3/4 or into Goddess on opponent's turn (use one of their monsters, negates their face up monster effects, stop a special summon from gy)
  •  Cyberse Accelerator + Accesscode Talker (usually 5300ATK if summoned with a Link 3 monster) >  Accesscode effect to destroy opponent's cards > Accesscode attacks twice
Link Monsters that you can't use normal monsters as material and will need to link off first:
  • Geonator Transverser
  • Borrelsword Dragon
  • Mekk-knight Crusadia Avramax
  • Accesscode Talker
  • Underworld Goddess of the Closed World
Cards from the Legacy Pack:
  • Card Destruction
  • Cyberse Accelerator
Side Deck:
  • Crossout Designator - Negate those hand traps
  • Forbidden Droplet / Forbidden Chalice - if you need more monster effect negation
Just helping a friend

deck_excerpt: Tri-Brigade isn't always needed for Birds to be good.
deck_description: Pure Lyrilusc is arguably easier to play than Lyrilusc Tri-brigade, sacrificing some of the grind game potential to have more simple options for those wanting an easier, yet still viable deck to run. While the deck is a bit expensive due to demanding 3 Recital Starlings as well as a lot of SR rarity cards, it's cheap enough that you can rely on opening the secret pack they come from a few times to obtain the cards necessary, and craft whatever you still need.  Nerval exists in the deck as a searchable 1-of to make going into Bird of Sovereignty much easier to do, and going into a Stormwinds and/or Dark Simorgh can end games while on top of 2 more disruptions (Utopic Future Draco and Ensemble Robin), but can be taken out by preference. The deck can go 1st or 2nd very well with some minor tweaks to the deck to make one or the other better.  The side deck options are alternatives you can try out instead of some of the options in the main deck.

deck_excerpt: Fun and casual deck that can win you games in gold for masterduel! Enjoy developing the rock combos in which can summon the big boss monsters that sto
deck_description: -Always pick to go first if able.  -Always activate special summoning effects EXCEPT for that of Granite (adding a rock monster to hand is always going to be the better move).  -Always wait to use the Adamancipator spells until you run out of gas with the monster effects.  -Don't wait to get Fossil Fusion in grave to use Miracle Rupture, just use it right away to get the grave effects of Weather Soldier or Block Dragon.  -Your targets for Foolish Burial or Miracle Rupture will usually be Weather Soldier or Block Dragon with occasionally sending Adamancipator Crystal - Dragite if you open with Adamancipator Signs.  -Your targets for Extra-Foolish Burial will always be Fossil Warrior Skull Bone or Fossil Dragon Skullgar (typically Skullgar for the free fusion summon). The ONLY exception is if you drew monster reborn, in which you would send Skullgios or Skull King for the free boss monster.  -Your targets for Granite will usually be Adamancipator Seeker or Adamancipator Researcher, but if you've already activated both their excavation effects, you can add Block Dragon.  EXTRA NOTE: Feel free to switch out Infinite Impermanence for a different handtrap like Ash Blossom or Effect Veiler. As of right now, I like Imperm the best because it can't be countered with Called by the Grave and it can't be negated by Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess.

deck_excerpt: If you want to play a pure Cyber dragon deck, you should give this a try!
deck_description: You need a good hand to start, and you can finish in 1-2 turns if you have many monster cards.  CD Core for searching Cyber Emergency, then find another CD monster  CD Nachster can be Special Summoned by sending CD Herz to the GY to activate Herz's effect, or sending Cyber Dragon to summon it by another effect of Nachster.  CD Drei is for XYZ Summon, to summon CD Nova and then CD Infinity, which is a necessary card with ablity to negate effect of any cards by detaching 1 material and to attach one Face-up Attack Position card to it as a material  Limiter Removal is useful for OTK, and you can use all monsters on the field to fusion summon Chimeratech overdragon  Cyber Network is very important, allowing player to summon banished monsters, especially when many spell cards in this deck involves banishing monster . As an alternative, you can use cyberload fusion to send all the banished monsters to the deck.  There's two way to play this deck. If you want to play safe and slowly, you should summon those Fusion Cyber Dragon, Chimeratech Rampage can destroy spell and trap cards, while Cyber End Dragon can inflict piercing damage. Or if you want OTK, you can use such cards as Power Bond or Limiter Removal for double the ATK or banish monsters and then use cybernetic fusion to summon a chimeratech overdragon with super high ATK up to 8000-9000 if have enough banished cards.

deck_excerpt: Casual Ursarctic deck for Master Duel
deck_description: Primarily a going-second deck.  Lefty Driver can be used with Ursarctic Departure if you start with it in your opening hand. Righty+Lefty is a one-card Ursarctic Polari combo.  This deck uses Effect Veiler instead of Infinite Impermanence because it is a Tuner, which can help make the level 8 Synchros.  Phantazmay can help find the right Ursarctic monster, you need and puts a level 7 body on board.  Gadarla helps bypass various Barrier Statues because this deck relies a lot on Special Summoning, but you can also use Effect Veiler if you need to.  Nibiru can clear the enemy board and the token can be stolen with Ursarctic Big Dipper. It is also a Rock, so excavating it with Adamancipator Risen - Dragite can provide some removal.  If you choose to use Pot of Extravgance, then you will need to run 3 copies of all the Ursarctic Synchros.

deck_name: Phantom Knights from 2 Legendary Hero Decks
deck_excerpt: This Deck is build from 2 Legendary Hero Decks. Cheap non meta but still fun to play.
deck_description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z_U0IXjzg9M   This is a fun cheap Phantom Knights Deck I only made it because I already had the cards left. If I start first I summon Dante. There are a lot of options, cockadoo, junk forward, kagemucha + any lv3 monster, silent boots with gloves or cloak. Use Dantes effect to send 3 card from deck to gy hoping phantom cards, repeat in turn 2 if dante is still on field. Next step summon Rusty Bardiche. Therefore you need 3 dark monster. With Dante, Armageddon and Foolish Burial at least there should be some phantom card in your gy. There are several ways: Easiest: Junk/Cockadoo/Kagemucha +Boots + cloak/gloves on hand. GY options: banish Wing, Blade or Sword to summon a knight from gy so you just need two others on hand. banish cloak to get boots on hand. If theres no trap in gy banish boots to get shade brigandine and activate instant. banish gloves to send wing to gy, activate wing to summon a knight from gy. banish fragile armor so send Wing, Blade or Sword, or a phantom knight if you have already one of them in gy. Activate Bardiche to protect yourself with blad or sword, sending to gy cloak gloves or armor Next step summon dark requiem. Your oppenent need to have min 1 monster and 1 other card on field. Activate Bardiche send 1 lv3 knight to gy and get rank up on field. Summon Break Sword (where Bardiche points to) just like Dante OR rescue ferret (1 phantom knight and another lv3 monster), but you need two phantom knights lv 3 in gy and/or as material (you already have 1 because of bardiche). Destroy 1 card with Bardiche if he has 3 cards or more on field. Activate Break sword to destroy himself and 1 card from your oppenent, but he still needs to have 1 monster open on field. Activate Break Sowrds effect in gy and summon two lv 3 kngihts (getting lv4). Summon Dark Rebellion activates his effect even the monster from your oppenent has 0 atk. In your oppenents tunf activae rank up and summon dark requiem where bardiche points to to destroy 1 card. If you can summon Rebellion before Break Sword its fine, with break swords you can destroy 1 card which is usefull when your oppenent has a lot of cards on field. In general: Use Leviair and Mist Claw to get back banished monsters. With twin twister send to gy what you actually need there and destroy spell traps from you or your oppenent (both can be usefull). If you dont get Dante protect yourself with a evilswarm (summon knightmare in first round is also good start). here i got Wee With and Dharc in Extradeck, beause i had them already. With them its easier to summon Bardiche. If you dont have them play the snychros and a second Cockadoo (Cockadoo+ lv 3 for coral dragon activate coral summon another card from gy than summon sky dragon) and antoher copy of dark hole and dark eruption. I love the Legendary Hero Decks, i play nordic deck and supported them with battle of Chaos cards (thats why i have dharc). I also have a elemental/destiny hero deck but now more than the half of deck isnt from legendary hero deck anymore... Big upgrade of the phantom deck is 3 Knights of torn scale, Burning abyss (Cir, Graff and Cherubini) but theyre "expensive"...cheaper alternative and still good support is Wee Withc, Knightmare Phoenix and Unicorn, Physic Tracker and Wheeler + Emergency Teleport.

deck_excerpt: Corporate sensationalism meets generic gameplay at it's own leisure.
deck_description: Video link in the description below: ( https://youtube.com/watch?v=Jpy1qxB_oWc&feature=youtu.be ) Dinosaur decks can sometimes be called "Nintendo meets Konami". Why is this? Simply put it that both companies are notorious at not only unoriginality and rehashing the same thing over and over; but also milking their same ideas to the point where the drops become crust instead of gold. While over the years we had some interesting occurrences from Ligthsworns to even Dogmatika; the fact that everything Dinosaurs touch becomes repetitive after awhile shows the reality with modern Yu-Gi-Oh and how Dinosaurs (as a whole archetype) symbolize corporate greed and how out of touch card design has it's consequences on it's own. That being said, the reason I went with the scrap variant was because it was the most recent to top at a YCS event with being at the Las-Vegas invitational back in February (with it finishing in the top 32 overall). Also while not directly aspired from this top 32 finished, I did concept some ideas for the sake of at least trying to find something new for Dinosaurs to try instead of repeatingly slapping the same gimmicks as hard as HEROs had the past few years. With the DPE package being the mainstay for most of Yu-Gi-Oh and the epicenter of the current fuss in the TCG (besides the Adventurer Package); I had decided to go with Dark Ruler No More and Ghost Belle & Haunted Mansion to either negate the effect before it happens, or to prevent it from repeating itself by stopping the special summong from the Graveyard. Another goody added in here is the Psy-Frame package: which includes Gamma + Driver, and PSY-Framelord Lambda (a link-2 monster that allows you to activate psy-frame gear monsters from the hand whether you control a monster or not). The side deck featuring cards like Token Collector and Super Polymerizationare all checks and balances against decks like Phantom Knights, SwordSoul, and Numerous Adventurer packages running afloat. The Extra deck which hasn't really changed much aside from newest Charmer Link Monster (Dharc the Dark Charmer, Gloomy), and maybe the super poly targets added in to keep Phantom Knights and other decks in checks at times. Then comes the scrap package, which features quite a mouthful to cycle from; but to put simply: you pop Scrap Raptor; Summon Chrimera off of the Raptors' Double Summon effect; Link Summon into Scrap Wyvern, to special summon (preferably) Scrap Chimera, to pop him to special summon Scrap Raptor, and pop one of your opponents cards. If that sounds like a waste of time that screams "how do you do fellow kids", then it obviously does, and Konami should feel ashamed and at least acknowledge that Dinosaurs "felt" more playable with or without this.

Zombie strat, pretty simple stuff, Doomking Balerdroch and Vampire Sucker, built around incorporating the Brave Engine, and built more as a kinda midrangey control grindy deck that gains resource advantage to take over the game. The goal is the get a Gryphon Rider and a Balerdroch on the field with Zombie World and Solemns ideally, but the different engines are perfectly capable of holding the games where you see one half of the deck. I like the idea of playing a maindeck focused Brave deck that doesn't lost to Scythe.  Let's go over the cards.  So I have a 10 card Brave package, pretty standard adventurer stuff, 3 Blue Girl, 3 Rite, 1 Gryphon Rider, 1 Adventure, 1 Dracoback. The last card is Foolish Burial, which is nutty in this card, but starts as a Rota for the Brave engine (while also finding Zombie World and Balerdroch when needed). I'd like more access to this engine, but near as I can tell Konami was wily with this engine, and realistically that's probably a good thing given how pushed it is in this form.  We can't activate the effects on the field of any monster we normal summon the turn we brave - we get around this by using graveyard effects, and by activating Banshee on the field on the opponent's turn when needed. You also have to sequence your plays right, since using Bloom locks you out of summoning Gryphon Rider as well. With that in mind, it is still pretty easy to put up a decent number of high quality interruptions very quickly with this engine. Because we are desperate for Zombie World, we're running 3 Banshee, 3 Zombie World, and Terraforming plus Foolish listed above. For Balerdroch we run 2 - you see it just enough in those numbers, and you'd rather end on Suck out of Bloom rather than just Balerdroch. You could replace 1 for 1 with the third Balerdroch if you're worried about grindier matchups with grave hate.  Next, I've got Pots. Weird mix, I know, but here's how I came to it. Initially I was running 3 Extra, but it didn't feel like enough "go" for me. I really wanted that raw card advantage, so I was on 3 Extra, but I decided to try 1 Prosperity in this mix. This immediately felt better in a lot of ways - the Brave engine gives you ways to pitch excess pots, and while Prosperity is usually weaker in this deck, I came to realize having 1 in the mix did up the consistency of the deck nicely. However, I was having some trouble in games where I saw multiple pots, since my Extra Deck got very thin very fast. I usually don't like Desires much, but in this deck you very often pull the whole engine out of the deck t1 before you ever even fire off Desires, and at 1 Desires if you play it smart it will almost never screw you. Again, raw cards are big here, and being able to actually pull those raw cards is important. However, I left the split, since Prosperity was fulfilling its niche quite nicely, and helps to mitigate from banishing all the Sucks or Link 1s or Barricadeborgs.  Interruption. Called is obligatory - ostensibly for hand traps, and useful there, but also just completely busted as an interruption. 3 Imperm is also kind of obligatory, and Imperm is basically the only Hand Trap I run these days. I think Solemns are also important here - Judgment helps stop sweepers from blowing out your field full of spells and traps, in addition to being a very powerful card and a decent chain ender in its own right. Strike is the ideal chain ender, this is the Countertrap that is good even going second, and having so many negates that pop is tight. 2 Ice Dragons Prison are insane here - they trigger Suck, and thanks to Zombie World also almost always have targets, and the card is already just an insane swing in a lot of common matchups before that. But I like the 1 Trap Trick in the mix over the 3rd, basically represents the threat of a third Prison, but also lets me stack an Imperm in the relevant column on the turn you set your backrow.  Accesscode is bad here, and still really good. But tbh you shouldn't have trouble grinding games out with this engine... assuming you can protect your threats that is.  Still tuning the deck. I'm up to 2 Adventure, and on just 3 of each Zombie World card with no One-For-One or Terraforming, just on most of my 2 card combos, trying to max my chances of the 3 card full combo payoff. One-For-One was hit or miss, but I feel like just running the third Bloom is usually better, and Terraforming was mostly a card I pitched for Adventure. With 2 Adventure you have slightly more, albeit slow, access to your engine while being able to stack your GY with Zombies, so it pulls dual roles, and you can even pitch a redundant copy to the first copy to recycle it with Barricadeborg. I still like 2 Barricadeborg even with a back-up Adventure, and protecting Adventure is still clutch, but the engine seems harder to disrupt this way, and the cost of running Adventure is low, in general, and especially in this deck. I'd love a 2nd Dracoback, since I've taken occasionally to using the token to make Slayer in order to get access to Balerdroch before making a 2nd token and then summoning Gryphon Rider, but this also now kills a lot of the grind game, since there's only 1 Dracoback, and Barricadeborg doesn't recover it. Still, I couldn't justify a 2nd Dracoback, the card is sometimes fine to see but is also kind of the main brick in the deck.
